Introduction
In the name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful.
The days of our Master, the Supported King, the Knowledgeable, the Just, the Guided, the Patron of Blessings, Abu al-Abbas Khwarazm Shah - may Allah Almighty perpetuate his authority and guard his glory and status - are the times of honor and virtue. His times are the chronicles of generosity and glory. His hours are the seasons of literature and knowledge. His breaths are blessings. His sayings are yes (approval). His actions are biographies. His traces are blazes (highlights). His words are pearls. His lofty traits vie with the stars in height. His generosities rival the atmosphere in vastness. His beauties compete with the sun in brightness. His virtues race with the rain in abundance. So may Allah perpetuate the beauty of time by his survival, and the perfection of glory and elevation by his splendor, and rain justice and benevolence throughout the length of his period, and divert evil from his soul.
When the High Command - may it remain effective and high, and a decreed destiny - came out to his servant created for his service, named Abd al-Malik for the servitude of his presence, regarding "Scattering the Verse and Untying the Knots" from the selected poetry contained in the book titled 'Mu'nis al-Udaba' (The Companion of the Literati), the servant took it as a Qibla to pray towards, and a foundation to build upon. He turned to prose, which is nobler, and in the path of kings and great men, more golden. Its companions are better, and their gatherings are higher. The ranks of scribes (writers) have always been and will always be elevated above the ranks of poets. For scribes, being the tongues of kings, only correspond regarding collecting tax, or fortifying a frontier, or building a land, or reforming corruption, or inciting to jihad, or arguing against a faction, or consoling in a calamity, or similar great matters and significant affairs, in which they need to be possessors of much etiquette and diverse knowledge. The service of kings has marked them with its honor, and settled them in the dwellings of its leadership. Their dangers are high according to the height of the danger of what they delve into and go towards.
Poets, however, their purposes which they aim for and their goals which they run towards are describing dwellings and ruins, mentioning homelands and yearning for desires, and flirting with women, then asking and begging, and praising and satirizing. Because of the low status of poetry, Prophets - peace be upon them - are protected from it, and Kings are elevated above them. Allah Almighty said to the most noble of His creation and His trustee over His revelation: "And We have not taught him poetry, nor is it befitting for him."
When Imru' al-Qais began reciting poetry and his poetry reached his father, King Hujr, he disdained it from him, rebuked him, admonished him, and scolded him lest he return to its like. When he saw that he would not desist, he ordered his killing. The servant ordered with that protected him, spared him, and hid him, then informed Hujr of his deed and guaranteed Imru' al-Qais's repentance from his poetry.
It was said to Yahya ibn Khalid al-Barmaki: "Why do you not recite poetry?" He said: "Its devil is more malicious than for me to give him power over my mind, and there is no good in something whose best is its most lying."
Abu Muslim, the owner of the state, used to say: "Beware of poetry, for it satirizes its companion at the slightest slip, and seeks for lying the highest reward."
Abd al-Samad ibn al-Mu'adhdhal expressed clearly the reality of the situation regarding the degradation of the poet's rank due to his busying himself with the opposite of right guidance, where he said to Abu Tammam when he intended Basra and overlooked it:
"You are between two things you present to people... And both of them are with a humiliated face.
You do not cease seeking a union... From a beloved or seeking a gift.
What water remains for your free face... Between the humiliation of passion and the humiliation of asking?"
When the verses reached Abu Tammam, he said: "He spoke the truth, by Allah, and did well." He turned his rein away from Basra and swore never to enter it.
Regarding weariness with the craft of poetry, Abu Sa'id al-Makhzumi says:
"The dog and the poet are in a state... Oh, would that I were not a poet.
Do you not see him extending his palm... Asking for food from the comer and the goer?"
And the most poetic of the people of Isfahan, Abu Sa'id al-Rustami, said:
"I left poetry to the poets because I... Saw poetry as worthless goods."
I have made this book titled "Scattering the Verse and Untying the Knots" into letters and chapters, most of them adorned with the High Name - may Allah establish it as long as days and nights last. I hoped not to fall short of the saying of Al-Sahib Abu al-Qasim Isma'il ibn Abbad:
"Indeed, untying poetry is the rank of a scribe... But among them is one who unties and then ties."

Chapter
The Virtues of Scribes
And their Praiseworthy Qualities and Descriptions of their Traces

"A Letter on Untying the Saying of Abu Dulaf al-Ijli"
"A people, if they fear the enmity of an envier... They shed blood with the tips of pens.
And indeed, a strike from a scribe with his ink... Is sharper and more penetrating than the edge of a sword."
And the saying of another:
"A people, if they take pens for a purpose... Then draw with them the water of death.
They attain with them from their enemies, even if many... What is not attained by the edge of Mashrafi swords."

Being hostile to scribes is not among the actions of those with intellect. Disputing with them is regret, making peace with them is safety, and befriending them is a benefit and a cold spoil (easy gain). What do you think of a people who possess the reins of wishes and deaths with the beauty of their speech, and preach on the pulpits of virtue with the tongues of their pens, and shed the blood of enemies with the tips of their pens? Of old, their writings sufficed instead of battalions, and the traces of their hands stood in for sharp swords. Great gifts and talents flowed on their fingertips. In the blackness of their ink is the whiteness of blessings and the redness of blood. In it, at times, is the spirit of life, and at others, the poison of vipers. Sometimes the sweetness of honey, and sometimes the bitterness of colocynth. One day the reward of bliss, and one day the punishment of Hell. That is the bounty of Allah which He gives to whom He wills, and Allah is the Possessor of Great Bounty.

"Another on Untying the Saying of Al-Sahib"
"By Allah, tell me, is the paper you write on... From a suit it is, or did you dress it in suits?
By Allah, did this word of yours flow from honey... Or did you pour honey on your words?"
And the saying of Abu al-Fath al-Busti:
"If he draws his pens one day to work them... He makes you forget every brave warrior shaking his spear.
And if he decides upon the parchment of his fingertips... The scribes of mankind admit slavery to him."
I do not know, my master, is your handwriting spread brocade, or is your word gathered honey? So by Allah, tell me, is your paper from a suit it is, or did you dress it in suits? And did your words flow from honey, or did you pour honey on them? By Allah, you, when you took the pen, nullified every hero who shakes spears and draws swords. And when you ran it on the parchment of your fingertips, the scribes of mankind admitted slavery to you. How excellent you are when your pearls scatter and your magic multiplies. You alerted to your word every alertness, and your speech was precise and exalted above similars, and resembled the presence of the King Khwarazm Shah. For it is, by Allah, the plan of beauties and the garden of blessings. May that presence not cease to be green and fresh, cited as a proverb in beauty, and to which the attributes of security and prosperity end.

"Another on the Saying of Abu al-Fath"
"May I be the ransom of the one who gifted me his book... So he gifted me the world along with religion in a scroll.
A book whose meanings within its lines are... Pearls in a drawer, stars in a constellation."
And his saying also:
"Your book, my master, cleared my worries... And by it my envy and joy settled.
A book in whose secrets is joy... Its whisperer is saved from sorrows.
How many a wondrous meaning whose word was inserted... There, paired any pairing!
Like wine in glass, rather like a spirit... That flowed in a body of moderate temperament."
May I be the ransom of the one who gifted me his precious book, and presented me with his intimate address. So it was as if he gifted me the world and religion in a scroll, and pearls of beauty in a drawer, and stars of happiness in my constellation. No wonder that it freed me from the slavery of my worries, and cleared from me the clouds of my griefs. So joy settled by it, and disturbance departed with it. What do you think of a noble book, containing general virtue and massive gain? Its exterior is a rained-upon garden and scattered pearls. Its secret is joy and abundant companion. It saves its owner from sorrows and reconciles between him and time. How many a subtle meaning in it, in a noble word! How similar they are in pairing to nothing but pure wine in pure glass, or to the body of ivory in the doctrine of brocade, or to the subtle spirit in a body of moderate temperament, or to the mirror in which the beautiful face and the pretty countenance are seen, and to good creation adorned by good character and sweet nature, and to the gathering of the bright appearance to the illuminating, splendid, pleasing substance. All this, my master, is belittled beside your book, unique in your beautiful manners. But I say it is as if from the presence of the Great King Khwarazm Shah, the Patron of Blessings - may Allah strengthen his victory - arriving, and from the chest of his kingdom issuing. It is shining with the light of his assembly, and fragrant from the breeze of his glory. No wonder that the hand gathers from it white crystal, the Black Stone, red sulfur, green life, and the kingdom of the Banu al-Asfar (Romans/Byzantines). I ask Allah to protect you from the eye of your perfection, and make your days your mounts to your hopes.

"Another on Untying the Saying of Ibn al-Mu'tazz regarding Al-Qasim ibn Ubayd Allah"
"A pen, I do not know what I see, or a celestial body... Running with what Qasim wills and traveling.
Kneeling, prostrating, kissing a papyrus... As a grateful one kissed the carpet.
And great of meaning, precise, subtle... And of many actions while it is small.
How many gifts and how many deaths and how much life... And death do those lines contain!
Engraved in the darkness as daylight, so I do not know... Is it writing in them or depiction?"

Is it a cutting sword, or a shining lightning, or a rotating celestial body, or a moving pen? It runs with what our Master the King Khwarazm Shah - may Allah perpetuate his kingdom - wills, starting and returning. It serves his will kneeling and prostrating, and kisses his papyrus as the thankful one kisses his carpet. It opens for him the doors of fruitful, pleasing gardens, as his command opens the fortresses of closed lands. It is the precise of appearance, the great of meaning, the small of shape, the large of action, the near of voice, the far of fame. How many deaths and gifts does what he wrote contain, and how many blessings and punishments issue from what he imports and exports! Oh what a magician of the soul by the soul! He plants rubies and pearls in the land of the parchment, and embroiders the cloak of the sun with darkness. Glory be to Him who taught by the pen, taught man what he knew not. He, the Mentioned, is asked to look after religion and the world by prolonging the survival of our Master and perpetuating his days, and subjugating time by the scratching of his pens and the clashing of his sword. As long as the papyrus laughs with the weeping of the pen, and the night of desire whitens from the day of judgment.

Chapter
On the Pen

"A Letter on Untying the Saying of the Poet"
"Deaf, hearing, stationary, moving... It attains the massive things of highness while it is lean."
And the saying of another:
"And a mute, eloquent one, thin from illness... It is healthy throughout time and sick.
Great, dangerous, people know that it is... Little, despised, may be humiliated and honored."
And the saying of another:
"I remained weeping over them while by my side... Was one adorned with the ornament of lovers.
Slender of body as if the hand of Time... Fed it from them with a cup filled to the brim.
Sharpened in its tongue for gifts... And deaths, a spit of saliva spilled."
And the saying of Al-Mutanabbi:
"Thin of the journey, running on the crown of its head... And it goes barefoot, so its running strengthens when it is cut."
And the saying of another:
"And a mute one speaking decisive words... While its body is silent, hollow.
In Mecca it speaks in secret... And in Sham its speech is known."
And other descriptions of the pen and its characteristics from the book 'Mu'nis al-Udaba' and others, which the book speaks by citing all of it. The beginning of the letter is in the way of a riddle and its end in his high mention. May Allah establish it as long as days and nights last.
What is deaf, mute, eloquent, weak, strong, despised, mighty, thin of body, great of action, slender of person, fat of danger, insignificant of appearance, famous of substance, light of burden, heavy of impact, small of size, great of crime? It gathers the descriptions of lovers in slenderness, yellowness, and spilled tears. It imitates the actions of Time in benefit and harm, and combining honey and colocynth, and mixing gain with debt, and kingship with destruction. It runs with misfortunes and fortunes between standing and sitting. It decrees joy and misery when the papyrus laughs with weeping. It judges cases, deaths, and gifts, riding five mounts. In one of its teeth is the spit of the viper injecting it, and in the other the saliva of the bee ejecting it. In one of its sides is the falling affliction and the effective poison, and in the other the beneficial medicine and the comprehensive cure. If it tires and dulls and fails and ails, its head is cut off so it returns healthy and speaks eloquently. As if it were the candle, its glory in its humiliation, and its life in its killing. Among its characteristics is that it speaks in secret in the East, so what it secreted of logic is known in the West. Among its subtleties is that it reveals the conscience and obtains what is in the chests, and divides people between graves and palaces.
I will not prolong upon you, my master, by mentioning its wonders and benefits and describing its returns and habits. It is the pen by which Allah taught first, and swore by last, and made it the scribe of His revelation and the tongue of His command and prohibition. Sciences are from its traces, literatures are from its fruits, and swords and spears are from its servants. There is none of us but bearing its blessings and vengeances.
How excellent it is as a brother who rose to the sky of virtue, and the orbit of glory, and the spring of generosity from the hand of our Master the Great King Khwarazm Shah, the Patron of Blessings - may Allah perpetuate his authority and establish his pillars. So it began serving his high thought, and standing as he wills at his command, and extracting the pearls of his nature from the sea of his knowledge, and setting them as a crown on the parting of his time. There is beauty in its entirety, perfection in its totality, eloquence in its comprehensiveness, and skill in its best exhibitions. There is the free speech from which the water of honor drips, and upon which the ray of generosity shines. How many a signature of his possesses the slavery of beauty and beneficence, and falls in the place of water for the thirsty. May Allah protect our Master from the eye of perfection and the calamities of time. And may the traces of his high hand never cease to be a Qibla to which prayers of magnification are directed, and upon which the circumambulation of reverence and presentation is stopped. Amen, O Allah, Amen.

Chapter
Noble Deeds and Generosity

"A Letter on Untying the Saying of Abdullah ibn Ja'far ibn Abi Talib, may Allah Almighty be pleased with him"
"And I am not competing for money by nature... But I compete for high ranks.
I love that people be below me... Throughout time in the nobility of deeds.
No, by Allah, I never loved money... For anything at all except for giving.
I benefit and people benefit from me... And what remains comes to demise."
Whoever competed for wealth so its resources expand, its supplies continue, its numbers abound, and increases with the speaking (livestock) acquiring its kinds, and the silent (gold/silver) choking its bags, then I compete for high ranks and noble deeds. I see bearing debts as one of the greatest gains. I do not care except for comforting the free and snatching them from the claws of treacherous Time. I love that people be below me in good deeds and praiseworthy qualities. And by Allah, the highest of oaths and the loftiest in the conditions of faith, I do not love money except to spend it and be generous with it to its people. I believe that what I give remains and lasts forever, and what I keep perishes and runs out.
How can I not be so when I am among the servants of a King who is Glory created as a soul, and Generosity represented as a person? He has an ambition in generosity that removes Spica (star) from spinning in height, and drags its tail on the Galaxy in elevation. Even if the seas were his ink, the clouds his hand, and the mountains his gold, they would fall short of what he gifts. His highness taught me the beauties of praiseworthy character, and his presence accustomed me to generosity with what is available. I do not gather the scattered money except to disperse it, nor do I go with withholding except in its path. I do not fear poverty while I am the neighbor of the sea, nor do I fear going astray while I travel in the light of the full moon. He is none other than he who, if described, is known, and if mentioned, is thanked. That is none other than the Just, Auspicious King, and the Successor of Al-Ma'mun, Abu al-Abbas Ma'mun ibn Ma'mun, Khwarazm Shah - may Allah strengthen his victory in the protected kingdom and prolong his survival to facilitate the rugged paths and bring joy to the sad.

"A Letter on Untying the Verses of Aban ibn Abd al-Hamid al-Ladhiqi to Al-Fadl ibn Yahya al-Barmaki who gave him for them what enriched him"
And they are:
"I am of the Prince's need and a treasure... Of the Prince's treasures possessing profits.
A scribe, a calculator, a man of letters, intelligent... An advisor exceeding the advisors.
An eloquent poet, lighter than the feather... Of what is under the wing.
I have in grammar acumen and criticism... I have in it a necklace with a sash.
If the Prince - may Allah reform him - shoots me... As spears, I hit the edge of spears.
I am not huge, O my Prince, nor stupid... Nor short and round (Dahdah).
A lank beard and a beautiful face... And burning like the flame of a lamp.
And fresh talk in every art... And having insight into witty trifles.
How much and how much I have hidden with me a hadith... That is with kings like apples.
The most auspicious of people in bird omens on a day of hunting... In my morning and at the time of my evening.
The most sighted of people in wars and horses... And in beautiful, pretty maidens.
All this I have gathered, and praise be to Allah... For that I am of witty temperament.
I am not the ascetic tucking up his clothes... Nor the ugly, impudent jester.
If the Prince calls me, he finds from me... A brisk one like the shouting bell."
And it is long and current.

I love that people remain below me… throughout life in noble deeds. By God, I never loved wealth… for anything except generosity. I give and others benefit from me… while whatever remains will perish. Whoever competes in wealth does so to widen its sources, lengthen its streams, multiply its kinds—collecting the speaking and choking the mute within his pouches. But I compete in greatness and noble virtues, and I see that bearing burdens is among the greatest gains. I care only for aiding free-hearted people and rescuing them from the claws of treacherous fate. I love that people remain beneath me in good deeds and pleasant qualities. And by God, the highest levels of faith and its loftiest conditions: I do not love wealth except to give it, and to show generosity to its deserving people. I believe that what I give remains and endures; while what I withhold will perish and fade. And how could it be otherwise, when I serve a king who personifies glory, embodies generosity, whose ambition in giving reaches beyond the highest star and drags its hem across the Milky Way in loftiness? If the seas were his ink, the clouds his hand, and the mountains his gold, they would still fall short of what he bestows.

His lofty rank has taught me praiseworthy character, and his presence has trained me in generosity with whatever is at hand. I gather wealth only to distribute it, and I walk with restraint only along the path that leads to giving. I do not fear poverty while I am a neighbor of the sea, nor fear misguidance while traveling in the light of the full moon. He is none other than the just, blessed king—successor of al-Ma’mūn—Abū al-‘Abbās Ma’mūn ibn Ma’mūn, Khwarazmshah. May God strengthen his victory in his protected kingdom and extend his life to ease the hardships and delight the distressed.

"A Letter Explaining the Verses of Abān ibn ‘Abd al-Ḥamīd al-Lādhqī to al-Faḍl ibn Yaḥyā al-Barmakī, who rewarded him with what enriched him":

I am one whose need is the emir… a treasure among the emir’s treasures, yielding profit. A writer, accountant, eloquent poet… clever, honest, surpassing the honest. A poet whose verse splits meaning like a blade… lighter than a feather beneath a wing.

In grammar I have insight and critique… in it I possess a necklace with a clasp. If the emir casts me, God will cast him… a spear that strikes like the edge of spears. I am not large, my lord, nor stout… nor a tumbling hulk. A soft beard, a handsome face… shining like the flame of a lamp. Novel in conversation in every art… perceptive of subtle witticisms.

How many stories I have kept hidden… stories dear to kings like apples. The luckiest of men when hunting… morning and evening alike. Most perceptive in war, horses… and beautiful maidens with charming looks. All this have I gathered, and praise be to God… for I am of refined temperament. I am neither a cloistered ascetic… nor a shameless fool. If the emir calls me, he finds in me… a warrior like a ringing bell.

And it is long, widely circulated.

Were it not that describing oneself to Kings and Masters and mentioning what virtue one has when seeking a means is among the known customs and habits, Yusuf the Truthful son of Israel (Jacob) son of the Sacrificed (Isaac) son of the Friend (Abraham) - upon them be the best prayer and peace - would not have praised himself when he said to the Aziz: "Appoint me over the storehouses of the land, indeed I am a knowing guardian." This is an introduction to apologize to the Prince - may Allah prolong his survival - for praising myself to his presence when presenting it for his service.
For I am a need among his needs, and the virtuous are the needs of the Sultan; and a treasure among his treasures, and the capable are the treasures of the time. I have gathered, praise be to Allah, the tools of royal service, and acquired the instruments of sultanic works. My hand in writing is like lightning, my pen is celestial in running, my handwriting is like a garden after rain, my eloquence brings its harvest near and its range far, and my speech in correspondence comforts its hearer and pleases its manufacturer. I have in calculation a line by which I apply the joint of correctness, and take with it the edges of literature. I solve in grammar the subtleties of problems and remove the obstruction of shapes. My genius in poetry is unlike any genius, and my nature is unlike any nature. The virgins of my thoughts are brides I clothed with rhymes and adorned with meanings, so they travel the path of proverbs and run the course of imagination.
I have of compassion and advice what is the fruit of correct belief, and of loyalty and support what fulfills the rights of allegiance. I have a sound creation, an accepted image, honeyed traits, and light characteristics which are heavy in the balance of virtue. I am not the thin, slender, despised one, nor the huge, grand, famous one. I am not tall exceeding the tall, nor short outside the limit of moderation. I am not the cold ascetic, nor the rebellious assassin, nor the abstinent ascetic, nor the exposed licentious.
I mix prudence with kindness, and dignity with burning (brightness). I adorn beauty with eloquence, and lightness with preponderance. I combine the seriousness of scholars and wise men with the jest of jesters and wits. I am not devoid of the etiquettes of the Diwan and the battlefield, and the beauties of scribes and knights. Opinion is not lacking with me; I see by its beginnings the ends of matters, and uncover the covers of curtains from their ambiguities.
So I am at times the pillar of princes and the equipment of chiefs, and at times the basil of boon companions and the melon of wits. At times the bitterness of cups is swallowed by me, and the joy of souls is derived from my company. At times I give Jihad the fullest shares of diligence, and imprint the judgment of endurance in the truth of the struggle. At times I extend the hand of jest, so I do not speak a letter in seriousness, nor hide from silliness with silliness. My insight in turning the mill of war, igniting the ember of stabbing and striking, and grinding enemies like grinding grain is not less than my insight in exiting in company from the shell, rising the stars of the drinking companion, making the tongues of lutes speak, asking rain from the clouds of intimacy, and breaking the seal of amusement. Nor is my knowledge of fine horses, sharp blades, and strong bows less than my knowledge of the branches of statures, the apples of cheeks, and the pomegranates of breasts. Nor is what I have of the news of Arabs and non-Arabs, and types of sciences and wisdoms, and etiquettes of the sword and pen, less than what I have of pleasant superstitions and humors of jokes, which are better than basil, wine, and apples. I do not resemble anything in lecturing with them and burning in good expression of them except the flame of the lamp and the shouting bell. Then I have in hunting, regarding the luck of birds, fulfilling the wish, and obtaining victory, what makes its trace good with Kings and its fruit sweet to them.
It is incumbent upon the Prince to accept the one who gathered the dispersed parts of these beauties with a good acceptance, and collar him with a necklace of favors, and to select him for himself, and take him for his seriousness and jest. If he wishes, he populates the gatherings of his intimacy with him. If he wishes, he mends with him the rents of his kingdom. If he wants, he specializes him for his sitting and company. If he wants, he entrusts him with a side of the sides of his kingdom. If he loves, he delegates to him the refinement of his works and the investing of his wealth. If he loves, he draws from him the sword of the tax and brings out the lion of the battalion, so he finds with him in all these states and affairs what verifies the best thoughts.
I have introduced myself to the Prince with my effort, and described to him what I have. If his witnessed generosity, good character, and high ambitions incite him to accept me and realize my hope, I will be the protégé who keeps the trust and the servant who thanks the favors. If he folds me in the folds of negligence and wraps me in the wraps of harshness, then in the wide earth there is a place to roam for one whose shadow has narrowed, and upon Allah then upon the King Khwarazm Shah - may Allah strengthen his victory - is reliance. I will spread my hope to his presence which is the Kaaba of hopes, the place of saddle-dropping, the Qibla of virtuous men, the refuge of persecuted kings, and the escape of tested masters. I will strike with an arrow in quoting from its light and scooping from its sea, and demonstrate my good condition by what appears on the one it helped. If I am of the great, then I have a model in Adnan al-Harawi, and if I am of the small, then I have a model in Ibn...

...Al-Tha'labi al-Naysaburi and Al-Salami al-Naysaburi. Farewell."

"Another on Untying the Saying of Marwan ibn Abi Hafsa"
"If he touched with the palm a dry, decayed stick... It would shake green until the fruit comes out.
You see him; 'No', 'Meet me', 'Return', 'Will', and 'Promise'... He did not say this, nor is there a need for him in it.
But he says 'Yes', 'Rejoice', 'Here', 'Take',... 'This'; mankind acknowledged his virtue for him.
If the scribes of Allah's creation, all of them... Yes, and their accountants, came to you and hastened.
To calculate or write a tenth of what... Your hands gifted one day of the days, they would not be able."
May Allah preserve our Master the King Khwarazm Shah for generosity and bounty. He is the one who, if he touched a dry stick, the water would return to the column, until it shakes and blossoms, and greens and fruits. He is the one on whose tongue do not run words of rejection and expressions of promising, like 'No', 'Will', 'Promise', 'Tomorrow', or 'After tomorrow'. But his saying to his asker and the seeker of his gift is: 'Yes', 'Rejoice', 'Here', 'Wealth has come to you', and 'Take this and that'. If the scribes of the earth and the accountants of creation gathered to write his gifts and calculate his presents, they would not be able to record a tenth of what his hands gift. So may his height last for him, and may whoever is hostile to him be his ransom.

"Another on Untying the Saying of Al-Farazdaq"
"Regarding Yazid ibn al-Muhallab when he was removed from Khurasan"
"Abu Khalid, Khurasan was lost after you... And those with needs said: Where is Yazid?
The throne of the kingdom has no joy after you... Nor does a generous one have generosity after your generosity.
So the East was not rained upon after you with a rain... Nor did a stick turn green in the two Marws after you."
I - may Allah prolong the life of the Prince - mourn for Khurasan, for events have happened in it, and confusion has covered it after him. Its affairs were disrupted, its frontiers were lost by his distance, and its landmarks became disguised since they became without his trace. Its pulpits almost wept for the loss of his name. The sons of needs and the owners of requests said: Oh my sorrow for Yazid and his granting to those coming to his door, and his good response to those intending his side. Oh my regret for that general honor, great character, noble nature, and massive gift. The throne of the kingdom has no joy with his absence, nor does generosity have a soul in Khurasan after him. Since his shading shadow departed from it and his abundant favor left it, neither a rain nor a drop rained on it, nor did a stick turn green in the two Marws, nor did a festival return to them. Even if the calamity was great by his removal, he was not removed from the authority of his virtue. And even if he was dismissed from Khurasan, he was not dismissed from doing good. Farewell.

"Another on Untying the Saying of Abu Ishaq al-Sabi regarding Al-Muhallabi the Vizier"
"He has a hand that excelled in generosity with its gift... And logic whose pearls scatter on the paper.
So a seal is hidden in the belly of its palm... And in its fingertips Sahban is concealed."
And the saying of another:
"He has clouds of generosity in his fingertips... Their rains are white silver and gold."
And the saying of Ali ibn Jabala regarding Abu Dulaf:
"Abu Dulaf, indeed tolerance did not cease... Shackled, complaining to Allah of its shackles.
So my Lord gave it glad tidings of the birth of Qasim... And sent Gabriel to it, so he untied it."
May Allah preserve our Master the King Khwarazm Shah. Allah's eye is on his high hand when it writes, and may a lasting protection never cease to be upon it when it gifts. It is the one from whose fingertips flow seas that eject pearls and coral, and from its palm arise clouds that rain silver and gold nuggets. It is as if Sahban is in it dragging the tail of his eloquence, and Hatim establishing the trace of his tolerance. No wonder that generosity is his ally, his friend, and his intimate. He did not cease to be a prisoner of a jail whose gate was locked, and a companion of shackles whose remedy was weak. So Allah gave him glad tidings of the birth of the Auspicious King, Ma'mun ibn Ma'mun. And He sent Gabriel, so he untied his shackles, cured his burning thirst, removed his illness, and made his tongue speak with praise to Him who broke a captivity and made ease after hardship, and with thanks to Him who brought him out by the blessing of his birth and the happiness of his resource from the humiliation of slavery to the glory of freedom, and from the burning of Hell to the Paradise of Bliss. May the world not lack beauty by him for whom Generosity is among his freedmen, thankful ones, and saints. May Allah perpetuate his days for him for noble deeds and literatures, as long as the coolness of youth is deemed good and the coldness of drink is found pleasant.

"Another on Untying the Saying of the Poet"
"Whenever askers come to him, lamps of... Cheerfulness and joy light up on him.
He has favors for those of kindness as if they are... The locations of rain water in the desolate land."
And the saying of Marwan ibn Abi Hafsa:
"O you for whom Allah fashioned his palm from generosity... So he knows nothing but giving and generosity.
Your gifts encompassed whoever is on earth entirely... So you and generosity are carved from one wood."
And the saying of another:

"If what you give were from the sand of 'Alij... The sand would have run out from your gift.
You vied with the downpour of rain, and the rain is heavy... So the dew of your palms lasted and the downpour stopped."
We have, praise be to Allah, a King who, when askers come to him and hopers intend him, the water of good news flows in his moon-like human face, and he gives them glad tidings of safety from time. His favors fall upon them like the locations of rain in the desolate land. How could he not be so when Allah created him from the clay of generosity, and made his palm the palm of the aided? He prefers nothing but generosity with what is available. It is as if he and generosity are from one wood. If what he gives were the sand of 'Alij, the sand would run out. If he vied with the downpour, the downpour would cease. May Allah water his morals with their likes from the flood of the rain clouds, and may they never cease to ease roughness and remove sadness.

"Another on Untying the Saying of Abu Tammam"
"He is the sea from whichever sides you come to him... Its deep is kindness and generosity is its coast.
He accustomed the spreading of the palm until if he... Bent it to grasp, his fingertips would not answer him."
And the saying of Zuhair:
"You see him when you come to him rejoicing... As if you are giving him what you are asking of him."
And the saying of Mansur ibn Badhan:
"Abu Dulaf never said 'No' at all... Except in the Tashahhud, but his saying is 'Yes'."
And the saying of another:
"I asked Dew and Generosity: Are you free?... They both said: We belong to Ubayd.
I said: And who is your master? So they towered... Over me and said: Khalid ibn Yazid."
Our Master the King Khwarazm Shah - may Allah perpetuate his kingdom and strengthen his victory - is a sea whose deep is kindness and whose coast is known generosity. His favors have accustomed him to spreading the palm, so if he wanted to clench it, his fingertips would not answer him. Whenever he is asked, his chest expands, his side shakes, his ease translates for him, the page of cheerfulness is read in his face, the crescent of joy shines from him, and the lightning of happiness flashes in him, until it is as if he is given what he gives. His sayings are 'Yes', and his actions are 'Yes'. People are the slaves of his bounty and benevolence. Were it not for the Tashahhud, he would not run 'No' on his tongue. I asked Dew and Generosity, I said to them: Tell me about yourselves, are you free? They said: We are nothing but slaves truly, and owned by bondage. I said: And who is your master? Pride took them with arrogance, and they dragged the tails of height and boasting, and said: He whose mention mouths find pleasant, and for whom no likes are seen, Ma'mun ibn Ma'mun Khwarazm Shah. When the mention of the High Name knocked on my hearing, I turned my face towards the presence of high ranks, and spread the earth with my hand a spreading, and engraved the dust with my mouth an engraving. I said: Many a slavery is better than freedom, and many a bondage is better than emancipation. May you never cease to be of the possessions of that King as long as the stars of the sky rotate in the orbit.

Chapter
Kindness of Asking

"A Letter on Untying the Saying of the Poet"
"O you whose right hand never ceased since it was created... To be the second drink and the first drink for the seeker of gift.
If you are doing a favor to a man... For the virtue of affection, then I am that man.
So bestow upon me a favor from you that revives me... For I am thankful for the kindness, bearing (it)."
You, O Prince - may Allah prolong your survival - are a sea that is generous to those who hope for it without excuses, and waters those who come to it second drinks after first drinks. If you are doing a favor to a distressed man, who has dedicated the parts of his soul to your affection, and spread the sides of his chest for your love, then I am that man described by loyalty to you, known for supporting you. You are higher of eye (more discerning) regarding what you see of bestowing a fruit from the fruits of your virtue that revives me from the speed of poverty, and saves me from the fangs of time. Knowing that I am thankful for the favor, keeping the trust, God Almighty willing.

"Another on Untying the Saying of the Bedouin to Ma'n ibn Zaida"
"May Allah reform you; what my hand shows is little... And the dependents have destroyed my money as they increased.
Chicks of a nest in a cast-away desert... Were in goodness as long as harm did not visit them.
Time leaned upon them with its chest... So they sent me to you and waited."

I complain to the Prince - may Allah reform him - of the bad state, the lack of money, and the abundance of dependents. Among them are downy chicks, old while they are young. They were in the shade of grace and under the wing of wealth, but days attacked them by reclaiming what they lent and robbing what they benefited. They threw their weight upon them and brought down their calamities upon them. When their nest rejected them and their living narrowed upon them, and they endured horrors that cause greyness and calamities that leave parents white-haired, they guided me to the Prince - may Allah support him with wide hopes - and sent me to him from distant lands, and waited for my return to them with leafy wood, abundant luck from fortunes, laden mounts, and heavy bags. If he sees - may Allah elevate his opinion - to realize their thoughts and delight their eyes, and bring them out from tightness to ease and from disturbance to tranquility, he will do so, God Almighty willing.

"Another on the Saying of the Poet"
"O Mighty One (Aziz), harm has touched us... All, and our family are scattered.
We have among men a very old man... And we have goods of little value.
Their seekers became few so they became stagnant... And our trade with them is trifles.
So count our reward and give us full measure... And be charitable, for we are dead."
O Mighty One - may Allah strengthen your victory and elevate your command - harm has touched us and our family, and bitter time has bent over us. Imbalance and dispersion have encompassed us, and sons and daughters have separated from us. We have a very old man from whose body and strength time has taken as it took from his state and grace. Allah afflicted him with non-existence upon old age. So we became of those with lowered degrees and owners of goods of little value. The matter is in stagnation, which is the brother of corruption, and its bad effect on a small trade of ours and a meager sustenance. We suffer from it mote in the eyes, choking in the throats, and lumps in the chests. So count the abundant reward and the beautiful thanks by a noble look from you that revives us while we are dead, and resurrects us while we are dust. And be charitable to us, indeed Allah is with the doers of good. And His prayers be upon the Chosen Prophet Muhammad and all his family.

"Another on Untying the Saying of Abu Abdullah al-Khali' to Ibn Tulun"
"I am praising, I am thanking, I am publishing... I am hungry, I am on foot, I am naked.
They are six and I am the guarantor for half of them... So be the guarantor for half of them with a standard.
Feed and mount and clothe, then you have loyalty... Upon choosing the beauties of the good ones.
And shame is in praising other than you, so suffice me... By generosity from you, my exposure to shame.
And Fire to me is like begging, so do you see... Not to task me with entering the Fire?"
I - may Allah prolong the survival of our Master - am praising him, thanking him, publishing his virtue. But I am hungry, and hunger is a great affliction and painful punishment. And on foot, and being on foot is mutilation. And naked, and nakedness is humiliation. These are six qualities; I have guaranteed half of them, and guaranteed our Master's generosity the other half, to run according to his manner in bestowing favor by feeding, and kindness by leading mounts, and magnifying the patch with the robe of honor. And he has from me loyalty with praise whose description is good and whose scent is pleasant, and thanks like the thanks of the garden for the rain and the night-traveler for the moon, and spreading like the spreading of reddish musk and grey ambergris. Let him know that I see my praising other than him and my exposure to his gift as a shame that no apology washes away, nor night and day efface. Just as I protect myself from Fire in asking and spilling the water of the face before men. If he sees - may Allah elevate his opinion - to protect me from shame and not expose me to entering the Fire, he will do so running on his habit in enslaving the free. God willing.

"Another on Untying the Saying of the Poet to Ali ibn Isa"
"O you whom the causes of Wilayah adorned... And who singled out noble deeds with care.
My clothes are silk-cotton (Mulham) on a day of snow... And suffice me, I do not prolong in complaint."
The one whom Wilayah adorned - may Allah prolong our Master's survival - indeed he has adorned it with his good traits, and cared for noble deeds until I returned from his servants. May Allah prolong his survival to invest thanks from the planting of his blessings. Our Master - may Allah perpetuate his support - sees me in summer clothes with which the hands of wear have played what they played, and upon which the changes of time have eaten and drunk. Winter has extended its canopy, and cold has untied its belt, and the heads of mountains have returned white, and dressed from snow a new sheet. I do not add to this amount of complaint, even if I endured from winter the most severe injury. Farewell.

"Another on Untying the Saying of the Other"
"I came to you, O Aqil, without brotherhood... Nor a cause being other than hope.
If you bestow favor, it is not strange from you... And if you prevent, I refer to Destiny."

Whoever seeks a means to our Master - may Allah prolong his survival - by a sanctity and a covenant, and a precedence of service, I seek a means to him by hope, spacious of sides. It suffices as a means with the virtuous generous ones, of whom he is famous for their sovereignty and the central jewel of their necklace. Then I mention to him my need for a haste of his aid, and a vanguard of his provision. If he bestows it upon me, it is not strange, and he obliges praise and thanks. If it be the other, I attribute it to the rule of Destinies running contrary to estimation, and I do not bind him with the sin of unjust Time and stumbling Luck. God Almighty willing.

"Another on Untying the Saying of Sahban ibn Wa'il"
"O Talh, the most generous of those who walked... In lineage, and the most giving of them of inherited wealth.
From you is the giving, so give me... And upon me is your praise in the scenes."
Our Master - may Allah prolong his survival - is the most generous of people in lineage, and the most noble of them in ancestry, and the most eager of them to enslave the free with favors, and the most generous of them in spending inherited and newly acquired money. Until he is, in confirming thoughts, dispersing the stored, and spending the preserved, Ma'mun ibn Ma'mun. So from him is the giving and from me the praise. To him belong the gifts, and to me the praise. Upon him is the righteousness, and upon me the thanks. I will convey of that in the crowded scenes and special gatherings what noble deeds will rejoice at and seasons will shake for. God willing.

"Another on Untying the Saying of Abu Ahmad ibn Abi Bakr al-Katib to Abu al-Fadl Muhammad ibn Abdullah al-Bal'ami"
"O Abu al-Fadl, you have the clear Fadl (virtue)... And with what you are nicknamed, you are worthy.
No blessing is devoid of Zakat... That necessitated the thanks of the Lord of the Worlds.
So the Zakat of money is from its types... And the Zakat of Jah (status) is aiding the seeker of help."
No wonder our Master - may Allah prolong his survival - was nicknamed Al-Fadl, for he is its father, its son, and its brother. The nickname agreed with the one nicknamed, and its word matched its meaning. Allah looks after Al-Fadl and Isfadal (bestowing favor) by prolonging his period, perpetuating his joy, and guarding his soul. Our Master - may Allah perpetuate his support - has known that blessings which necessitate thanking Allah for them are hardly devoid of Zakats by which gifts are preserved and increases are milked. So the Zakat of money from its types is known, and to its deserving ones in the rule of Sharia is directed. And the Zakat of Jah is spending aid to its seeker, and fulfilling the need for its owner. Here I am asking rain from the clouds of his Jah, and seeking victory over Time by his good opinion. I ask him to occupy an hour of his days with me, to return to me what has dried up of the water of my face, which is above my blood, and renew for me what has worn out of my Jah, which is above my money. He - may Allah perpetuate his empowerment - does good beautifully, and collars his allies with favors. God Almighty willing.

Chapter
Demanding and Seeking Increase

"A Note on Untying the Saying of the Poet"
"Suffice as a reminder of my affair my face... And suffice you that I see you and you see me.
And indeed, if I draw near, I observe my right... And if I am far, do not forget my place."
The reminder benefits the believers, and is tolerated from the sincere. I limit myself from reminding him of my affair to what my face confronts him with, and suffice myself from demanding my need by what he sees of my person and imagines of my condition. I know that if I attend him, he obliges (gives) to me, and if I am absent from him, he does not forget me. If I write to him, he answers me about my letter and to my request. Allah keeps him and protects him, and protects me from seeing evil and hearing it regarding him.

"Another on Untying the Saying of the Other"
"I go for a greeting and come for its like... And suffice you with the greeting from me as a demand."
I - may Allah prolong the Sheikh's survival - go to his presence for greeting and come. I do not reveal what is in my chest of need as long as the spirit accompanies me. Rather, I leave that to his piercing acumen and his constant care. I trust his answering the caller of generosity in my affair. There is no doubt in his eagerness for what leads to attracting my thanks. Suffice with the greeting as a demand, and with the visit as an exaction. Many a signal is more eloquent than an expression, and an allusion more effective than a declaration, and a tongue of condition more articulate than a tongue of speech. Farewell.

"Another on Untying the Saying of the Poet"
"I remind, not that I knew you forgetting... My affair, nor that I think you heedless.
But I saw the sword, after its drawing... Needing shaking, even if it is sharp."
I do not remind the Sheikh - may Allah prolong his survival - as one forgetting my interests, nor heedless of my successes. He is more remembering of the needs of his allies than to be alerted to them, and more intensely embracing of them than to be called to them. A sword may be shaken while it is sharp, and a horse urged while it is swift. I am, regarding the Sheikh - may Allah support him - on an appointment, and his fulfillment for me is in wait. God Almighty willing.

"Another on Untying the Saying of the Speaker"
"And I smelled the breeze of success for my need... And behold, it has a breeze from your palms.
I worked myself in your hope, which has... A neck (pace) towards you urging me and a trot."

"And perhaps I despaired, then I say: No... Indeed, he who guaranteed success is generous."
The star of desire has appeared to me - may Allah prolong the Prince's survival - in his courtyard, and the breeze of success has wafted from his palm. A mount, easy to ride, neither rough nor slow, has lifted me to hope. It connects the fast pace with the trot, and confronts me with the tongue of the massive deed. Perhaps the tongue of whisper symbolizes to me despair of people, so I say: No, by Allah, while the guarantor of success is generous, filling his clothes, successful in the extension of his breaths. May his glory not cease remaining, and his sea watering.

"Another on Untying the Saying of the Poet"
"O you who mastered us in nobility and generosity... And surpassed in his virtue all creation.
By the right of Muhammad and the sons of his sons... And his refined, pure family.
Connect the broken feather of my wing... With a dismissal (setting free) and a splendid prize.
For the like of you, negligence does not befit him... And the like of me, the attribution does not suit him."
Our Master - may Allah prolong his survival - has surpassed those in the horizons with his overflowing generosity and the white traces of his bounty. May the springs of tolerance never cease to explode from his fingertips, and the spring of virtue laugh about his favors. I ask him by the right of Muhammad the Messenger of Allah, his elect, his choice from his creation, and his family, who are the clan of Faith and the tree of Good Pleasure, to lighten the burden of need from me, mend what Time has whittled of me, fix what poverty broke of my wing, and combine my lamp and my success. For the like of him is above negligence, and the like of me is too small for demanding. I ask Allah to prolong his survival for a kindness that ends at its farthest, and a favor that leads by its forelock.

"Another on Untying the Saying of the Poet, written to Al-Ma'mun"
"My need to you has become distant, so order for me... O my Prince, hastily a dye."
The period - may Allah prolong the Prince's survival - has become long regarding my need with him, until the crow of its youth flew, and the day rose beside its night, and the morning of its greyness whitened, and whiteness covered the blackness of its hair. It became of those of high ages and companionship to the past days. If the Prince - may Allah elevate his command - orders for it a dye that returns the hue of its youth and delights the eyes of its loved ones with it, he would have sold stagnant goods and repaired a corrupt state. God Almighty willing.

"Untying the Answer of Al-Ma'mun about it"
"We have ordered for it a dangerous dye... That leaves the head like the blackness of the crow."
We have ordered for it - may Allah support you - a dye, black of skin, coal-black of jilbab, intense of robe, crow-like in color. As if it is from the darkness of horses, or from the dress of the Abbasids, or from the clothing of bereaved mothers, or from the braids of virgins, or from the pupils of houris, or from the saliva of darkness. So let it use the dye even if it is from false witnesses, and let it return youth even if it is from the goods of deception.

"Another on Untying the Saying of the Poet"
"If the gift is after procrastination... Then may it not be, even if it is abundant.
So may rain be for the gift, then rain... If it is easy, even if it is little.
And poets have sharp tongues... Over defects, fulfilling, indicative.
It is of the intelligence of the noble if they fear them... And treat them with beautiful treatment.
If they place their brandings upon them... Even if they strive, they have no trick."
You have known - may Allah support you - that procrastination muddies the favor even if it is high, and makes the gift hateful even if it is splendid. Just as hastening makes it big even if it is small, and makes it much even if it is little. Poets resent those who drag them on the thorns of procrastination and deprive them of the fruit of the promise. They have tongues that drain seas, split rocks, make the absent hear, tear the veil, indicate defects, and uncover hidden things. If they brand with them, they make an outcry as they wish. If they satirize, they excel and have done evil. If their speech becomes denounced and their arrows penetrate, there is no trick to repel them unless the fruit returns to the calyxes and the children to the wombs. The prudent is he who treats them with the best treatment, does not take the path of disputation with them, looks after his honor by bestowing upon them, and protects against evil by presenting good to them. You - may Allah support you - take heed from what you hear and understand, and act by what you know. God willing.

"Another on Untying the Saying of Mansur al-Faqih al-Misri"
"Abu Ja'far, you are not fair... And the like of you, if he says a saying, fulfills.
So either you fulfill my promise... Or you will be satirized and inserted into 'Fi' (In).
And people have known what is after it... So cover the talk and do not reveal."
Abu Ja'far, how many are your morals and how little is your fairness! The like of you is he who, if he promises, fulfills, and if he contracts, completes. So either you preserve the past covenant and fulfill the previous promise, and be of those who are fair and fulfill. Or else you will be rubbed and inserted into 'Fi'. And what is after it is known, and the meaning is understood. It is not hidden from people what I alluded to, and your way is to cover it. God Almighty willing.

"Another on Untying the Saying of the Speaker"
"Say to the Prince, and there is no harm in the truth... Leave off your striking fives for sixes (plotting/confusion).
From two, do not be stingy with one... Either the gift or the comfort of despair."
It is incumbent upon me - may Allah support the Prince - not to say other than the truth, and my fingertips run not with other than honesty. Regarding either matter, its consequence is sweet, and the weight of its fruit is light. I have a subtle point of its width and a short one of its length, which is that striking fives for sixes is not of the action of noble people. So either the fruit of success or the spirit of despair. I say what Allah the Manan said: 'So retention with honor or release with kindness.'

"Another on Untying the Saying of the Poet regarding Yahya ibn Khalid al-Barmaki"
"I saw Yahya - may Allah perpetuate his state - ... Doing of kindness what no one has done.
He forgets what was of his favor always... To the seekers, and does not forget what is promised."
Our Master - may Allah prolong his survival - is the unique of mankind and the single of the noble. His days are a fertile spring, and his generosity is strange and wondrous. He folds what preceded of benevolence in the folds of negligence and forgetfulness, and remembers what precedes of his promise until he engraves it in the gem of his chest, and directs all his thought to fulfilling it. As if he has looked into the biographies of our Master the King Khwarazm Shah - may Allah perpetuate his kingdom - and encompassed the greatness of his blessings and the subtleties of his generosity, so he adopted his character and ran in his paths. By my life, whoever contemplated his news and observed his traces knew that Generosity is Ma'muni not Barmaki, and Bounty is Khwarazm Shahi not Hatimi. He knew that were it not for the wonders of Allah's creation and the marvels of Allah's kindness, those noble deeds would not have grown in flesh, nor those virtues mixed with blood, nor those beauties gathered in a person, nor those prides organized in a soul. So Glory be to Allah when you enter the evening and when you enter the morning, and Glory be to the Creator of Ma'mun ibn Ma'mun.

"Another on Untying the Saying of the Poet"
"Necessities in matters call... To using what is not befitting of etiquette.
And the confusion of a man in his fluctuation... Calls to his persistence in the request."
Our Master - may Allah prolong his survival - knows that necessity permits the prohibited, breaks chivalry, rejects youthfulness, and calls a man to what is not good for him nor befitting his lineage and etiquette. Just as he knows that excessive confusion prevents the obligatory choice, and carries the shy to impudence until he does not care about ugliness. May Allah protect our Master from all that runs contrary to his preference and comes between him and his choice. Violent necessity and severe confusion have combined upon me - may Allah perpetuate our Master's support - which licensed for me the persistence which is not of my characteristics, and incited me to urgency which was not of my ways. Our Master - may Allah perpetuate his days - is higher of eye in what he sees of treating my condition with the medicine of his generosity, and holding my last breath with a drop of his rain.

"Another on Untying the Saying of the Other"
"May Allah prolong safety and survival for you... And increase you in the world in height and ascent.
I sent my messenger and he is the bearer of my note... So your opinion regarding what I said yesterday is successful."
The Sheikh - may Allah prolong his survival and perpetuate his ascent in high ranks - meets with my note the one who is my messenger in obtaining my request. So his opinion in returning my thought confirmed, and dismissing it with success granted, God Almighty willing.

"Another on the Saying of the Poet to Abdullah ibn Tahir"
"What shall I say if I am asked and it is said to me... What did you obtain from the Generous, the Preferring?
If I said he gave me, I lied, and if I say... The Prince was stingy with his money, it would not be beautiful.
So choose for yourself what I say, for I... Must inform them even if I am not asked."
I - may Allah prolong the Prince - am of rising intention, departing resolve, traveling concern and belief. Nothing remains but the march, and from Allah is facilitation. I do not know what to say when I return to my homelands and authority, and witness my friends and brothers, and they ask me about my condition in his presence and my share of the fruits of his service. If I said I obtained the fertile gardens of his blessing, and the cloud of his connection rained on me, the tongue of my condition would belie the tongue of my speech, and my bags and loads would not praise him. And if I said that the Prince - may Allah perpetuate his support - was stingy and did not verify the thought, I would be describing the full moon as not shining, the musk as not diffusing scent, and the sea as sinking and not overflowing. So I stand where his choice stops me, of thanks or complaint, and his preference approves for me, of praise or seeking increase. If he sees - may Allah elevate his opinion - to unleash my tongue with the more beautiful of the two sayings regarding him, and entrust me only to the better of the two thoughts of him, he will do so, God Almighty willing.

"Untying the Answer to it by Abdullah ibn Tahir"
"You hastened us, so the hastiness of our kindness came to you... Little; had you given us respite, it would not have been little.
So take the little and be as if you did not say... And we will be as if we did not do."

You addressed us - may Allah support you - with the address of one who equipped, loaded, and emerged, marching without slackening and heading without turning back. We preferred that you stay and not depart, so that we reach of fulfilling your right what comes with leisure, not with speed and haste. Since you have renewed your resolve for travel, and stripped your concern for the homeland, may Allah make the best accompanying you in your stay and departure, your travel and presence, and all your actions and directions. We have ordered for you a little haste of kindness; what makes it much is the excuse in the shortcoming with the hastiness. So take it and suppose that you did not ask, so we know that we did not give. The matter is sufficient with us, neither for us nor against us. And (?) between us is standing, no blame binds either of us. Farewell.

"Another on Untying the Saying of Mansur al-Faqih"
"Indeed, the Imam of Hijaz judges... Upon you in the promise with guarantee.
And I have promises with you following in succession... Known of time and place.
So fulfill the promise or declare... The breach, and be safe from time.
And do not torture with 'will' (saufa) a heart... Ulcerated by procrastination and delay."
The Sheikh - may Allah prolong his survival - is Hijazi in Fiqh, Shafi'i in religion. Among his doctrine is that whoever promised a promise has guaranteed a guarantee and covenanted a covenant. And in the religion of chivalry and rights of youthfulness is that whoever gave the document from his tongue, its conditions are binding on him in reality. I have in the custody of his generosity promises known of times and eras, known of locations and places. If he fulfills the covenant and completes the contract, he has mended my fracture, untied my captivity, and engrossed my thanks. If he sees otherwise, then declaration is comforting, and there is no harm in the cold of despair. How worthy he is not to increase the torture of a heart exhausted by the promise, stripped on the thorns of procrastination, wounded by the fangs of time. Allah aids him in good deeds, grants him success for benevolences, and provides him abundant share of the enduring righteous deeds.

"Another on Untying the Saying of Ibn al-Rumi"
"May I be your ransom; I did not ask... You for that robe for a shroud.
I asked you for it to wear it... While my soul is still in my body.
Procrastination has become long with it... And I feared the accidents of time.
So do not make it a yarn... Its weaver rejoiced to Aden.
Lo, bestow it, for indeed... Mastery is the hastening of favors.
Lo, and make it complying with... The beauties of your handsome face.
Pure like your honor, indeed it... Was not mixed with filth.
Thick like your opinion... Indeed it and firmness are in a horn (coupled).
Thin like your acumen which... became finer than intellects.
And let not its value impress you... Suffice with praise as a price.
And suffice you, if you were stingy with it... With the loss of praise as a loss."
May Allah make me your ransom, O my master, and prolong your survival. Until when is this severe procrastination with the new robe? Why did the promise in it become like threats? Did you not know that I asked you for it to wear in my life, not to be shrouded in it at my death? Deferment has become long with it, violent, until I feared the hindrances of accidents, and was not safe from the calamities of time. It should not be that its weaver rejoiced to Yemen and threw his staff in Sana'a or Aden. The guarantor is only your virtue in sufficing the trouble of requesting it, and running on the rule of your sovereignty in bestowing it upon me, and answering my prayer by your generosity to execute it complying with your beauties, imitating your characteristics. And make it pure like your honor which was not mixed with what stains it, nor marred by what dirties it. Choose it thick like your opinion which no defect permeates, thin like your acumen which no slip encounters. Let not its value seem great to you, for praise is higher and more expensive to Allah, and more worthy of extraction. If you were stingy with it - and far be it from you - suffice you the missing of thanks as a defect, and enough.

Chapter
Procrastination and Breaking the Promise

"A Letter on Untying the Saying of Ibn al-Rumi"
"If your procrastination had a spirit and a body... In its length, we would not doubt that it is Awj (bin Unuq).
Just as your gift, with what is in it of shortness... If it passed by people, they would say: Ya'juj (Gog) passed."
And the saying of another:
"We tested you, praise be to Allah... Indeed testing avails.
And behold, all your promises... And the wind are equal."
And the saying of another:
"You prolonged waiting for tomorrow after tomorrow... And I did not see from you a hand over a hand.
So name a tomorrow whose time I wait for... For every tomorrow has after it a thousand tomorrows."

Procrastination has become long - may Allah prolong your survival, my master - as if I bend from it upon Awj, or see by it the shadow of the spear, and witness the life of the vulture, or suffer the night of abandonment, or witness the Day of Resurrection. I do not compare your gift to Ya'juj in its shortness, littleness, and smallness. It is shorter than the fingertip of an ant, less than a single atom, and smaller than a tuft of hair under the lower lip. I have tested you - if tests were useful, and revealed to me the consequences from you - regarding promises that have resemblance to the wind, and they are a cause of the deceiving lightning, and between them and the waterless cloud is a relation. Until when - may Allah reform you - do you drag me on the thorns of procrastination, deprive me of the fruit of the promise, and distract me with tomorrow and after tomorrow, while I do not see a hand for you over a hand? Has the time not come for you to specify the relied-upon day, and leave me from the frequent mention of tomorrow, for it is far of term, connected to eternity?

"Another on Untying the Saying of the Poet"
"I asked you for a need, so you answered regarding it... With the best that can be of an answer.
When I aimed for it, it aimed for the Pleiades... So my need became above the clouds."
And the saying of Abu Nuwas:
"You promised me your promise until when... You made me covet the treasure of Qarun.
You came at night with washing water... Washing what you said with soap."
And the saying of Abu al-Ayna':
"I do not wonder, nay your deeds are more wondrous... At the length of my frequenting you while you lie.
And you say to me a saying I think you are truthful... So I come out of greed to you and go.
If I and you gathered in a session... They would say: Musaylimah and this is Ash'ab."
I asked you - may Allah reform you - for a need, light in burden upon you, heavy in favor for you. You combined for me in it the best answer and the most complete acceptance. When I aimed for it, it was with the Pleiades in height, and with Capella in direction. I began imagining it once at the end of the earth, and at times above the clouds. Long have you made me covet the treasures of Qarun with your honeyed promises, then followed them with your washed excuses. I do not know which of our two states is more wondrous, just as I do not know which is more lying: My greed for you which renews my reliance on you and repeats my frequenting you, or your tongue which professes lying as a doctrine and finds breach soft as a mount. If a crowded forum gathered me and you, or a private gathering joined us, some of their people would turn to others criticizing you and cursing you, saying: This is Musaylimah, meaning you, and this is Ash'ab, meaning me, and attributing me to false greed. Musaylimah was the biggest liar the green (sky) shaded, and Ash'ab the greediest the dusty (earth) carried. News of that in lying has traveled in the lands and arrived at the waters, and news of this in greed has flown in the horizons and ridden the mouths. May Allah accept our repentance from lying and calumny, and from pure breach, and from greed that leads to stain (nature), by His grace and kindness and vast mercy.

"Another on Untying the Saying of Abu Tammam"
"And a veiled one I sought, so I found him... A star distant from the riders of seekers.
When I lacked his gift, I deprived him... Of my thanks, so we went away deprived together."
If your veiling - may Allah support you - has become long, your seclusion intense, and your doorman grim. How many a veiled one whose side I sought and whose door I intended, I found him a star distant from the seekers, and a snake that does not listen to charmers. When he deprived me of wealth, I deprived him of praise. When he prevented me the gift, I prevented him the praise. So we ended up together in deprivation; as for him, of generosity, and as for me, of blessing. He of thanks, and I of abundance. He has done good to me as he wished, since he did evil. Did he not free my shoulder from the slavery of the favor, and not oblige me to keep the trust? Farewell.

"Another on Untying the Saying of Di'bil"
"You promised the sandal then turned away from it... As if you desire insult and slander.
If you do not gift me a sandal, then be it... If you dotted a letter after the Nun."
You promised me - may Allah support you - the sandal and did not help, but turned away from mentioning it and shunned. So you became a target for the arrows of blame and became slandered. If you gift it now, otherwise you will wear the robe of the cheated, and be it if you dotted the letter after the Nun (Na'l -> Baghl/Mule?). The prudent is he who protects honor with the lowest offer, and does not expose it to tribulation. Farewell.

"Another on Untying the Saying of the Poet"
"I accompanied you for two years in the state of my estrangement... Hoping for your dew, and madness has arts.
So I did not obtain from you a gift other than that I... Learned how the humiliation of poverty is."

Oh my sorrow, if sorrow avails. Oh my grief, if grief is useful: For two years I exhausted in your company and spent in your service. I had from the distress of estrangement a companion and intimate, and from hope, wide of regions, a motive and ally. Deception is hidden, and madness has arts... So I did not enjoy a gift from you nor settle with a benefit, nor attain what enriches me like the feather of a bird. Rather, I learned how the humiliation of poverty is, and how the injustice of Time assaults. Complaint is to Allah not of Him. In Him, Exalted, is compensation for every goer and replacement for every missed thing. So praise be to Him for His favors, and His prayers be upon the Prophet Muhammad and his family.

"Another on Untying the Saying of the Professor Abu Bakr al-Khawarizmi"
"Lo, who will convey to the Professor that I... Am the sharp sword, shyness sheathed it.
I helped, and the salt lands with you are a pasture... And we thirst, and the mirage with you is water.
Time knocks on us, and every day... We have a calamity whose margins are weeping.
You had promised us a look, but it was slow... And slow horses may reach (eventually).
If fulfillment is difficult with you one day... Then demanding is present with us.
And a people other than me are satisfied with hope... And I have no satisfaction with their judgment.
For the brother of hope is on certainty... Of tribulation, and in the suggestion is doubt.
The worst of hopers is a brother of procrastination... Hope populates his sides.
If it is morning, his appointment is evening... And if it is evening, his appointment is forenoon.
This admonition is a mediator, but... It has two collars: praise or satire.
Between success and hindrance is a border... And a bridge called generosity.
So do not complain of destiny, for one who abuses... Himself does not complain; you are destiny.
Be gentle with the Prince, for everything... By which benefits are attained is alchemy.
May Allah prolong the ages of high ranks... And that is that survival prolongs for you.
And may a palm not cease to extend to you... Its merchandise is praise or supplication.
If Time is pleased with the like of my soul... As a ransom for you, then it is the ransom for you."
My heart - may Allah prolong the survival of our Master the Professor - is full of blame for him; blame abounds for it and the book narrows from it. But my tongue, even if it is a massive sword and a sharp blade, shyness has sheathed it due to the majesty of our Master and his nobility, and the reverence of what I imagine of the elevation of his rank and place. Oh my wonder, all wonder, at our drought in his neighborhood, and our thirst near his house! Salt lands with him are a fresh pasture, and drink with him is fresh water. Time attacks us with the sharpness of its nail and the meanness of its nail, raids us with its accidents and changes, and exposes us to misfortunes followed by misfortunes, and calamities in which we have speeches, whose margins are weeping that breaks the necklaces of tears, and complaining that speaks of the fire between the ribs. He - may Allah support him - had promised us of his good look at us what the thought of it was beautiful, and we waited for it long. It was slow, and horses may reach despite their slowness, and fold the stages with the shortness of their step. If fulfillment is difficult with him, demanding is present with us. If negligence lasts from him, demanding lasts from us. Other than me is he who is satisfied with hope and inclines in it to satisfaction, because the brother of hope is on certainty of tribulation and in doubt of relief and gift. The worst of the hoped-for is he whose procrastination increases and intensifies, and the life of hope in his presence lengthens and extends. If he enters morning, he makes the appointment evening, and if he goes in the evening, he makes it morning. It is known that admonition is a mediator having two ends: praise or satire that travel in the lands and reveal offense and benevolence. Between success and release, and suspension and hindrance, is a bridge whose water is medicine and whose wind is breeze, and its name is generosity. So let not our Master - may Allah perpetuate his support - complain of destiny, thus complaining of himself and deceiving his sense, because he is the Sultan, and he is destiny and time. What I ask is that he be gentle like the Prince - may Allah prolong his survival - so he shakes the side of his generosity and asks rain for me from the cloud of his blessings. For every water that calmed thirst is water, and everything by which benefits are attained is alchemy. I ask Allah to prolong the ages of high ranks by the length of his life and the height of his destiny and command. May his conditions not cease to be happy and envied, hopes attached to him, and palms spread with praise for him and prayer for him. And may his survival and meeting not cease to be a beauty for this world. If Time is pleased with my soul as a ransom for him, it is his ransom and loyalty.

"Another on Untying the Saying of the Poet to Abu Dulaf al-Qasim ibn Isa"
"Abu Dulaf, no seeker of need remained... Among people other than me, and the place is barren.
Does it please you that I returned from you disappointed... While no creature is seen disappointed from your dew?
And that I turned praise into blame... And a speaker stood with it among the worlds?
How, while you are the favoring benefactor who... For every stranger is a share of his dew?
If I attain what I hoped from you, then I... Am worthy, otherwise departure is near."
The good look of the Prince - may Allah prolong his survival - has encompassed all his petitioners, hopers, and visitors. I do not know anyone but that he reached a share of his gifts and struck with an arrow in his bounty, except me. For I see myself outside this general (inclusion), despite what I have of loyalty to him and service to him of the specific. I wish I knew, does it please the Prince - may Allah support him - that I prolong the rein of absence, then leave his presence with disappointment, while no one has been seen disappointed in his days or failed from his favors? Does he accept that my praise turns into disparagement, my eulogy into slander, and my thanks into complaint, undertaken by speakers extending the reins of address and prolonging the span of verbosity? No, by Allah! How, when he is the favoring benefactor, saddled in benevolence and bridled, who has for every one of his hopers the fullest share of his spacious protection and fertile place? If he observes my condition with the eye of care, and remedies the illness of my hopes with the medicine of favor, then I am worthy from him of a favor that weights my back and engrosses my thanks. Otherwise, I am of those who travel and do not rest, nor give rest, nor does the wind attach to them. God Almighty willing.

"Another on Untying the Saying of the Other"
"Suffice me and suffice you of procrastination and repetition... I wasted my life on promised delay.
A distant procrastination and an attainment I do not reach... And a contract of promise with an action not knotted.
So execute your resolve regarding us if you want for us... Good, for my resolve is executing, not returned.
Today is the last day of my returning... And today I cut my hopes with my emphasis.
Do not think me like one whose ways narrowed... My Lord is Kind and my provision is not blocked."
By Allah, I have become weary of delay and repetition, and did not obtain from the abundance of appointments except the near procrastination and the distant attainment. So if you execute your resolve in giving, otherwise I executed my resolve on departure. This, my master, is the first day of viewing and the last day of returning. Do not think me of those upon whom the ways narrowed and mounts lacked. Allah Almighty is Kind, His making with me is encompassing, His provision for me is returned (to me), and His door before me is not blocked. Farewell.

"Another on Untying the Saying of the Other"
"A people whose promises are embellished... Embellished by speech and lies.
The hoper of their gift always needs... Three things without testing:
Treasures of Qarun to be his... And the life of Noah and the patience of Job."
I complain to Allah then to you, O my master - may Allah perpetuate your glory - of a people whose promises are embellished with sayings of lies, decorated with ornaments of falsehoods. If the hoper seeks them to seek aid, he does not do without three things in waiting for their bounty: The treasures of Qarun, the like of whom was not created in wealth. And the life of Noah, than whom there is none longer in ages. And the patience of Job, who is cited as a proverb in endurance. Allah is the Helper against the burning of waiting and the hardships of compulsion.

"Another on Untying the Saying of the Other"
