"I will claim that I was pleased while I was not pleased... And claim that I was treated kindly while I was shunned.
And claim that I returned in the best state... And I am not seeking a home out of necessity.
Because you have ability, so you do not care... Whether I was angry at your deeds or pleased.
I will go from you holding fast to despair... And be content with what provides me sustenance.
Either the turn of days until... They bring what I hope for, or I die.
Thus is Time, its state is buckets (turns)... It benefits riches and sometimes causes loss.
How many a rich man after poverty... And a winner returned having no place to spend the night.
If hope dies due to bad condition... Then indeed Allah is Living, does not die."

And how could it be otherwise, when you are the generous benefactor… from whose grace every stranger receives a share? If I attain what I hope from you, I am deserving; otherwise, departure is near. The noble attention of the emir—may God prolong his life—has encompassed all of his petitioners, those who hope in him, and his visitors. I know of none who has not received a portion of his gifts and drawn a share from his bounty—except me. I see myself excluded from this general generosity, despite my special loyalty and service. Oh, if only I knew—does the emir, may God strengthen him, find it easy to prolong the reign of absence, then send me away from his presence in disappointment? No one has ever been disappointed in his days, nor failed in receiving his kindness.

Would he be pleased if my praise became blame, my admiration turned reproach, and my gratitude a complaint recited by speakers who extend their sermons and lengthen their phrases? By God, no. He is the generous benefactor, blazing in kindness, bridled in grace. Every one of his hopeful petitioners receives a great share from his wide protection and fertile station. If he looks upon my condition with care and remedies the illness of my hopes with his favor, then I am worthy of a gift that bends my back and consumes my thanks. Otherwise, I am among those who journey without rest, who neither find comfort nor give it, and whom the wind does not cling to—God willing.

"Another Letter Explaining the Saying of Another":

"Enough for you and me of delay and repetition… I have wasted my life on postponed promises. A distant delay and a gift I cannot reach… a knot of pledges tied to deeds unfulfilled. So carry out your resolve for us, if you wish us well… for my resolve is firm, unresisted. Today is the last day of my petitions… and today I cut off my hopes with certainty. Do not think me one whose paths have tightened… my Lord is gentle, and my provision is not blocked."

By God, I am weary of postponement and repetition. From the many promises I have gained nothing but near delays and distant gifts. If you enact your resolve in granting, well—otherwise I enact my resolve in departing. This, my lord, is the first day of confrontation and the last day of review. Do not think me one cornered with no paths or lacking mounts. God is gentle, His care surrounds me, His provision is not withheld, and His door before me is never shut. Peace.

"Another Letter Explaining the Saying of Another":

"A people whose promises are adorned… adorning speech and lies. Whoever hopes for their gifts always needs… three things without experiment: the treasures of Qārūn, if he possessed them; the lifespan of Noah; and the patience of Job."

I complain to God, then to you, my lord—may God preserve your honor—of a people whose promises are adorned with the embellishments of falsehood and painted with the colors of deception. When a seeker comes to them for aid, he cannot wait for their bounty without three things: the treasures of Qārūn, unmatched in wealth; the lifespan of Noah, unmatched in length; and the patience of Job, unmatched in endurance. And God is the one sought for help against the burn of waiting and the anguish of need.

"Another Letter Explaining the Saying of Another":

"You claim I am pleased while I am not… claim I am loyal though I was wronged. Claim I return in good condition… while necessity keeps me awake. For you have commanded, and so you care not… whether I am angered by your deeds or pleased. I will depart from you, clinging to despair… content with what gives me sustenance. Either the fortune of days will bring what I hope… or I will die. Such is the way of time, its cycles alternating… granting wealth and at times stripping it away. Many a man was rich after poverty… and many a wealthy one became homeless. If hope dies from hardship… God is alive and never dies."

I - may Allah support my master - preserve the veil of beauty so I do not tear it, and protect the water of the face so I do not spill it. I show satisfaction while I am angry, and thank while my heart is full of complaint. I claim that my master interceded for me with Time, and extended to me the hand of kindness, while he shunned me a shunning that left my state dry. I claim that I returned with red camels carrying white blessings, while necessity made lawful for me what Allah forbade, and I do not own among the people the dinner of the night nor the lunch of the day. My master - may Allah support him - is lofty with the nose of power, riding the mount of pride, going in the path of glory, not caring whether I was angry or pleased, failed or succeeded. Since the wine of wealth intoxicated him, so he transgressed and oppressed and was undutiful and did not observe the right, I will depart from him, riding the back of despair from him. I will hold fast to stillness and silence, and contentment with sustenance. Either a successful hope or a comforting death. Likewise is Time, its states are buckets (turns), and its filling is hopes and terms. Sometimes it benefits, sometimes it causes loss. At times it gives, at times it loots. How many a man the udders of wealth flowed for, and the clouds of wish rained upon, after he was a hostage of weakness and poverty, and a victim of humiliation and misery. How many an owner of wealth like dunes of sand has ended up in the most apparent straits, and revealed the ugliest poverty. If hope dies due to his bad condition, indeed Allah is Living, does not die. If what I hoped for is missed, Allah's making is not missed. Allah is sufficient for me alone, and He is the best Disposer of affairs.

"Another on Untying the Saying of Abu Tammam regarding Abbas ibn Lahi'ah"
"Fire, shame, hateful things, and destruction... Shackles, crucifixion, pliable spear, and wood.
Are sweeter and more delicious than a gift you bestow... And you will not bestow it, O dog, O dog!
You made me complain, so when I complained of you... You got angry; may that discontent and anger last.
O most of people in promise whose stuffing is breach... And most of people in speech all of which is lying.
You remained plundering the world and its decoration... And your honor remained an honor of evil being plundered."
Evil and harm. Nakedness and mange. Shame and defect. Disgrace and Fire. Affliction and hardship, imprisonment and misery. Bad luck and calamity, and incurable disease. The strike of injustice upon the burning of separation, and the slap of humiliation upon the distress of estrangement, are more desirable and sweeter than a gift your hands bestow. And suffice you what I said, and enough. O dog of defects and ugliness, and O pig of disgraces and scandals. You made me complain, made me cry, harmed me, and humiliated me. When I complained, you were disturbed and ignited, and became sharp and heated. May your burning in the fire of anger and rage last, and your twisting on the bed of wrath and fury. O most of people in breach - and breach of promise is the character of the scoundrel - and most of them in speech in whose shoulders falsehood walks, and in whose doctrines lying hesitates. It suffices the liar that he says it as an insult while his heart is an adversary. You remained plundering the world and robbing, and attaining from it what you seek, while your honor is a target for plundering, and an example for cursing. May Allah not remove other than you, nor curse other than you. Farewell.

"Another on Untying the Saying of Al-Mas'ar to Abdullah ibn Tahir"
"What do you say - may my soul be your ransom - regarding a man... Who rode determination in the bridle of patience?
He rises from the world over its rugged terrain... And settles from it in the place of travel.
Finding pleasure at the door, his stay was long... So the leaf of the palace door wept for him."
What is the saying of our Master the Prince - may Allah prolong his survival - regarding a man who rode to him the mount of determination bridled with firmness, saddled with decisive patience? He endured the horrors of travels, and penetrated the difficulties of rugged and rough paths, until he arrived at a watering place of your courtyard, and threw his staff at your door. He stuck to it finding pleasure, and went early and late to it repeatedly until his stay was long. His disease became incurable, and his cure became mighty and scarce. The virtuous people of the age pitied him, and the leaf of the palace almost wept for him. Is there with the Prince - may Allah support him - a look for him that holds his last breath which defect permeated, and steadies his foot which slipping possessed? For his opinion in that has its virtue which he is worthy of. God Almighty willing.

"Untying the Answer to him by Abdullah ibn Tahir"
"I did not forget your share, so seek help with patience... And open with my busyness from you the door of excuse.
Do not despair if matters become difficult... For ease is expected during hardship."
You - may Allah strengthen you - know that Sultanic occupations may hinder brotherly rights. We do not forget the right of your service, nor what was paved and confirmed of your bond. So increase in patience, do not narrow in chest, and open for us the door of excuse until the door of thanks opens for you. Do not despair of two eases with the hardship. God Almighty willing.

"Another on Untying the Saying of Al-Buhturi"
"A cloud whose generosity missed me while it was pouring... And a sea whose flood passed me while it was bestowing.
And a full moon that lit the earth east and west... While the place of my foot from it is black, dark.

Do I complain of his dew after it encompassed mankind... And who dispraises the rain except a dispraised one?
Fath ibn Khaqan did not prevent his gift... But it is Destinies that give and deprive."
Our Master the Prince - may Allah prolong his survival - is a cloud all of which is rain, and its habit is aid. But it did not revive my land with a rain, nor wet my uvula with a drop. He - may Allah strengthen his victory - is a brimming sea, its flood is blessings. But I am thirsty in his neighborhood, deprived of his good traces. Just as he is a full moon that filled eyes with delight and filled the lands with brightness, yet the place of my look is empty of his light. By my life, it is unchangeable. Oh my wonder at thirst in the neighborhood of the swelling sea, and at darkness in facing the shining full moon. How "?" the generality of creation thanked him, and how do I dispraise one whom the tongue of Time praised? Who dispraises rain except a dispraised one, and who blames the sun except a blamed one? The Prince did not single me out for deprivation, for he has encompassed people with kindness. But Destinies give and deprive, and undo and establish. There is no despair of Allah's mercy, and no harm with Allah's grace. Farewell.

"Another on the Saying of the Poet"
"The thirsty seekers came so they returned... Quenched, and the watering place was pleasant for them with you.
I came to your sea, swelling, overflowing... So I returned my bucket as a dry skin rattling.
I see you raining on a side over a side... While the sky of my house from your tolerance is a barren land."
I see the seekers - may Allah support our Master the Prince - intending his spacious courtyard and arriving at his sweet watering place. The watering place accommodates them with him, and the drinking place is pleasant for them. They return from him having quenched and watered, and narrated of his noble deeds what they saw. I arrived at his intended courtyard and his frequented sea. When I extended my glance to the fresh water and threw my bucket among the buckets, he returned the bucket dry, rattling, and dropped me into what I did not expect. I see him raining on sides, aiding relatives and strangers. My land is devoid of his rain, and my hand is empty of his white and yellow (silver and gold). Conditions may corrupt then improve, and the generous may be stingy then generous. With today is tomorrow, and with Saturday is Sunday. Farewell.

"Another on Untying the Saying of the Other"
"Abu Hasan, what excuse do I and you have... In your sleeping regarding my affair and my thanks for the length of my life?
Do you accept that I be satisfied, while you are my means... With other than satisfaction from the people of my time and from my time?
I made you a sea for me and your palm a deep... And the neighbor of the sea thirsts on the coast of the sea!"
I wish I knew what your excuse is, O my master, in your sleeping regarding my affair and your abstinence in attracting my thanks. Why did you accept other than satisfaction in aiding me against my time, while you are my means from mankind and my intercessor to wealth? Among the wonders is that you are a full sea, and I am thirsty on your coast. Allah is the Helper.

"Another on Untying the Saying of the Other"
"The forelocks of noble deeds are in your grasp... And these people are the sons of your blessing.
Those branches of highness belong... If they belong, to your root.
So why was I left without a pasture... While this creation grazes in your blessing?"
Our Master - may Allah prolong his survival - has reached the furthest of high ranks and possessed the forelocks of noble deeds. Beauties are from the traces of his days, and people are the sons of his bounty. Branches of glory branch out from his lofty tree, and the tongue of Time preaches his consistent virtues. May Allah perpetuate for him the most abundant portion, just as He poured out by him the best blessings. To proceed: Why do I not take a share of his fertile courtyard, while people graze in the gardens of his blessing, and have what they wish of the fruits of his state? My rights require that I be with him in the group of those successful in their aims, winners of their demands; not that the world turns away from me while it is led by his command, and time disguises itself to me while it is in his hand. This is a flash of complaint, running the course of a reminder. It benefits the believers and is tolerated from the sincere. Behind it is what turns it into thanks and returns aversion into kindness. God willing.

"Another on Untying the Saying of the Other"
"If there is in you (plural/fem) neither shade nor fruit... Then may Allah distance you of trees."
And the saying of another:
"If you have no world with you to benefit us... Nor are you possessor of religion so we hope for you for religion.
And you were a friend not hoped for a gift... We made a friend in your likeness from clay."
And the saying of Mansur al-Faqih:
"If you were stingy with my kindness... And I did not attain a support from you.
And you are a slave like me... So why do I worship a slave?"
If the tree did not clothe me with its shade nor give me its fruit, may Allah empower a cutter over its root and destine a woodcutter for its branch. If you are not hoped for benefit, nor benefitted from in matters of religion and the world, then you are nothing but a spirit in impossibility, nay a statue of clay. If I did not attain from you status and support, then you are a slave like me and I do not worship the slave. Farewell.

"Another on Untying the Saying of the Poet"

"If you are not hoped for repelling a mishap... And there was no greed for needs with you.
Nor are you a possessor of status by whose status one lives... Nor are you on the Day of Gathering among those who intercede.
Then your life in the world and your death are one... And the wood of a toothpick is more beneficial than your union."
If I do not hope for you to repel mishaps, suffice important matters, and fulfill needs; and you did not have status enabling me to show what I intend and triumph over whom I oppose; and you were not chaste of wrapper, pure of burdens, clear of courtyard from sins, innocent of palm from crimes, so that drawing near to you and quoting from what you have leads to preparing provision for the Day of Return; then your death and your life are equal. May Allah not distance other than you. No trait of your traits is praised, and the wood of a toothpick is more beneficial than your union. Peace be upon other than you.

Chapter
Thanksgiving

"A Letter as if from the tongue of some servants of the Majestic Presence - may Allah guard it - to the High Assembly - may Allah comfort it - on Untying the Saying of the Poet"
"If thanks had a person that appears... When the onlooker contemplates it.
I would have depicted it for you so you see it... And know that I am a thankful man.
But it is dwelling in the conscience... Moved by the circulating speech."
My thanks to the High Assembly of our Master the King, the Lord, the Supported, the Patron of Blessings, Khwarazm Shah - may Allah prolong his survival, perpetuate his highness, and grant victory to his banner - for his blessings which drowned me and enslaved me, and filled my hand and my heart, is the thanks of the garden for the rain and the night-traveler for the moon. Rather, the thanks of the thirsty arriving for the cold fresh water. Rather, the thanks of the captive for his liberator and the slave for his emancipator. If thanks had a person the sight perceives and the look obtains, I would have depicted it and perfected its depiction, just as I established it and perfected its establishment, so that our Master - may Allah strengthen his victory - sees it with his high eye as he heard it with his conscious ear. So he knows that I am thankful for his favors connected like the connection of fortunes, remembering his kindnesses organized like the organization of necklaces. Even if thanks dwelt in the depth of my soul and the core of my heart, what circulates of my speech as proverbs and travels in the horizons as imagination has moved it. Upon Allah I seek help to rise to the obligatory of thanking the blessing and exerting capacity in service. He is the best Helper and strongest Supporter.

"Another on Untying the Saying of the Poet"
"Do not deny the blessing to the possessor of blessings... He does not thank Allah who does not thank people."
And the saying of another:
"I thanked you, for thanks to Allah is obedience... And whoever thanks for the favor, Allah increases him.
For every time there is one who is followed... And this is a time you are undoubtedly its unique one."
And the saying of another:
"The Prince equaled our days with his generosity... So all of them for all of us are festivals.
As for our reality, we are his slaves... But in his kindness, we are children."
Thanks - may Allah support our Master the King, the Lord Khwarazm Shah - is obedience to Allah, a bond for the blessing, and a key for increase. I will surely thank the Benefactor, the Patron of Blessings - may Allah perpetuate his authority - the extent of my words, and I will surely praise him to the capacity of my pen. Whoever does not thank creation does not thank his Creator, and whoever does not praise his Provider. For every time there is one who is followed in noble deeds by his character, and guided in high ranks by his ways. Our Master - may Allah perpetuate his support - is the unique of his time, and the peerless among his peers. He has equaled between our days with his blessings and the traces of his generosity and kindness. All of them are a witnessed Friday and numbered festivals. We are in reality his slaves truly, and his property by bondage. But in his kindness to us, his compassion upon us, and his looking after us, we are the dearest children of the most generous father. May he never cease to be of glory between inherited and newly acquired. Among the wonders is that the father is fresh of youth, good of reception, and at a far extent from middle age, while among his children are those whom greyness has bridled with its bridle and led with its rein. Among them are those who passed youth by stages and arrived at the watering places of old age. Among them are those of high ages and companionship to the past days. So may Allah prolong the survival of our Master, victorious, lucky, and by the eye of His care noticed and protected, until he reaches the utmost age and the highest command, and possesses what the sun rose upon and the blowing of the wind ended at. Amen.

"Another on Untying the Saying of the Other"
"I will surely thank you for a favor you intended... Indeed, intention for favor is a favor.
And I do not blame you if destiny did not execute it... For the thing is diverted by the inevitable destiny."

I - may Allah support the Sheikh - know his beautiful intention regarding my successes, and his belief knotted with my interests. I thank him for what he intended of my well-known affair, and what he resolved of reaching me with kindness and favor. I do not blame him if destiny did not aid him in reaching what he sought, and judgment did not help him in executing what he wanted. Most judgments and destinies run contrary to preference and estimation. Things are by inevitable destiny estimated and facilitated, or hindered and delayed. Farewell.

"Another on Untying the Saying of the Other"
"I pledged my hand to inability to thank his kindness... And there is no increase above my thanks to the thankful.
If it were something possible, I would have done it... But what is not possible is severe."
I - may Allah support our Master - am a hostage of inability to thank him and falling short of spreading his kindness. Although my thanks has no increase for an increaser, nor beyond it a limit for an exaggerator. The incapable, if he admits, is a winner. If thanking him were something possible, I would have done it, and broadcast it in gatherings and spread it. But what is not possible is excused, and the excuse in that is conceivable. God willing.

"Verse"
"I speak of some of what you bestowed upon me... And you gave me request before requests.
If I were able, everyone above the dust... Would have stood on my behalf thanking you."
I - may Allah support him - thank some of what his kindness and virtue encompassed me with, since there is no hope in reaching the obligatory of thanking all of it, and publishing what he entitled me to of the gift before asking and requesting. If I were able, everyone above the dust would have thanked him on my behalf for his favors which are more than the number of dust (particles). But I ask Allah, Exalted is His Name, to undertake his reward on my behalf, and help his deed and intention in good, and to keep him for the beautiful to populate its paths, and the good to bear its results, by His mercy and the breadth of His grace.

"Another on Untying the Saying of the Other"
"And when your kindness was above my thanks... And thanks was of the right of fulfillment.
And that Allah has given you a kingdom... Clear to the enemy and the friend.
I desired of Him to reward you on my behalf... Just as the poor desired of the Rich.
And it secured me from shortcoming that I... Referred you in reward to the Capable."
Our Master the King, the Lord, the Patron of Blessings, Khwarazm Shah - may Allah prolong his survival - has prolonged the rein of favoring in my affair, poured upon me the cloud of preference, and extended to me the hand of bounty, until I took over the furthest desire. When his kindness was above my thanks, and the amount of his fragrance greater than my ability, and his place in kingship and authority greater than for the like of me to thank him, I turned from thanks and praise to knocking on the door of heaven with supplication. I desired of Allah, Great is His Majesty and Holy are His Names - the desire of the incapable of the Capable, the weak of the Strong, and the poor of the Rich - that He undertakes rewarding him on my behalf with the best of what He rewarded a benefactor for a thankful one, and a doer of good for a publisher. It secured me from falling short and negligence, and hanging onto the tails of excuses, that I referred him to the Capable of reward, the Able to recompense. He is the One asked, Exalted, to spread the hand with highness, couple the grandfather (luck) with happiness, and make his two days his tomorrow.

"Another on Untying the Saying of Mahmud al-Warraq"
"If a glorious one dispensed with thanks... Due to pride of soul or highness of place.
Allah would not have ordered servants to thank Him... So He said: Thank Me, O two heavy ones (Jinn and Mankind)."
Thanks - may Allah support you - is loved, desired, and sought. If a glorious one were above it due to the highness of his status, or a king due to the elevation of his authority, Allah would not have ordered His servants to thank Him and talk of His blessing and kindness.

"A Letter on Untying the Saying of the Other"
"Convey to our brother - may Allah take charge of his company - that I... Even if I do not meet him, I meet him.
And that my heart is connected to seeing him... Even if his dwelling is far from my dwelling.
No blessing arrived at me nor a hadith... Except that Allah favored me with it from him.
Nor a beautiful trial that dragged good to me... Except by it I attained his first and his last.
The sea runs out and his gifts do not run out... And the rain is counted and his gifts are not counted.
Allah knows that I do not mention him... And how does he mention who does not forget him?
May Allah show me what my heart attempts... And guard him, take charge of him, and keep him."

Who conveys from me to the brother, the benefactor, the preferrer, the doer of good, the beautiful? May Allah take charge of his company, return his absence, and hasten his return safe. Indeed, I meet him in distance, observe him with the eye of the heart, and represent him in my mind until he is like my present companion. How can I not spread the sides of my chest for his love, and not hold onto his loyalty with my hand and fingernail? Whatever blessing is in me is from Allah then from him, or Allah caused it for me at his hand. I do not see around me a beautiful abundant grant, and a massive great favor, except that I attained it from the year of his bounty and the next, and the drizzle of his kindness and its downpour. He is in his generosity nothing but the overflowing sea and the abundant rain. However, the sea, its water gets cut off, while his giving is not cut off. And the rain is counted, while his favors are not counted. Allah knows that I see him in the mirror of thought. I do not mention because I do not forget. The majority of states is desire to Allah that He guards him and takes charge of him. God willing.

"Another on Untying the Saying of Ibn al-Mu'tazz"
"Abu Hasan, my tread was firm in safety... And tremors overtook me in dilemmas.
You dressed me in a shield upon a prudent (mind)... So I called out to the vicissitudes of Time: Is there a challenger?"
The Sheikh - may Allah perpetuate his support - has made my foot firm in safety when panic slipped with it, and grew my feathers when Time had clipped them. He overtook me in the tremors of dilemmas until he rescued me from the fangs of calamities. He dressed me in a shield of ample tails, prudent of width and length, and a weapon whose appearance pleases and whose substance frightens, whose singing is good and whose trace is ugly. He girded me with a sword whose like is rare and scarce. So I called out to the vicissitudes of Time: Who is the one who emerges? I will surely thank him like the breaths of gardens at dawns after rains. And I will surely desire to Allah Almighty that He prolongs his survival and improves his reward on my behalf.

"Another on Untying his Saying also"
"To the family of Sulayman ibn Wahb are favors... Upon me, and kindness to me that preceded.
They taught the days how to treat me kindly... And they washed the blood from my father's robe."
The family of Sulayman have successive favors upon me like the succession of rain on the desolate land, and consecutive blessings like the succession of wealth to the poor. Preceding and following favors, and coming and awaited hands. They are the ones who shortened the road to obtaining my wish, and comforted me while I was like a stranger in my homeland. They taught the days how to treat me kindly, and how to heal me and please me. They are the ones who cleared my watering places of turbidity, and washed the blood from my father's robe, until I attained through them the sleep-inducing revenge, and shook hands with victory and bliss. May Allah reward them on my behalf with the best of what He rewarded an initiator of kindness and a reviver of a human.

"Another on Untying the Saying of Abu Tammam"
"You sufficed me the sufficiency of water in choking... And you were the originator of the downpour of the abundant cloud.
You renewed for me a hope whose wonders were... Secluded before it in the demand of a character.
If the nature of Abu Ya'qub were in a stone... Solid, it would overflow with water bursting in it.
There is no beautiful thing of the world nor good... Except that most of it is in that character.
O favor of yours, were it not for what I lighten it... With of thanks, it would not be borne nor tolerated.
By Allah, lift from me the weight of its burden... For I fear from it for my neck."
The trace of the virtue of our Master the King, the Patron of Blessings, Khwarazm Shah - may Allah prolong his survival - with me is like the trace of water with choking. The location of his bounty with me is like the location of guidance with the confused. Long has he created for me with his known generosity and described kindness a cloud of dewy shade, pleasant downpour and drizzle. My garden laughs from its weeping, and my land turns green from its blackness. Until he renewed for me of my hope what wore out, and verified for me of my thought what failed. I say: If his character were in a solid stone, it would overflow with extending water. Or in thorns, they would wear the robe of roses. He is nothing but a person entirely glory and generosity. There is no beauty in the world except it exists in his character. How many a majestic blessing and heavy favor of his, I lighten with thanks but it becomes heavy, and I overcome with spreading but it overcomes and kills. By Allah, lift its weight, for I feared from it for my back that it splits and cuts, and for my neck that it breaks and dislocates. Allah is the Helper on thanks that runs the course of the breeze for his blessings, and indicates my place among his slaves and servants. He is the Asked to perpetuate the state of the world by his survival, and combine highness for his hand and banner behind him. Amen, O Allah, Amen.

"Another on Untying the Saying of Ali ibn Hilla"
"May I be your ransom, I did not abandon you out of ingratitude for a blessing... And is obtaining increase hoped for by ingratitude?
But when I came to you visiting... You exceeded in kindness to me, so I was unable to thank.
From now on I do not come to you except excusing... I greet in two months a day, and in the month.
If you increase me in kindness, I increase in aversion... So we do not meet throughout life until the Gathering."

I do not abandon my master - may Allah support him - out of ingratitude for his blessing which burdened my back and filled my chest. Is increase of kindness hoped for by ingratitude? But whenever I mounted the vehicle of longing to his countenance, and the mouth of hope smiled at me in visiting him, he poured upon me from the clouds of his kindness what disables me from reaching his thanks. So I wear the mask of shyness and blame, and go with the shame of the frequency of what luxury is by. I tread the path of excusing, and knock on the door of falling short. Here I am, having sat from his service with a heart standing towards his presence, and delayed from him with an intention preceding in his loyalty and support. I restricted myself to greeting once every month, and perhaps I did not visit in two months except a visit. If he increases me in favors, I increase in breach. If he runs on his habit in kindness, I continue on my opinion in abandonment. So we do not meet until the Gathering. Farewell.

Chapter
Apology and Seeking Favor

"A Letter on Untying the Saying of Al-Hasan ibn Wahb to Al-Mutawakkil while he and his brother Sulayman were in his prison"
"I say while the night, its pavilion is extended... And a third of it has passed or it has reached the middle.
O Lord, inspire the Commander of the Faithful to satisfaction... With two servants of his who have neared destruction.
If they have done evil in what passed... They will not do evil, praise be to Allah, in the future."
The anger of our Master - may Allah perpetuate his support - is the anger of the soul against the body, and the cutting of the liver by the hand of grief. There has shaded me from that what showed me the light of the world as darkness, and depicted the light of the sun in my eye as gloom. How many a night whose pavilion is extended and the door of its morning is closed, I revived with supplication while it kills me with weeping. When its chest passed and its half ended, I said, having worn the robe of the humble and fulfilled the conditions of the submissive, forgetting the pledge of sleep while I am in prostration: O Knower of the unseen, O Coverer of defects, O Forgiver of sins, O Turner of hearts. Bless Muhammad, the best of those with whose mention supplications are opened, and by blessings upon whom requests succeed. Inspire Your Caliph in Your earth and Your trustee over Your creation, satisfaction with two poor servants of his, submissive to confession of their sins. The vicissitudes of days have duelled to prey on them, and their fangs hastened to seize them. They are on a brink and exposure to destruction. Even if each of them sinned and deserved punishment, he has repented, apologized, and turned back. Apology necessitates forgiveness, and repentance demolishes the sin. If he did evil in what passed of his time, he will not return to evil in what remains of his life. God willing.

"Another on Untying the Saying of Abu Qabus the Christian in softening the heart of Al-Rashid towards Al-Fadl ibn Yahya al-Barmaki"
"Trustee of Allah, grant Fadl ibn Yahya... To your generosity, O Gallant King.
Trustee of Allah, suffice you that Fadl... Is your suckling brother, and the suckling brother has a covenant."
O Trustee of Allah over His creation and His shadow in His earth. O King whom angels serve and spheres aid. Grant Al-Fadl ibn Yahya to Allah, then to your virtue, the honor of your origin, and the height of your place. For he is your suckling brother, and the right of suckling is not wasted. And your servant, and service has a sanctity. Your vizier, and the vizierate has a covenant. Do not narrow, O Commander of the Faithful, with the breadth of your clemency from him, nor muddy the purity of your pardon for him. For the pardon of kings is more lasting for the kingdom. And whoever pardons and reforms, his reward is upon Allah.

"Another on Untying the Saying of the Poet"
"If you pardon your sinning servant, then in... Your pardon is a shelter for virtue and favors.
I committed what I deserve of error... So be generous with what you deserve of beauty."
And the saying of Abdullah ibn Abdullah ibn Tahir:
"So consider me sinning as you said, unjust... Then a beautiful pardon so that the virtue is yours.
For if I am not worthy of pardon from you due to the evil of what... I came with, then you are worthy of it."
And the saying of another:
"Forgive my slip to secure the virtue of thanks... From me, and let not my reward miss you.
Do not leave me to seek means by excuse... For perhaps I may not stand with my excuse."
The small slip, and the great pardon. In the pardon of our Master - may Allah perpetuate his support - for his servant is a shelter for the virtue which is from him. I have come with what I deserve of error and evil, so let him come with what he merits of hoped-for pardon. Let him consider me sinning as he said; then why did he not forgive? And why did he not do good and beautiful, and pardon and favor, so that he has the mentioned virtue and the thanked pardon? If I am not worthy of the beautiful with the evil of what I came with and the ugliness of what I committed, he is worthy of it with his brilliant generosity and widespread glory. It is incumbent upon him to forgive my slip, raise me from my stumble, combine in pardoning me thanks and reward, and not leave me to seek means by excuse. For perhaps I will not perform it at the time of need and in the position of argument. Farewell.

"Another on Untying the Saying of the Other"

"Suppose I did evil as you claimed... Then where is the affection of brotherhood?
And if I did evil as I did evil... Then where is your virtue and chivalry?"
Suppose, O my master - may Allah prolong your survival - I slipped; and the scholar whom I do not rival may slip. And I stumbled; and the generous horse whom I do not race may stumble. And I did evil; and the doer of good whom I do not equal may do evil. Where is the affection of brotherhood whose covenant is not rejected, and the sanctity of friendship whose bond is not diminished? If you repaid me for the evil, where is your virtue upon which the sphere of glory revolves, and where is your chivalry to which the hand of highness points? Here I have fled from you to you, and sought help by your pardon against you. So make me taste the sweetness of your satisfaction and favor, just as you made me taste the bitterness of your anger and revenge. Know, without being taught, that my sin, even if great, your pardon is greater than it. I do not have, praise be to Allah, a sin that your forgiveness is too narrow for. The noble is he who, if he is able, forgives; if he possesses, is gentle; if he captures, frees; and if he binds, releases. Farewell.

"Another on Untying the Saying of Ibn al-Mu'tazz"
"O my master, I have stumbled, take my hand... And do not leave me nor say 'Perish'.
And pardon, if I return, then pardon a second time... For the doctor treats the one who relapsed."
I complain to my master - may Allah perpetuate his glory - of the stumble of my foot and the abundance of my regret. I ask him to take my hand and not say to me 'Perish', but revive me and dress me in the robe of his pardon for me. If I return to the sin, let him return to the pardon. If I return to turbidity, let him return to clarity. Allah may pardon the repetition of evil which the soul commands, and the doctor treats the one who relapses after his recovery. Farewell.

"Another on Untying the Saying of Abu Nuwas"
"Months have passed for me since I was imprisoned, three... As if I had sinned what is not forgiven.
If I did not sin, then why is my imprisonment... And if I was a possessor of sin, then your pardon is greater."
I have been immersed - may Allah prolong our Master's survival - for three months in the bottom of a prison whose effect on the soul is bad, and which blocks the light of the sun from me. As if my sin is the grave sin with which beautiful forgiveness is ugly. Our Master - may Allah perpetuate his support - obliges pardon at the slip, just as he commits to giving at the request. If I am innocent, then the truth accommodates me and justice includes me. If I am a sinner, then the pardon of our Master - may Allah perpetuate his power - is greater than my sin, and his noble sympathy overtakes me. God Almighty willing.

Chapter
Acceptance of Excuse

"Section on Untying the Saying of the Poet"
"Accept the excuses of one who comes to you apologizing... Whether he was truthful with you in what he said or lied.
For he who pleases you outwardly has obeyed you... And he who disobeys you hiddenly has respected you."
Confession removes the commission (of sin). Apology necessitates forgiveness, whether the excuse was a lie or truth, false or true. He who hid has feared you, and he who apologized to you did not sin against you. The noble is he who makes trust in his friend prevail over doubt in his verification.

"Another on Untying the Saying of Ibn al-Mu'tazz"
"It was said to me: So-and-so did evil to you... And the staying of a youth upon injustice is a shame.
I said: He came to us and created an excuse... The blood money of the sin with us is apology."
Some of those who eat food with me and suckle wine with me said to me in these days: My pledge with so-and-so is doing evil to you, committing crimes against you. I see him now accompanying you and not separating from you, intermingling with you and not leaving you. Requital is obligatory in nature and permissible in Sharia. It is a shame for a youth to overlook the mote (in the eye) and stay upon injustice and harm. I said: Did you not know that he came to me apologizing to me, shedding tears of seeking favor before me, and acting with gentle speech and elegant excuse in what, if Time came with its like, it would pardon its vicissitudes and secure the feared from its danger? Apology, even if little, is the blood money of the sin, even if great.

Chapter
Complaint

"Section on Untying the Saying of Abu al-Fath Kushajim"
"I used to fight the doubt of Time... In days when his eyes were sleeping.
When he woke up, I made peace with him... And whoever fears his assault makes peace with him.
I used to covet his moon... So I became content with the hilt (or remaining part)."
I used to fight the doubt of Time, assault it with sword and spear, and extract justice from it with the utmost possibility, in days when his eye was sleeping, his fire was extinguished, and his wind was stagnant. When he woke up and growled at me and became lion-like, and gathered to oppose me and crowded, and prepared to reveal enmity to me and sought help, I inclined to peace seeking safety. I became content from the moon with the hilt, and satisfied from the spoil with safety in return. Allah is the Granter of success to the right.

"Another on Untying the Saying of Abu Hiffan"
"O this woman, how much will the blame and criticism be... Do not blame a man whose clothes are shreds.
If I enter evening alone, then the sea is alone... And the full moon is alone and the sword is alone.

If the vicissitude of a time faulted his appearance... Then between his two rags is a crushing lion."
You knew what passed between me and a blaming woman who saw me alone, not keeping company with anyone, wearing rags that had thinned, and recited "When the sky splits open". So she blamed me for isolation from loved ones and wearing worn-out clothes. I said to her: As for isolation, I have a model in it in the swelling sea, the shining full moon, and the sharp sword. As for rags, a man is not known by his cloak, just as a sword is not known by its sheath. Even if the vicissitude of Time robbed me of wealth so I wore rags, between them is a crushing lion from me, and he will have a victorious luck. With today is tomorrow, and with hardship is ease. God Almighty willing.

"Another on Untying the Saying of Di'bil"
"I went and I do not know where I go... And which matters in determination I ride.
If my two palms touched an organized necklace... Of pearls, it became perforated shells.
If my palm grasped a palm of a dirham... A scorpion would return to my leg while in the palm."
I have no expression suitable to describe what I am in of confusion in my ways, difficulty in my demands, and the craft that showed me the door of good blocked and the face of hope blackened. If I touched a pearl, it would become a brick. If I took a gold nugget, it would become a dung pellet. If I took a dirham that benefits, it would turn into a scorpion that stings. There is no complaint of Allah but to Him, and my reliance is only on Him.

"Another on Untying the Saying of the Other"
"Time was unjust to us in its disposal... And which time did not run against the free?
I have from Time what if its ease... Were thrown on the rotating sphere, it would not rotate."
I complain to you of a time sharp of nail, mean of victory, unjust of march, loose of the reins of change. It has encompassed the free with its famous injustice, and assaulted them with its drawn sword. It humiliated them and removed them, and shifted their conditions from grace and bliss. It singled me out from the bitterness of its fruit and the badness of its effect with what, if thrown on the spheres, they would not rotate, or on the stars, they would not move, or on the mountains, they would sway, or on the seas, they would sink. Allah is the Helper against the harshness of Time.

"A Letter on Untying the Saying of the Poet"
"I see the time of griefs stopped upon me... So why do I not see the time of joys?
My days increase Time in length... So oh my sorrow for a short time."
And the saying of another:
"I wish I knew, will I spend a night... As the overnight of one happy of gift, pleased with Time?
And do I have from the days a day bringing glad tidings... Of bestowing a favor or rewarding a possessor of favors?"
And the saying of another:
"He for whom the world was a wealth... We are of the spectators of the world.
We glance at it from near with regret... As if we are a word without meaning."
Why, my master - may Allah prolong your survival - do I see the time of worries eating my flesh and griefs drinking my blood, and not see the time of joys for which my side shakes, and happiness with which my wit rises? Why do I see days longer than the nights of lovers when they are shot with the arrows of separation? Oh my sorrow for a time whose darknesses are lights and whose long times are short. I wish I knew, will I spend a night as one sleeps whose luck is happy, whose fire stick ignited, whose command rose, and whose time pleased him? Do I have a day in which I am able to bestow a blessing, or repel a vengeance, or reward a possessor of a favor, or treat a brother of ordeal? As for now, in this world described with freshness, I am among the spectators. I glance at it right and left, and see nothing but worry and regret. I see nothing but one of eclipsed mind, suffering, as if I am a word without meaning. What makes you know? Perhaps relief is near, and Allah allots me a share of good.

"Another on Untying the Saying of Al-Buhturi"
"Whoever praises or dispraises his time... This one, I am not praising Time.
Poverty like the poverty of Prophets, estrangement... And ardent love; the affliction is not one."
And the saying of Al-Khalil, also narrated for Al-Hamdawi:
"I did not increase in my literature a letter I rejoice with... Except I increased a letter under which is bad luck.
Indeed the one advanced in skill in his craft... Wherever he turns from it, he is deprived."

I, my master - may Allah support you - am praising Allah in all states, but not praising treacherous Time. For it was not content for me with single ordeals until it made them pairs, and poured upon me waves from the whip of torment. It afflicted me with poverty like the poverty of Prophets, estrangement exposing me to hardships, and ardent love exposing me to tribulation. The matter is that I do not increase a letter of literature except I increase a letter (of bad luck). Nor do I memorize a line except I wear poverty. Nor do I master a known (fact) except I know bad luck. Likewise, the one advanced in skill in his craft, pointed to for the virtue of his brilliance, wherever he turns he is deprived, and however he excels he is dispraised. The prudent is he who affirms what pleases him in Allah's grace and blessing, and refers what grieves him to Allah's power and wisdom. I hope to be that with Allah's help and will.

"Another on Untying the Saying of the Professor Abu Bakr al-Khawarizmi"
"I have a thin shirt... Which illusions tear.
And a Jubbah (cloak) not equal to... Its misspelling (Jannah/Paradise or Hayyah/Snake?), and farewell."
The generosity of my master - may Allah perpetuate his glory - does not approve for me in this frowning, calamitous winter, and the cold baring to me the fang of severe cold (Zamharir), that I go and come in worn-out clothes like thin air and shimmering mirage. The shirt, nothing remains of it but the name, and illusion tears it. The Jubbah, wear has become its ally and intimate; it does not equal its misspelling. The turban, if the breeze of air blows on it, almost gets organized in the thread of dust particles. If you clothe me in a robe that is beautiful in the eyes, I will clothe you in a robe that is beautiful in ears and hearts. God willing.

Chapter
On Expecting Relief

"A Letter on Untying the Saying of the Poet"
"Do not panic even if you become insolvent one day... For you have been solvent in the long time.
Do not despair, for despair is disbelief... Perhaps Allah enriches from a little.
Do not think of your Lord an evil thought... For Allah is more worthy of the beautiful.
I saw hardship followed by ease... And the saying of Allah is the truest of all sayings."
It reached me, my master - may Allah support you - that you panic from the choking of Time, and do not wear the garment of patience over hardship. As if the cycles did not turn upon you, night and day did not discipline you, and news and traces did not pass by your eye and ear. As if you do not return from patience to the best equipment, nor look into the book of relief after distress. Do you not know that if you were insolvent for a month, you were solvent for an epoch? If you practiced hardship for days, you wore blessing for years. Just as the period of joy did not last, the period of harm does not last. Just as the turn of the gift did not tarry, the turn of the ordeal does not tarry. Do not despair of the mercy of Allah, for despair is disbelief, and with hardship is ease. It is as if Allah has removed your harm and tribulation, enriched you and satisfied you, and given you your wish. So do not be among those thinking of Allah an evil thought, for He, Exalted, is more worthy of the beautiful. Do not be among the despondent, for He, Mentioned is His Greatness, relieves shortly. His saying, Majestic is His Glory, is the truest saying. Wait, my master, for the exit from tightness to breadth, and from disturbance to tranquility. Rejoice in a satisfied life and sufficient blessing. God Almighty willing.

"Another on Untying the Saying of the Other"
"Perhaps a relief Allah will bring; indeed... He has every day a command in His creation."
And the saying of another:
"Perhaps the Mender of the broken bone, by His bounty... Will prepare for the broken bone, so it mends.
Perhaps Allah... Do not despair of Allah, indeed He... Makes easy with Him what is great and big."
If you are, O my master - may Allah keep you - between a lying-in-wait ordeal and an intending calamity, suffering from them mote in your eye, choking in your throat, and harm in your heart; rather enduring what if it passed by iron would melt, or by a newborn would turn grey. Perhaps Allah brings a relief that mends your break, enriches your poverty, and fixes your affair. Do not despair of Allah, for every difficulty, if He eases it, becomes easy. His command, if He wills a thing, is only that He says to it, 'Be,' and it is.

"Section on Untying the Saying of some Alawites"
"Behind the strait of fear is the breadth of safety... And the beginning of what is rejoiced at is the end of sadness.
So do not despair, for Allah made Joseph possess... His storehouses after release from prison."
You know, my master - may I be your ransom - that behind the tightness of fear is the breadth of safety, and that the beginning of joy is the end of sadness. So do not despair of a relief that clears the flood of your distress and raises the star of your joy. For Allah brought Joseph out from the humiliation of slavery to the glory of freedom, and from the distress of exhausting imprisonment to the spirit of pleasing kingship. Many a matter was hard then became easy, and difficult then softened.

"Another on Untying the Saying of the Other"
"Move your wishes if you are distressed... For they are fans.
Perhaps paired with the trembling of hearts... Are successes.
And perhaps a good omen meets you... Under the thought."

If worries pile up on you, and clouds of grief accumulate upon you, and the plan of the matter narrows, and the eruption of distress intensifies, then take wishes as fans to fan your heart with, cool the heat of your chest, and see in their movement the calmness of your anxiety, and in intimacy with them the removal of your loneliness. Perhaps the trembling of hearts is paired with what delights the eyes, and the tongue of omen speaks what verifies thoughts.

Chapter
Dispraise of Time, Decline of the Noble, and Rise of the Mean

"Section on Untying the Saying of the Poet"
"Suffice it as sadness that chivalries were nullified... And that possessors of literature among people were wasted.
And that Kings, no one enjoys favor with them... Among people except one who sings and is slapped.
Their tambourines are populated with their instruments... While their mosque is empty of people, barren.
Oh would that I had become a singer among them... And was not miserable with what I was gathering."
Suffice it as sadness that chivalry has been wasted, youthfulness nullified, and possessors of literature lost due to lack of seekers. Most Kings are oblivious, playful, boasting of singers and those who are slapped. Their gatherings of intimacy are populated and flooded with amusements, and their mosques are abandoned. Oh would that I were a singer for them so I attain the wish, and realize wealth by singing, and was not miserable by gathering sciences, mastering the known, and wearing the robe of the deprived.

"Another on Untying the Saying of the Professor Abu Bakr al-Khawarizmi"
"Living turned away and the system was cut... And meanness lived when the mean lived.
Time left me behind upon people... If they imitated dogs, they would be noble.
Time almost insults me explicitly... If Time had speech.
Were it not that I dispute the decree of my Lord... I would have said: I ransom my death, and farewell."
The joy of living has turned away, the system of freedom cut off, the trace of humanity erased, the sphere of chivalry stopped, the days of the noble ended, and meanness lived by the life of the mean. Time left me behind upon people who, if they imitated dogs, would be the noblest of the noble. If Time spoke, it would pelt me with arrows of insult just as it intended me with its blameworthy actions. Were it not that I dispute the decree of Allah, before which there is no veil or defense, nor caution or prevention, I would have insulted this low world, wished for death, shortened speech, and said: I ransom my death, and farewell.

"Another on Untying his Saying also"
"The fire of highness died down after ignition... And Good shouted: Come to demise.
We lacked generosity except in wishes... And except in pages and dictations.
Oh would that notebooks were people... So creation would become rich from the nobility of deeds.
If I were made a commander of an army... I would not fight except by begging.
Because people are defeated by it... While they stood firm for the tips of spears."
Did you not see highness, how its firebrand died down and its horse stumbled? And Good, how it signaled demise and its saddles were tied for departure? And Generosity, how it became helpless, mighty, and scarce? Except in notebooks and books of news and exploits. Oh would that books were people, so their faces would be for beauty, their tongues for eloquence, and their hands for tolerance. If I were a commander of an army filling the earth, charging its length and width, and it occurred to me to rise against an enemy who showed the page of open hostility and rode the back of opposition, so he gathered and mustered, joined and spread, collected his sides and wrapped his wraps; I would not fight him except by begging, from which the heroes of men are defeated, while long they stood firm for sharp swords and long spears.

"A Note on Untying the Saying of Ibn Lankak"
"A time in which generosity became mighty (scarce) until... Generosity became in the highest towers.
The free passed away, became extinct, perished... And Time left me behind upon louts.
They said: You have stuck to the house strictly... I said: Due to the loss of benefit in going out."
You blamed me, my master - may I be your ransom - for sticking to the house, and said that the living, if he does not go out of it, is like the dead. As if you do not know that going out, if it is useless, isolation is the best sitter. Especially in this time when the generosity of the wealthy has become scarce until it became in the highest towers of the sky. The free passed away, so no fire-blower nor lighthouse-raiser remained of them. I remained among louts whose hidden nature baffled every treatment. They protect their pennies and degrade their souls. Do you blame me for hating them and continuing to diminish and reject them? I have no doubt that if you knew them, you would excuse me as you blamed me. God willing.

"Section on Untying the Saying of Ibn al-Rumi"
"I saw Time raising every scoundrel... And lowering every possessor of noble traits.
Like the sea, pearls sink in it... And carrion ceases not to float in it."
And the saying of Jahza:
"O Time, woe to you! What is this mistake?... A low one rose and a high one fell.
A donkey wanders in a meadow... And a steed is tied without fodder."

I see Time raising every vile scoundrel and lowering every precious free man. It is like the sea; precious jewels are in it (at the bottom), and vile carrion floats on top of it. Like the scale; it raises from the pan what inclines to lightness, and lowers from it what remains by weight, and distances from decrease. How many a donkey wanders in a green, fresh meadow, grazing in its green spring and drinking from its cold water. And how many a noble horse is tied without fodder. But it is Time, and its remedy is patience.

"A Note on Untying the Saying of the Other, narrated for Shams al-Ma'arif Qabus"
"O you who reproached us with the vicissitudes of Time... Does Time oppose anyone but him who has danger (importance)?
Do you not see the sea, carrion floats above it... And pearls settle in its furthest bottom?
We, even if the hands of Time tampered with us... And harm touched us from the persistence of its misery.
In the sky are stars that have no number... And none is eclipsed except the sun and the moon."
You reproached us - may Allah support you - with the vicissitudes of Time and confusion between its fangs and claws. Has Time opposed anyone but those of danger and the notables of the free? Its habit has always been raising the mean and lowering the noble, fighting the virtuous and making peace with the vile. Until it was compared to the sea in which fresh pearls sink and dirty carrion floats above. Even if Time singled us out with its massive accidents and excused others from its great calamities, in the sky are stars that cannot be counted by calculation, and none of them is eclipsed except the luminaries (sun and moon). This is a sufficient summary. Farewell.

"Section on Untying the Saying of..."
"This is the time which we were warned of... In what Ka'b and Ibn Mas'ud narrate.
If this lasts and no change happens to it... No dead will be wept for, nor a newborn rejoiced with."
This time has many wonders, not few calamities. Waker of fitnas (strife), not putting ordeals to sleep. It speaks only with complaint and is silent only upon tribulation. It is the time which long warned us of its evil and cautioned us against its harm. How many a non-rejected hadith came to us in it from Ka'b al-Ahbar and Ibn Mas'ud. By Allah, if what we see of the appearance of corruption and the prevalence of injustice in the lands lasts, the situation will surely turn to congratulating on death and condoling on births. Allah is the Helper against this time.

Chapter
Seeking Increase of Brothers

"Section on Untying the Saying of the Poet"
"I became a stranger asking whoever appeared to me... Of people: Is there a truthful friend?
They said: Two dear ones that are not found... A truthful friend and the eggs of the Anuq (bird)."
I am a man who has long been estranged, gone east and west, until as if I am a mote or painful kohl in the eye of the earth, and the successor of Khidr in traversing land and sea. My lost property sought in my travels, and the most important wish of my wishes, is a truthful friend I rely upon, lean on, and seek support from. I never asked about him an intelligent or clever person, and a wise man of letters, except he said: That is rarer than the pied eagle, and than the eggs of the Anuq. Yes, and than the red-footed crow and red sulfur.

"Another on Untying the Saying of the Other"
"Indeed, my friend is the one who strives for my benefit... And my beloved is not the one who wants my misery.
If I see misery with my loved ones... I see my prosperity with my enemies.
Cure nor removal of illness is hoped for... If the disease is from the place of the medicine.
To water runs the one who chokes on a morsel... So say: Where does he run who chokes on water?"
My friend is the one who is truthful to me, whose intention is pure for me, and who wants good for me. Not the one whom my offense pleases and my misery delights. If I see misery from my loved ones, I hope for satisfaction from my enemies. If the disease is from the direction of the medicine, the causes of cure are delayed. To his brother a human flees, and with water the choking one seeks help. If he chokes on water, in what does he seek aid? And if a man is attacked from his brother, in whom does he seek help?

"Another on Untying the Saying of the Other"
"Uff and Tuff to one whose affection... If I slipped from him a little while, slipped.
If the wind inclined this way and that... He inclined with the wind however it inclined."
Uff to one who befriends you, acts truthfully to you, and is sincere to you as long as you are in sight of his eyes and hearing of his ear. If you are absent from him for a period, his affection is absent. If you slip from him for a while, his love slips. No welcome to one who was, among friends, present at prosperity, missing at tribulation. He inclines with the wind and does not return to the correct knot (contract).

"A Note on Untying the Saying of Al-Muthaqqib al-Abdi"
"So either you be my brother in truth... So I know from you my lean from my fat.

Or cast me aside and take me... As an enemy I fear and who fears me."
I see you, O my master, befriending me then deceiving me, acting sincere then hunting me, being truthful then acting hypocritically, associating then grinning (insincerely). So either be my brother in reality and give me from your tongue the firmest document, or cast me aside and take me as an enemy I fear and who fears me, and I do not hope for you nor do you hope for me. Farewell.

"Section on Untying the Saying of the Poet"
"Suffice it as sadness that no friend nor brother... Gains wealth except arrogance enters him.
Or he twists or thinks you are below him... And that is the one which became great, so there is no patience with it.
So no friend attained above nourishment the amount of an atom... Nor was given ease upon his hardship.
And that is only desire for his brotherhood... Or caution lest abandonment sway him."
How many a brother I have who is a friend as long as he is straitened. He befriends and accompanies, agrees and corresponds. It is only that he recovers from the illness of poverty, takes off the robe of distress, the resources of his money expand, and the branches of his condition branch out, until he drags the tail of pride over his brother, and does not observe the pact of friendship in him. He places himself in the rank of Saturn, and thinks his brother below him in station. That is the one by which the chest narrows and for which patience does not expand. So no friend became solvent after hardship, nor attained above nourishment the weight of an atom. This supplication is only to maintain his brotherhood and perpetuate his purity, and caution lest abandonment take him in every way, and he rides every mount of arrogance and pride.

Chapter
Contentment

"A Letter on Untying the Saying of Al-Bassami"
"My house is dearer to me than... The house of the Caliph and the Vizier.
If I ate a little piece of bread... And drank from the water of the pool.
Then I am the Caliph, not the one... By whom the top of the throne is raised.
Indeed, the little if it is pure... And suffices, substitutes for the much."
You blamed me, O my master and lord - may Allah perpetuate your glory - for satisfaction with subsistence and sitting back from the service of kings and nobles. As if you do not know that I took contentment as a craft, and made it secretly a merchandise. I saw isolation as a formidable glory, and sticking to the house as a high rank. By Allah, my little house, despite the smallness of its yard, the shortness of its building, the narrowness of my living, and the scarcity of my furniture, is dearer to me and more preferred by me than the house of the Caliph, which is the sister of Paradise from which houses are shy and palaces fall short. And (dearer) than the house of the Vizier which contains what souls desire and eyes delight in. If I settle in my house, wear my rags, eat a little piece of bread from Halal, and drink an unleavened drink from fresh water, then I am the Prince, not the one by whom the throne is lifted. I am the Caliph, not the one to whom creation submits. It is of my doctrine that what is pure and sufficient of the little stands in for the abundant much. Farewell.

"Another on Untying the Saying of Abdullah ibn Tahir"
"How is the life of a man who has every day... A flag spread before a town?
And if the wind moves the sound of a drum... From afar, his heart is terrified.
O one rich from armies and the mission... Congratulations to you on the comfortable resting place.
Whoever has a piece of bread, living from people... Rich with it, then that is the Prince."
I see the subjects envying the shepherds (rulers) and governors if they see their beauties, and envying masters and leaders if they wish for their places. They do not know what is in the exterior of their conditions of internal horrors, and what is in those lofty ranks of hidden perils. They overlook what is in the whiteness of blessings of the redness of blood, and in the ease of life of the crime of the army. What is the life of one who exposes himself to tribulation and rubs against hardship in conquering the lands of enemies? He has every day spread flags and drawn swords. If the drum speaks, his heart palpitates, and if the clamor rises, his mind flies. O you who are dispensed from leading armies generally and specifically, and from mobilizing troops as a solid structure. O you whom Allah sufficed the clashing of swords and the confronting of deaths. Congratulations to you on the favored shade and the comfortable resting place. Know that whoever has subsistence and chastity, and his drink is pure and his flock safe, then he is the Prince even if flags do not flutter over him and mandates do not continue for him. Farewell.

"Another on Untying the Saying of Al-Khalil ibn Ahmad to Sulayman ibn Habib ibn al-Muhallab"
"Convey to Sulayman that I am in spaciousness from him... And in richness, except that I am not a possessor of money.
Poverty is in the soul not in money, we know it... Likewise the matter of richness is in the soul not the money.
If Sulayman was stingy with his gift... Then Allah is the most generous asked one for a asker."
And the saying of Mansur al-Faqih:
"Everyone in this world... Of people is few.
And the least of people is the one whom... The little from it does not satisfy."

I, O my master - may Allah support you - despite my distress and the bad effect of my poverty, am in spaciousness and richness from Sulayman. I praise Allah the Manan. For richness is the richness of hearts not the richness of wealth. Likewise, poverty is in souls not in conditions. If Sulayman was stingy with his gift and ran on his habit in depriving his asker, then Allah is the best hoped for and the most generous asked one. He is the Generous who is not stingy, and the Forbearing who does not hasten. You have known that whoever settles for the world has worn the robe of the humiliated, and the most humiliated of people is he who is not satisfied with the little. Often I say: Whoever is not content with the little is a captive of the wealthy. Farewell.

"Section on Untying the Saying of Muhammad ibn Bashir"
"For me to push through days of nakedness with worn clothes... And suffice from much provision with the hung (scant)."
"Is better and more honorable for me than to see favors... Everlasting from mean people on my neck."
It is of my doctrine that pushing through days with worn clothes and rough food is better than wearing the necklaces of favors of the mean. Farewell.

"Another on Untying the Saying of the Other"
"Contentment of the soul follows it with comfort... And the greed of a man brings him near to humiliation.
Greed is not an increaser in sustenance... Nor is slackness a decreaser of it."
In contentment is the rest of the soul and the protection of the face. Man's greed is a bringer of humiliation. His greed and striving do not increase a man's sustenance, just as his slackness and negligence do not decrease it.

"Another on Untying the Saying of the Other"
"If I am satisfied from Time that... I attain subsistence and a right living.
Then the rich and the poor... And the stingy and the generous.
Are equal to me, so why do I humble myself to one who does not give... And give the leadership?"
If I walked the paths of guidance and correctness, and was satisfied from Time with subsistence and payment, then equal to me are the rich and the poor, the great and the small, the generous who is the companion of generosity and its friend, and the stingy who is the colleague of stinginess and its guest. So why do I humble myself to one who acts mightily over me, and give the leadership to one who does not do good to me? Whoever I dispense with, I am his equal, and whoever I need, I am his captive. Peace be upon the other.

Chapter
On Sustenance

"A Letter on Untying the Saying of the Poet"
"O rider of the night and horrors and destruction... Do not tire yourself, for sustenance is not by movement.
Do you not see the sea and the fisherman standing... In his night while the stars of the night are entangled?
He has gathered his limbs while the wave beats him... And his eye is between the eyes of the chest of the net.
Until when he became happy with his desire... And the whale had blocked the skewer of the one who hooked it.
It came to you with him pure without turbidity... So you became owning it more than the one who owned it.
A making from Allah, He gives this by the trick of that... This one hunts and this one eats the fish."
O my master - may Allah support you - you cease not to survey the edges of stages, ride the horrors of watering places, endure distances farther than your hopes, and tread unknown lands that overlook destruction with you. As if you do not know that sustenance is divided and the greedy is deprived, and that sustenance is not by movement and fatigue, and bearing hardship and toil. So gently, O my master, and kindly. Reduce your toil and decrease your seriousness and effort. Do not be like the fisherman of the whale who suffers for the happiness of another with it. Do you not see him how he advances on the sea and risks his life while the night has lowered its curtains and dragged its tails over him? The wave takes him and leaves him, and terror narrows on him and widens. His eye is on the net and his concern is catching the fish. Until when he catches it with the sweat of the brow and swallows the two bitters (calamities), it comes to you pure without turbidity, and gives it to you pardoned without danger. That is only from the making of Allah who gifts properties to His servants, and provides for this one by the striving of that one. So this one hunts wretched, meeting (hardship), and this one eats wholesomely, pleasantly. Blessed be the Wise Creator and Glory be to the Generous Provider.

"Section on Untying the Saying of the Other"
"Man strives and sustenance strives seeking him... So perhaps they differed in striving and seeking.
Until when the Merciful estimated their meeting... For agreement, sustenance came to him from near."
To you, O my master and lord, is a hadith. You see a man seeking sustenance while it seeks him hastily. Perhaps they differed, so this one went east and that one went west, and the face of deprivation appeared there. Perhaps they agreed, so sustenance called out answering, and success happened nearby. If Allah wills a matter, its causes agree, and if He does not decree a thing, its seeking becomes impossible.

"Another on Untying the Saying of the Other"
"If sustenances run upon creatures... With justice, my sustenance will overtake me running.
And if sustenances run upon them... With generosity, I hope He will be generous to us also."

I do not accuse the Provider, nor do I deem sustenances slow. If they run by justice in the decree and division by equality among creation, my sustenance will come to me flying to me with the primary feather of the crow and the covert feather of the eagle. And if they run upon them by injustice - and far be it from Allah - I hope He will be generous to me also, and not break His habit with me.

"Another on Untying the Saying of the Other"
"If you know that your Lord is a Creator... And you worshipped a creature, then you are not a believer.
Or if you were in doubt regarding the sustenance which... The God guaranteed, then you are not certain."
And the saying of another:
"Do not humble yourself to a creature out of greed... For that is a decrease in you in religion.
And seek sustenance from Allah from what is in His treasures... For indeed sustenance is between the Kaf and the Nun."
If you know that Allah is your Creator and you worshipped a creature, then you are not a believer. If you were in doubt regarding the sustenance which Allah guaranteed, then you are not certain. Beware that greed for the creature enslaves you, so you decrease in religion and disdain certainty. Seek sustenance from Allah, for His sustenance is between the Kaf and the Nun, meaning His saying "Kun" (Be) so it is.

"Another on Untying the Saying of the Other"
"If there was in a deaf rock anchored... In the sea, gathered, smooth of sides.
A sustenance for a servant created by Allah, it would split... Until it delivers to him all that is in it.
Or if its path was under the layers of the seven (heavens)... Allah would facilitate the nearness of its ascents.
Until the one for whom in the Tablet is a share attains it... Either it comes to him or he comes to it."
O son of Adam, do not worry about your tomorrow's sustenance, and act as if it is in your hand. If your sustenance were in a deaf rock, gathered, and joined to the bottom of the sea, it would split from it until it reaches you and is obtained by you. If it were in the seventh heaven, Allah would facilitate its descent to you, until you attain what was written for you in the Tablet, and exchange distress for spirit (relief). Either it comes to you or you come to it, and quickly or slowly you possess it.

Chapter
Estrangement

"A Letter on Untying the Saying of the Poet"
"As if I am entrusted with designating the lands... To know of them the place of length and width.
If I have a return one day, then it is worthy... Otherwise, some evil is lighter than some."
I wrote, my master - may Allah perpetuate your glory - from some dwellings of transfer and places of estrangement. The lands have thrown me around, and homelands have rejected me, until as if I am entrusted with measuring the earth and knowing the longitude and latitude. Or as if I am the successor of Khidr in traversing land and sea. If my travels result in the deal of the winner and I return to the homeland with the spoil of the victorious, then praise be to Allah for the life of hopes and the goodness of conditions. If it be the other, then some evil is lighter than some, and there is no despair in estrangement of ease and lowering (of wing). Farewell.

"Another on Untying the Saying of the Other"
"And if the dwellings change from their state... Then leave the dwellings and hasten the transfer.
Staying is not a mandatory duty upon you... In a town that leaves the mighty humiliated."
And the saying of Al-Buhturi:
"And the most beloved of the land's horizons to the youth... Is a land in which he attains the noble demand."
And the saying of another:
"A man in his town is lost... And the lion in his thicket is hungry.
So rise, you will see the world and meet wishes... And death, no repeller repels it."
If your country and homeland reject you, and your desire and wish become impossible, then in the earth there is a place to move, and upon Allah is reliance. I advise you, my master, to depart from a town that clothes the mighty in the robe of the humiliated. The most beloved horizons to the noble is a land by which they reach the desire. Of old it was said that a man in his town is lost, just as the lion in his thicket is hungry. So upon you is estrangement to see the world and attain wishes. Beware of fear of death, for it is not repelled in the homeland and urban area, nor in estrangement and travel. Farewell.

"Another on Untying the Saying of Al-Burqu'i"
"In disturbance and in estrangement... Is the attainment of wishes and reaching the desire.
If the fire, its fire stick narrows with it... Its spaciousness is in separating from the fire stick.
If a sharp sword settles in its sheath... Another contains the virtue on the day of struggle."

I do not approve for you, my master and lord - may Allah support you - sticking to your house in your insolvency, and satisfaction with your state despite the perfection of your tool. I urge you to replace sleep with wakefulness, and residence with travel. Reach every extent of disturbance, and borrow the wing of the crow in estrangement. As if I see your travels having resulted in a spacious place for unloading the saddle, and in success as a lodger and ease as near. I do not increase you, my master, in knowledge that the authority of fire is in separating from the fire stick, and that swords, if they settle in scabbards, their virtue does not appear at clashing and struggle. May Allah make the best accompanying you in your travel and presence, your stay and departure, and all your actions and directions.

Chapter
Hatred of Estrangement

"A Letter on Untying the Saying of the Poet"
"Whenever I remember the House (homeland), my tears overflow... And my heart becomes a spoil for mumblings.
Yearning for a land in which my mustache turned green... And in which the knots of amulets were untied from me."
And the saying of another:
"Nearness of the House in poverty is better... Than the expanded living in estrangement."
And the saying of Ali ibn al-Jahm:
"O my mercy for the stranger in the distant land... What has he done to himself?
He separated from his loved ones, so they did not benefit... From life after him, nor did he benefit."
