I wrote - may Allah prolong my master's survival - and when I remembered the homeland, tears choked me, and sighs overcame me. Yearning for a land whose soil raised me, whose air nourished me, whose breeze brought me up, and in which amulets were untied from me. And regretting a town in which was the greening of my mustache and the prime of my youth, and in which is the gathering of my peers, brothers, and loved ones. Residence in it with insolvency was dearer to me than settling in other than it with wealth. But the decree of Allah has no defense before it nor prevention, nor abstention from it nor caution. So O my mercy for the stranger afflicted with the distress of estrangement and the burning of separation, residing in the land far from his homeland, distant from his dwelling. O my sorrow for what he did to himself and cut of his intimacy, when he separated from his most special loved ones and sincerest brothers. Neither do they benefit from life after him and rest from pain at his distance, nor does he enjoy his life after them and distinguish between it and his death. It is not difficult for Allah to return his estrangement and facilitate his return to his loved ones.

Chapter
Greyness (Old Age)

"A Letter on Untying the Saying of Al-Sahib"
"What is the matter with her, she has exposed me... At my greyness to harm?
She says 'Away' after... She used to say 'Welcome' (Habba-dha).
I was the kohl of her eye... So I became in it like the mote."
And the saying of Al-Buhturi:
"The songstresses fault my greyness... And who is for me to enjoy the faulted?
My passion for youth, even if it passed... Is praiseworthy, below my passion for greyness."
My letter, my master - may Allah prolong your survival - and the morning of greyness has shone for me after you, and I was robbed of what I wore of the fresh robe of youth. My slave girl denied me and hated me, turned away from me and abandoned me, exposed me to harm and shunned me. She began saying to me 'Away', 'Uff', and 'Tuff', after she used to say 'Welcome', 'Hello', 'Family', and 'Ease'. I was in her eye like kohl and slumber, so I became in it like insomnia and mote. Greyness is a sin with songstresses not forgiven, and a defect not covered. Would that this defect lasted for me and covered part of me and all of me, and did not separate between me and my term (death). My passion for the departing youth is below my passion for the descending greyness. Farewell.

"Section on Untying the Saying of Ibn al-Rumi"
"I became an old man having mark and pomp... The whites (women) call me 'Uncle' sometimes and 'Father'.
That is a call of reverence and honoring... I wished I were compensated for it with a nickname."
I have worn the cloak of greyness, and the pomp of old age has ascended me. If the songstresses call me 'Uncle', I am filled with grief. If they call me 'Father', I think they heaped abuse on me. That is from them a call of reverence, even if it is to me a call of impairment. My wish is if I were compensated for it with a nickname requiring nearness from them.

"A Letter on Untying the Saying of the Other"
"I was stripped of youth, and I was fresh... Just as the branch is stripped of leaves.
I wept over youth with all my tears... So weeping nor wailing benefited.
Oh would that youth returns one day... So I inform it what greyness did."

You knew me, my master - may Allah perpetuate your glory - young of age, moist of branch. You see me now having been stripped of the pleasing youth as the branch is stripped of leaves. How much I grieved over it the fill of my chest, and wept for it the fill of my eye. So the staying grief did not benefit, nor did the flowing tear cure. How often I say: Oh would that youth returns one day to me, and stops by me even for an hour. So I renew a covenant with it, guide coolness to my liver, and complain to it of greyness and its bad effects and bitter fruits. However, attaining the days of our Master the Just King, the Patron of Blessings, Khwarazm Shah - may Allah perpetuate his state - is a new youth and a happy life. In passing life in his presence, viewing fortunes by his countenance, and enjoying the wearing of his blessing which races blessings, reveals worries, and raises ambitions, is a compensation for youth and its freshness, and the time of boyhood and its bloom. May Allah make him, of all that is prayed and will be prayed for kings and glorious ones, taking the most complete shares and the fullest numbers. Amen, O Allah, Amen.

"Another on Untying the Saying of Ibn al-Mu'tazz"
"O my blamer, Time has sufficed you my refutation... I took from the glances of the buxom soft girl.
And it sent greyness into my head and its parting... With its white falcons upon my black crows."
And the saying of Yahya ibn Ziyad al-Harithi:
"When I saw greyness, its whiteness settled... In the parting of my head, I said to greyness: Welcome.
If I thought that if I withheld my greeting... It would turn away from me, I would have desired it to turn away.
But when it settled hated, the soul tolerated... It one day; it was more removing for the hate."
And the saying of Muslim ibn al-Walid:
"Greyness is hated, and hated is its leaving me... Wonder at a thing loved despite hatred.
Youth passes and a successor may come for it... But greyness goes lost with a lost one."
I see you, my master - may Allah support you - blaming me for the impulses of youths and the instigations of Satan. Time has sufficed you my refutation and blame, since my yesterday in licentiousness is not like my today. I have forgotten the winks of glances from sick eyes since greyness bridled me with its praiseworthy bridle, and sent its white falcons upon my black crows. When it laughed to me revealing the fangs of snakes, and I wept over the sweetness of life, I said: Welcome to you as a comer whose stay I will honor, and hello to you as a visitor whose entertainment I will improve. Had I thought that if I withheld my greeting from its appearance I would find safety from its assault, I would not have greeted one who robs me of my intimacy, nor honored one who announces my death to my soul. But when the intended hateful thing and the pain of the observing matter settle, if a man's soul tolerates what it meets of evil and endures of bitter life, that is more repelling to its harm and more removing for its shame. It is known that greyness is hated in visiting and embracing, hated in going and separating. So despite hatred of it, it is loved, and despite its bad effect, it is not cursed. That is because youth passes and greyness succeeds it, while greyness is followed only by near death. May Allah help us in preparation for the Day of Return.

"Another on Untying the Saying of the Other"
"Let not greyness frighten you, O daughter of Abdullah... For greyness is ornament and dignity.
Gardens are only beautiful when... Flowers laugh in their midst."
And the saying of Di'bil:
"Welcome and hello to greyness, for it is... The mark of the chaste and the awe of the pious.
My greyness was like a string of shining pearls... In the crown of a glorious, crowned king."
And the saying of Al-Buhturi:
"And the whiteness of the falcon is truer in beauty... If you contemplate, than the blackness of the crow."
My letter, my master - may Allah perpetuate your glory - and greyness has descended upon my hair and extended its embroidery on my face. Flowers laughed in the garden, tar whitened, and dignity loomed. So welcome and hello to greyness, and welcome to the beloved enemy. For it is the mark of the chaste pious, and the awe of the noble scrupulous. In it you witness experience and the title of trial and wisdom. As if it is the ornament of a king or a string of pearls in the crown of a king. The camphor of greyness is more splendid than the musk of youth, and the whiteness of the falcon is more beautiful than the blackness of the crow. Farewell.

"Another on Untying the Saying of Ibn al-Rumi"
"O man who blackens his hair... So that he is counted thereby among youths, desist.
Even if you blackened every white... Pigeon, you would not be counted among crows."
Dyeing - may Allah support you - is of false witnesses and goods of deception. I see you in severe trouble and arduous effort from overcoming Time by blackening hair. So gently, may Allah have mercy on you. Know that old men are not counted among youths. Even if you blackened white pigeons, you would not be counted among crows. Farewell.

"Another on Untying the Saying of some long-lived Arabs"
"The benders of Time bent me until... I am like a sneaker approaching a prey.
Short of step, he who sees me thinks... While I am not shackled, that I walk with a shackle."

I wrote - may Allah keep you - while the decades of my life have doubled, and days have taken from my body. Old age bent my bow until I am like a sneaker of prey. Weakness shortened my steps until I am like one walking with a shackle. What is hoped from one like me in the shortness of steps, the failure of powers, the nearing of the term, and the heading towards the other abode? Farewell.

Chapter
Praises

"A Letter on Untying the Saying of Abu Nuwas"
"You have descended, O Abu al-Abbas, in a station... Behind which eyes do not see a place to cast (ambition).
You entrusted Time with an eye not heedless... With the generosity of your palm, you heal all that it wounded."
And the saying of Abu Tammam:
"The beauties of Ahmad ibn Abi Dawood have made forgotten... The evils of all Time.
Whenever you settle with him, you settle in a courtyard... Suckling from the night clouds and morning clouds.
The blessing of days filters from him... And the provisions of servants are divided in him."
And the saying of Ibn al-Rumi:
"His sides shake at praise when he hears it... From the shake of Glory, not from the shake of Mirth (Tarab).
As if he, while asked and praised... Ishaq sang to him and the strings are in clamor.
Were it not for the wonders of Allah's making, these virtues would not have grown... In flesh nor nerve."
And the saying of Al-Wawa al-Dimashqi:
"Whoever compared your gift to the clouds has not... Been fair in judgment between two forms.
You, when you give, are laughing always... While it, when it gives, is tearful of eye."
I wrote - may Allah prolong the survival of my master - from the Presence in Gurganj - may Allah guard it - and I praise Allah Almighty that I am in it among the servants of our Master the Supported King, the Patron of Blessings, Khwarazm Shah - may Allah strengthen his victory and perpetuate his kingdom. He has descended from Highness to the highest station behind which there is no aim for eyes, and above which there is no field for thoughts. He entrusted Time with his high ambition and his guarding eye. He heals all that it wounded and revives all that it slaughtered. Until his beauties made forgotten the evils of all time, and his virtues encompassed every human. If you settle in his presence, you settle in the spacious quarter and the fertile courtyard, which is the suckling of clouds and remover of worries, the mine of generosity, the spring of blessings, the refuge of creation, and the divider of sustenance. If you see there, you see bliss and a great kingdom, an illuminating moon, and a raining cloud. If he hears free speech in the service of his high qualities and praise of his endeavors, the shake of Glory and the relief of pure Generosity take him. As if Ishaq al-Mawsili is singing to him, and the strings are responding, and the cups are alternating. Were it not for the grace of Allah and the wonders of His making and the marvels of His power, those virtues would not have grown in flesh, nor those noble deeds mixed with blood. So blessed be Allah, the Best of Creators. May Allah keep our Master for the world and religion. By Allah, he was not fair who described his flooding generosity and compared it to the raining cloud, because it gives while it is frowning of face, weeping of eye, while our Master - may Allah guard his kingdom - gives while he is apparent of cheer, laughing of tooth. May noble deeds never cease to issue from his characteristics, and successes be watched from his lightnings.

"Section on Untying the Saying of Al-Buhturi"
"You drew near in humility and rose in glory... So your two matters are descent and ascent.
Likewise the sun is far from being rivaled... And light and rays draw near from it."
And the saying of Abu al-Tayyib al-Mutanabbi:
"If you surpass mankind while you are of them... Then musk is some of the gazelle's blood."
Our Master the Supported King, the Patron of Blessings, Khwarazm Shah - may Allah strengthen his victory - in his lofty place and wondrous humility is like the sun, near in light and far in height. In his generosity and nobility and good characteristics, he is like the rain quenching the thirsty and reviving the livelihood. If he surpassed those in the horizons while he is of them, and excelled all of them while he is part of them, then musk is some of the gazelle's blood, and emerald is some of the stones of mountains. May our Master never cease to increase over people the increase of the sun over the moon, and the sea over the drop.

"Another on Untying the Saying of Al-Buhturi"
"For people are two full moons whose rising is not hidden... The full moon of the sky and the full moon of the earth, Ishaq.
A radiant one, doors of giving are opened by him... And for deaths by him are opening and closing.
Both your hands are right, having no left... And in your right hand are terms (lives) and provisions."
For people are two full moons combining highness and brightness, encompassing the horizons with their lights. What is in them of beauties and what creation has by them of blessings cannot be counted. As for the full moon of the sky, it is the one Allah illuminated and raised. As for the full moon of the earth, it is Ma'mun ibn Ma'mun Khwarazm Shah. He is the King who fills eyes with beauty and hearts with perfection. In his hand are the keys of provisions and terms. From his presence are the rising points of hopes and terrors. He is trustworthy over Allah's creation, and both his hands are right. Allah is his supporter, the full moon is his peer, happiness is his backer, and glory is his companion.

"Another on Untying the Saying of Ali ibn Jabala"

"Tigris gives drink, and Abu Ghanim... Feeds whoever Tigris gives drink to among people.
People are a body, and the Imam of Guidance... Is a head, and you are the eye in the head."
To Allah belong honored servants; Ma'mun feeds them and Jayhun gives them drink. What a difference between giving drink and feeding, and between livestock (An'am) and favoring (In'am). People are a body whose head is the Commander of the Faithful and the Imam of Muslims. Our Master the King Khwarazm Shah - may Allah strengthen his victory - is the eye of the head, the point of people, and the spring of dew and might. May Allah keep him as long as souls draw from breaths.

"Another on Untying the Saying of Al-Mutanabbi"
"Allah has honored a land you are its inhabitant... And honored people since He made you a human."
And the saying of Abu al-Fath Kushajim:
"Mankind stared at your perfection, so seek refuge... From their evil eyes with a single fault."
Allah has honored the earth and made it one of the best regions and most auspicious spots since our Master the King Khwarazm Shah - may Allah perpetuate his kingdom - inhabited it. He is a scholar in the garb of a world, and a king in the form of an angel. Just as He honored people by creating him a human. He is beauty in its entirety, and perfection in its totality. There is no fault in him other than that 'no fault in him' turns the eye (evil eye) away from his high qualities. Would that he had a single fault to protect his glory and extended beauties with. Even if he does not protect them with a fault, the Knower of the Unseen will protect him from the accidents of time and its calamities, and guard him from its misfortunes and thunderbolts. And He will place upon his soul, his blessing, his kingdom, and his dear ones a lasting protection by His mercy.

Chapter
Satire

"Section on Untying the Saying of Al-Hutay'ah"
"Leave noble deeds, do not travel to seek them... And sit, for you are, by my life, the fed, the clothed."
And the saying of Al-A'sha, and they are among the most satirical poetry of the Arabs:
"You spend the night in winter full of your bellies... While your female neighbors are hungry, spending the night empty-bellied."
Leave noble deeds to their masters, and abandon them to their owners. Do not move your foot towards them, nor tighten your saddle to them. Move away from noble deeds, which are to you among debts, rather among prohibitions. And sit at the place of rebuke of weary dogs, and in the row of sandals. You are only for comforting the body, sweetening the food, improving the dress, and refining horses. You are the one who guards his money while honor is lost, and fills his belly while the neighbor is hungry. Suffice that as meanness and blameworthy character.

"Another on Untying the Saying of Muslim ibn al-Walid"
"Their appearances were ugly, so when I tested them... Their appearances became beautiful due to the ugliness of the substance."
And his saying, which we present from the eyes of the poetry of the moderns counted in satire:
"As for satire, your honor is too small for it... And praise regarding you, as you knew, is great.
So go, for you are released by your honor; indeed it is... An honor you were mighty by, while you are humiliated."
I have been afflicted with people, fed ones, mean ones. You find their appearances ugly as long as you do not know their substances. When you test them, you find their ugly appearances beautiful due to the ugliness of their blameworthy substances. There is none of them but his honor is too small for satire and defamation, just as saying praise and eulogy is too great for him. He is in the custody of his vileness and baseness, and the contempt of his meanness and vice. He is released by his honor, malicious in his vehicle, mean in his lineage. Indeed, he was mighty by it while he is more humiliated than a nail clipping in garbage, and less than straw in mud brick.

"Another on Untying the Saying of Abu Umara al-Suri, and it is the most eloquent said in its meaning"
"A heavy one Allah created, the heaviest of what is seen... In every heart is a hidden hatred of him.
He walked, so the whale called its Lord from his heaviness... And said: My God, the earth increased an eighth."
No welcome to the heaviest of the two weights (Jinn and Mankind), and the most hated of the people of the two horizons. One who has in the heart of everyone on earth an abundant, full share of hatred. When he walked, the whale felt pain from his heaviness and complained of him to its Lord, and said: O You who encompassed creation with justice and grace, You created an eighth earth by which You increased me in heaviness. Allah will relieve the whale from the heaviness of his stillness and movement, and the rest of creation from the abundance of his bad luck and lack of his blessing, by His grace and mercy.

Chapter
The Gift

"A Letter on Untying the Saying of Ahmad ibn Yusuf the Scribe to Al-Ma'mun"
"Upon the servant is a right, so he must be its doer... Even if the Master is great and his favors are majestic.
Did you not see us gifting to Allah His property... Even if He is Rich from it, He is its accepter."
And the saying of another:
"If I were to gift according to the measure of your virtue... Then I would have gifted you the world and what is in it."

Upon the servant - may Allah prolong the survival of our Master the King, the Patron of Blessings, Khwarazm Shah - is a right he must fulfill, and serve with what he gifts, even if the Master is great and his high qualities are majestic. Therefore, we gift to Allah His property which is from His gifts, so He accepts it from His servants despite His richness. If I were to gift to his treasury - may Allah populate it with the length of his life - according to the height of his destiny and the loftiness of his status and command, I would have gifted the world in the exhibition of its greenness and freshness, and Paradise in the robes of its splendor and bloom. But I stopped at my capacity in service with a little that the sincerity of my thanks makes much, and a small amount that the clarity of my excuse makes big. If he sees - may Allah elevate his opinion - to show favor to his servant by permission to present that to him, honoring him and increasing in kindness to him, he will do so, God Almighty willing.

"Section on Untying the Saying of Ibn al-Matran"
"Affections, if devoid... Of mutual gifting, are muddied.
Like a stew devoid of... Meat, called Muzawwarah (Falsified/Vegetarian)."
And the saying of another:
"There is no friend, even if his friendship is complete... One day, more successful in needs than a dish (gift).
If he covers himself with the napkin setting out... He does not fear the repulsion of a doorman or a lock.
Do not lie, for people since they were created... For desire they honor people or fear.
Indeed deeds are above the star in their demand... And speech is found thrown on the roads."
Brotherhood is by mutual gifting, and alliance by mutual kindness. Affection without a gift is muddied, just as broth without meat is Muzawwarah. Nothing is more reforming for two friends and more gathering for the reunion of love between two brothers than a dish of kindness and gentleness, containing masterpieces and novelties. If its carrier covers it with a napkin, he does not fear the difficulty of the heavy barrier. It is known that most people give out of desire or fear, and the fewest of them is he who gives out of mercy and reckoning (reward from Allah). Deeds have always been difficult to desire, rare to attain and establish, found on every road and with every enemy and friend. What a difference between sound dirhams and speech that goes in the winds.

"A Note on Untying the Saying of the Poet"
"My gift is a ring to a man of letters... Reminding him of the covenant of his servant's affection.
If a pupil were engraved with its look... I would have made the eye the stone of his ring."
With this note of mine - may Allah prolong my master - is a ring gifted by a servant. He showed kindness with it to his gathering, to remind him when he wears it. He wishes he could mount in it the gem of his chest and engrave it with the pupil of his eye, so he would not be devoid of seeing him in the state of his presence and absence. My master is higher of eye in what he sees of accepting it and signing to me with the mention of its arrival. God willing.

"Another on Untying the Saying of the Other"
"We have sent to you - may Allah support us - ... A kindness, so be accepting of it.
Do not compare it to the dew of your flooding palm... And your abundant, copious kindness.
And forgive the smallness of the gift from me... Indeed the effort of the poor is not little."
I sent to you, O my master and lord - may Allah prolong your survival - something that slips from thought and is less than mention. So I love that you accept it despite its smallness, and do not compare it to what you give despite its abundance. And know that it is the effort of the poor, not the choice of the independent, and the masterpiece of the frugal courteous one, not the gift of the accumulating wealthy one. Farewell.

"Another on Untying the Saying of Abu al-Atahiya"
"A sandal I sent for you to wear... A foot with which you strive to glory.
If it were proper that I share with it... A cheek, I would have made my cheek its strap."
I sent to my master - may Allah perpetuate his support - a sandal with which he strives to every noble station, general glory, and great honor. Even if I cut it from my skin and strapped it with my cheek, I would not reach what is in the intention of servitude. Farewell.

"Another on Untying the Saying of Mansur al-Faqih"
"I gifted something that would be little were it not for... The story of omen and blessing.
A chair (Kursi) I took as a good omen in it when... I saw its reverse pleases you."
And the saying of Abu Bakr al-Khawarizmi:
"I ransom you; I did not send the cup (Kub) except... For an omen in it, a beginning, a return.
If you reverse Kub, it is Kawn (Being/Universe)... So be a universe that lasts without corruption."
The masters of men have spoken regarding Omen, because it is the tongue of time, and in it is the joy of man. With this note of mine, O my master - may Allah perpetuate your glory - is a chair (Kursi) I intended for omen and blessing, when I saw its reverse pleases you: 'Kub' (Cup), its reverse is 'Buk' (?). 'Kursi', its reverse is 'Yusrk' (Pleases you). So be a universe without corruption, and a sale without stagnation. And remain for accepting the little and giving the much, as long as eternity is known and nights and days connect.

Chapter
Congratulations

"A Letter on Untying the Saying of Ibrahim ibn al-Abbas"
"We do not congratulate you on Tus... But we congratulate Tus on you.
For Tus has become today... By you, a bride."

Whoever congratulates governors - may Allah prolong the Prince's survival - on the governorship of lands delegated to their care, and whose good management is roused in them; then I congratulate the land to whose people Allah did good, and upon whom He turned with His grace, since it was added to what the Prince - may Allah perpetuate his support - assumes. So the traces of his competence improve in it, and the ray of his happiness extends over it. I ask Allah to couple good and choice with what He entrusted him, and grant him success to attain His pleasure in what He gave him, and make him know of the happiness of his work what leads to the realization of his hope. By His grace and mercy.

"Another on Untying the Saying of Ibn Khallad the Judge to Abu Muhammad al-Muhallabi"
"Congratulation on the Vizierate"
"Now when the bow was handled by its shaper... And its night-traveler saw the direction in the darkness."
I praise Allah Almighty for the blessing that encompassed the people of the earth, and singled out those of pure virtue. Since the Vizierate was arranged from our Master the Vizier - may Allah prolong his survival - with its equal and sufficient one. The bow was handled by its shaper, and affairs ran their best courses. So the world is congratulated by what extended over it of his deed, and the earth shines with the light of his justice and virtue. May Allah choose good in what he took charge of and assumed, surround him with protection and support him, and couple success with him and not isolate him. Amen.

"Another on Untying the Saying of Adi ibn al-Riqa' al-Amili in congratulating some sons of the Caliphs of Banu Umayya on the Wedding"
"The moon of the sky and its sun gathered... With happiness, they did not set nor rise.
The curtains did not hide the like of them... Among whom we saw and whom was heard of.
May joy last for him with her and for her... And may they be congratulated throughout life together."
Welcome to the gathering of the sun and the moon, the meeting of hearing and sight, the connection of the free man with the free woman, and the conjunction of Jupiter with Venus. The seers have not seen the gathering of their likes in a curtain, nor have the narrators narrated the meeting of their forms in a chamber. May Allah perpetuate their joy with each other, congratulate them throughout life in ease and lowering (of wing), and make the connection between them connected with the most growing numbers, the purest children, the most perfect talents, and the most praiseworthy consequences. Amen.

"Another on Untying the Saying of Ibn al-Rumi congratulating on a Newborn"
"A full moon and a sun gave birth to a star... I swore by Allah they have produced a noble one.
Blessed is Allah and Glory be to Him... What a meteor from them is most piercing!
Three whose lights shine... No east was exchanged for a west."
Glad tidings! For the result of honor and glory has appeared, and the moon and the sun gave birth to a star of happiness. So Glory be to Allah! What piercing meteor was generated from them in the sphere of happiness, and what shining light sparkled by them in the horizon of nobility? They are three whose lights shine, and whose news are good. May no wests be exchanged for their easts. May Allah perpetuate the gifts for them, bless the parents and the child, make known in him the happiness of the birth and the blessing of the resource, and show from his sons righteous children and serving grandsons. Amen.

"Another on Untying the Saying of Abu Tammam in Congratulating on the Arrival from Hajj"
"As for that you performed Hajj, it is accepted and righteous... The share is abundant from you, the sin is forgiven.
You performed of the Hajj of Islam its obligation... Then returned, and the effort from you is thanked."
Thanks, thanks, O my master - may Allah prolong your survival. You have intended the most noble destinations, witnessed the most honorable scenes, visited the Ancient Glorified House, and served the Corner, the Hatim, and Zamzam. You arrived at the watering places of Paradise, and camped at the dwellings of Mercy. You performed the loan and fulfilled the obligation. You returned to your family happy, abundant. May Allah make your Hajj righteous (Mabrur), your effort thanked, your scales heavy, your trade profitable, and blessings coming and going to you.

"Another on Untying the Saying of Abu al-Fath to his son Abu al-Fadl Ibn al-Amid congratulating him on Nayrouz"
"Be happy with a Nayrouz that came to you announcing... Happiness, increase, and permanence.
So drink, for the spring has uncovered its veil... Revealing a cheerful, smiling view."
May Allah make our Master the Supported King Khwarazm Shah happy with this new season and praiseworthy Nayrouz. Which visited him announcing the most complete happiness, the best habit, and the most perfect increase. And inviting to drink upon the face of the fertile spring, for it has uncovered its veil revealing the beautiful wondrous view. Our Master - may Allah prolong his survival and perpetuate his kingdom - is higher of eye in what he sees of accepting the invitation, fulfilling the right of intimacy in it, striking the fire of joy in cups, and asking rain from the cloud of amusement with wine. May he never cease to be hitting with the arrow of hope, abundant in the wing of joy, observing life green of wood, wearing time continuous of fortunes, drawing lots for the virgin pleasures as he draws lots for the virgin lands, and picking the fruits of livelihood and the Hereafter. And may Allah perpetuate his authority as long as times repeat and Nayrouz and Mehregan alternate.

"Another on Untying the Saying of Ibn Abi al-Tayyib al-Mutanabbi congratulating Sayf al-Dawla on Eid"

"Congratulations to you on the Eid which you are its Eid... And an Eid to one who named and sacrificed and celebrated Eid.
For this day among days is like you among mankind... Just as you were unique, it was unique."
How do we serve the High Assembly of our Master the Supported King Khwarazm Shah - may Allah strengthen his victory and perpetuate his kingdom - on this happy day? And how do we congratulate him on the Eid while he is the Eid of the Eid? He is among the kings of mankind like this day among days. May he never cease to be congratulated with its likes, attaining the utmost of his hopes. May Allah make this Eid of the most auspicious of Eids in arrival, and the most complete of them in benefit.

"Another on Untying the Saying of Abu al-Shis congratulating and consoling"
"The neighbor ran in happiness and misfortune... So people are in loneliness and in intimacy.
The eye weeps and the tooth laughs... So we are in a funeral and in a wedding.
The Riser (Qa'im) Al-Amin makes us laugh and... The death of Al-Rashid yesterday makes us weep.
A full moon in Baghdad spent the night in comfort... And a full moon in Tus spent the night in the grave."
I wrote - may Allah prolong the survival of our Master the Prince - while I am between joy and sorrow, happiness and tears, rejoicing and disturbance. Due to what ran of Allah's decree with happiness whose lights shone, and misfortune whose traces were bad. So it encompassed all people with desolation and intimacy, and made them weep and laugh between funerals and weddings. It obliged each of them to raise hands to Allah asking for patience upon the great calamity and the massive loss in the past Prince - may Allah be pleased with him and please him, and make Paradise his abode. And obligated them to bear thanks for the general gift and the noble blessing in our Master the Prince, the Master - may Allah perpetuate his support - the inheritor of the throne of his authority, established in his high place. Praise be to Allah who, when He took back the most noble loan, delivered the best wishes. When He tested with the greatest horrors, He favored with the most noble hopes. When He hid the full moon of the earth in the grave, He compensated us for it with the sun. He, Exalted, is asked to pave for the past one in the Paradise of Refuge, and necessitate for him the degrees of nearness and proximity. And to prolong the survival of our Master the Prince, inheritor of ages, possessor of hopes, removing by the permanence of his period the griefs, and blocking by the freshness of his state the gaps. Amen.

Chapter
Elegies and Condolences

"A Letter on Untying the Saying of Ibn al-Mu'tazz in the Elegy of Ubayd Allah ibn Sulayman the Vizier"
"People became equal and perfection died... And the vicissitude of Time said: Where are the men?
This is Abu al-Qasim in his coffin... Arise, look how mountains vanish.
O supporter of the kingdom with his opinions... After you, for the kingdom, are long nights."
And his saying:
"Did you not see the death of highness and praiseworthy deeds... And how we buried creation in one grave?
Time has days that abuse intentionally... And do good, if they do good, unintentionally."
And the saying of Mansur al-Faqih:
"I say when their saying crushed me... Ibn Aqil passed to his Lord.
Because he resembled people most in his death... Indeed he lived a time without a resemble."
I wrote - may Allah prolong your survival, O my master - while the matter has become grave, the calamity great, the announcer came, efforts were mourned, people became equal, perfection died, terms ruled, and Time said: Where are the men? So-and-so rode the coffin after the throne, and mounted necks after horses. Look how impregnable mountains collapse and high mountains vanish. Oh my sorrow if sorrow availed, and oh my regret if regret was useful, upon the supporter of the kingdom with his opinions that hide their plots and show their benefits, and plans whose beginnings succeed and whose consequences delight. How eclipsed is the mind of Glory since it swallowed his loss, and how long are the nights of the kingdom after him! Highness and praiseworthy deeds died with his death, and virtues and institutes ended. Glory wore for him the clothes of a bereaved griever. Creation was buried in one grave. Time has days that do good inadvertently and do evil intentionally, and give in jest and take back in earnest. How often I said when so-and-so moved to the neighborhood of his Lord and turned to His honor and pardon: Because he resembled people most in his death, indeed he was without a resemble throughout his life. May Allah have mercy on his falling place, cool his lying place, honor his return, and make the abode of the righteous his place. And may He grant you success for what fortifies reward and does not nullify it, and provides recompense and does not drop it. And may He prolong your period after him, and make thanks in blessing your material, and patience upon tribulation your equipment.

"Another on Untying the Saying of Abu Tammam, and it is the blaze (best) of his elegies"
"Lo, indeed in death's gaining of a soul... The eye of noble deeds remains weeping for it.
It is the soul; if noble deeds weep for its loss... It is pulled from between the vitals of noble deeds."
And the saying of Abu al-Atahiya:
"Be patient for every calamity and endure... And know that man is not immortal.
Do you not see that calamities are many... And you see death lying in wait for servants?
Whoever is not afflicted, among those you see, with a calamity... This is a path in which you are not unique.
If you mention a calamity to be saddened by... Then remember your calamity with the Prophet Muhammad."

I wrote, my master, while I am weeping of eye, restricted of chest, robbed of patience, thinking evil of Time. How can I not be so when I see between the sharp claws of death and its strong fangs a noble form being preyed upon, and a generous soul being snatched? The eye of highness weeps, the heart of glory panics, and the soul of virtue is terrified. No wonder that Generosity weeps for it the fill of its eye, and grieves for it the fill of its heart. From its vitals it was pulled, and from its liver it was cut. What is the trick when the inevitable decree has settled, and the obligatory condolence has become due? Accidents are more than the plants of the earth and the drops of the sky. Who is he who has not been afflicted with the great loss? You are not, my master, unique in this path. Among what eases the severity of calamities and lightens the weight of misfortunes is remembering the calamity in the Master of Worlds and Seal of Prophets, Muhammad, blessings of Allah and His peace be upon him and upon his family and companions all. In him is solace, and for us in him is a model. May Allah pour upon you endurance matching the gathering of your opinion and intellect, and patience preserving for you the stores of your forbearance. And may He fulfill for so-and-so the portions of His forgiveness, and dwell him in His spacious gardens. Your opinion, master - may Allah prolong your survival - in writing to me with what you were guided to of the resolve of patience and determination of endurance, so I follow you in them and quote their lights from you, is thanked. God willing.

"Another on Untying the Saying of Ibn al-Mu'tazz"
"Do not grieve, may you be protected from grief and pain... And may you not lack a survival accompanying blessings.
Is it not said, in what you do not deny... That among the honors of a youth is his sending forward the harem (women/daughters)?
O gloater over Banu Wahb when they were bereaved... Do not rejoice at a decrease that increased them in honor."
Do not grieve, my master, may you be protected from grief and pain. And may you not lack a survival accompanying blessings. Know that burying daughters is among the honors, covering private parts is among the good deeds, and sending forward the harem is among the blessings. Let it reach the gloater over Banu So-and-so what I say, and acceptance is not upon me: Do not rejoice at a decrease that increased them in honor and benefited them in blessings. They have been alerted with an admonition, provided with a reward, covered a private part, and sufficed a burden. Farewell.

"Section on Untying the Saying of Muslim ibn al-Walid, and it is the most elegiac verse of the moderns"
"They wanted to hide his grave from his enemy... So the goodness of the grave's soil indicated the grave."
The gardens whose sides were thin and whose embroiderer was elegant envied a land in which so-and-so was buried. When fear hid his grave from the enemy in the earth, the breeze of pure generosity indicated it. The scent of fresh glory wafted from it, and its soil substituted in goodness for the breaths of the beloved.

Chapter
Visiting

"Section on Untying the Saying of the Poet"
"If you wish to be hated, visit continuously... And if you wish to increase in love, visit intermittently."
And the saying of another:
"Stick to lessening the visit, for it... If it increases, it is a path to abandonment.
For I saw the rain tired of when constant... And asked for with hands when it withheld."
Visiting is an increase in friendship, its scarcity is safety from boredom, and its excess is a cause of severance. Everything excessive is the enemy of nature. How excellent is what the Owner of the Sharia, peace be upon him, said: "Visit intermittently, you will increase in love." Rain, if it does not increase, is Ghayth (relief/rain). If it lasts and continues, it is Ghaith (vomit? likely intended: bothersome). No wonder it is tired of if it lasts, even if it revives plants and livestock. And it is asked for with hands and supplication if the knot of the sky is not untied by it.

"A Note on Untying the Saying of the Poet"
"I saw you loving me... And at the time I am absent, yearning.
So I abandoned not for boredom... Occurring, nor did I create a blame.
Except for the saying of our Prophet... Visit over the days intermittently.
So I abandoned when I abandoned so that... I increase by intermittence in nearness.
So excuse Abu Hasan and do not... Make my sitting away from you a sin.
Allah knows that I am... To you, of the two weights (Jinn and Mankind), the most sincere in heart."
I see you, O my master and lord - may Allah prolong your survival - loving me, yearning for me, reading the page of affection from my heart. So I sit back from you at some times without boredom or blame calling for disturbance. But to take the Sunnah of intermittence in visiting loved ones. I abandon you, O my master, out of desire for your connection, and distance myself from you out of eagerness for your nearness. I am patient from continuing with you out of stinginess from me for your sincerity. I hope you accept my excuse in apologizing, and turn my affair to the beautiful. Do not count as a sin my intermittence in visiting and my mediating between the two ends of severance and perseverance. By Allah, neither the dusty (earth) carries nor the green (sky) shades one more sincere than me in heart in loyalty to you, and purer in conscience in comforting you. May Allah prolong your period and guard your affection.

"Section on Untying the Saying of the Poet"
"Lessen your visiting the friend... You will be like the garment he renews.
Indeed, the friend gets bored of him... If he ceases not to see you with him."
And the saying of Abu Tammam:
"And the length of a man's stay in the tribe wears out... His brocade (face), so go away, you will renew.
For I saw the sun increased in love... To people because it is not eternal upon them."
Perhaps mutual hatred is in frequent meeting. So lessen the visiting of the loved one, you will be to him like the new garment. Do not expose yourself to boredom by frequent union. If your brocade wears out with loved ones, renew it by moving and estrangement. Know that the sun, if it did not set and stayed, and did not go down and continued, people would tire of it despite its beauties in the horizon and the generality of its benefits to creation.

"Another on Untying the Saying of Al-Abbas ibn al-Ahnaf"
"Longing brings a house near while it is distant... Whoever treated longing did not enslave the house."
Longing, my master - may I be your ransom - shortens the distant road, urges the slow mounts, and folds the low bed. Here I am visiting you and not repaying you for your aversion, and reviewing you and not holding you for your repulsion. The lover, if not asked to visit, visits, and does not enslave the house. Farewell.

Chapter
Visiting the Sick

"A Letter on Untying the Saying of Ahmad ibn Yusuf"
"They said Abu al-Fadl is ill, so I said to them... May my soul be his ransom from every caution.
Would that his illness were with me, and that he has... The reward of the sick while I am unrewarded."
And the saying of Abu Tammam:
"No life unless illness avoids your body... So distress clears by you from your brothers.
May you rise (La'a), Abu Ja'far, and be safe, for indeed saved... By you are chivalry and by you nobility rose high.
We were ignorant so we thought you fell ill, but no... By Allah, nothing fell ill but Wit and Literature."
It knocked on my hearing - may Allah prolong my master's survival - the news of his complaint, may Allah couple it with his recovery. So a fright overtook me, and anguish possessed me. I ransomed him from the cautioned with the two dear ones: family and child. Rather, with the two pillars: heart and liver. Rather, with my entire self and my whole soul. I wished I bore the illness and its pains on his behalf, and he attained its reward and recompense. I swear I have no life unless recovery shakes hands and rising and independence approach. So clouds clear from his brothers, and wellness circulates with the beloved to his friends. I ask Allah Almighty with sincere intention and pure belief to lift his side from it, erase his sin by it, save him as chivalry and virtues were saved by him, and perpetuate his highness as the piercing lineage rose high by him.

"Another on Untying his Saying also"
"Abu al-Qasim the Praised (Al-Mahmud) if praise is mentioned... You were protected from calamities whatever goes and comes.
If edges of a fever have reached you... No wonder that the rosy lion is fevered.
Ours, not yours, is the complaint, and it is not harmful... If the blade of the sword is healthy, what the sheath encountered."
May Allah keep you and protect you, heal you and suffice you and grant you wellness. If you complained, my master, of an illness, and became a target for fever, no wonder that the rosy lion is fevered, and the moon eclipses the full moon. Ours, not yours, is what you endure of pains. And in the sheath, not in the sword, is the blade. Farewell.

"Another on Untying the Saying of Ibn al-Rumi"
"For you did not fall ill, rather High Ranks... And you did not sicken, rather Hearts."
And the saying of Ibn al-Mu'tazz:
"O Time, the Vizier falls ill... And I do not approach his door.
This is of the misery which... I ceased not to be of its companions.
O Lord, keep death away from him... And wash him from his pains.
Who is like him? None is like him... In the worlds, nor with him."
Our Master - may Allah prolong his survival - did not fall ill, but the soul of Highness and the hearts of allies. How often I said when the news reached me of what happened to him of illness, and what pain he has of pain: O Time, does our Master - may Allah support him - fall ill so you hinder me from visiting him, until I do not approach his courtyard? This is nothing but misery which accompanies him forever. Then I said: O Lord, wash him from his pains with the water of healing, and enrich him with safety from medicine and doctors. For who is like him while Glory and Generosity are within his clothes, and with all people is his likeness?

Chapter
Satire

"Section on Untying the Saying of the Poet"
"The blessing of Allah is not faulted, but... It may be deemed ugly upon some people.
Richness does not befit the face of Abu Ya'la... Nor the light of the splendor of Islam.
Dirty of robe, turban, and palfrey... And face, nape, and boy."

The blessing of Allah, its risings are not faulted, but its locations may be deemed ugly with people who are the order of defects and ugliness, and the gathering of disgraces and scandals. It is to me like the noble free woman married by a mean slave, and like the luxurious necklace worn by a ugly monkey. By Allah, richness does not befit the face of Abu Ya'la, nor does the light of Islam shine upon it. Do you not see him, chronically ill of chivalry, dirty of clothes, disheveled of mount and boy? He is more similar to the poor than to the rich. May Allah not distance other than him, and suffice us his meeting.

"A Letter on Untying the Saying of the Other"
"If you are a possessor of money and are not preferring (generous)... Then you have no virtue over the dog and the monkey.
To a saying: My fathers built glory and highness... You spoke truth, but you have shat on glory."
And the saying of another:
"You boasted of your origin, a noble origin... Strike with it your obscure self.
And what does the origin from Hashim benefit... If the soul is from Bahila?"
And the saying of another:
"O most generous of people in fathers and boasting... And meanest of people when tested and tried.
Men lower their eyes if his fathers are mentioned... To him, and lower their eyes if his deed is mentioned."
If you are supported by money like the number of men and above hopes, and did not walk with it the paths of benevolence and favoring, and were turning away from the beautiful and closing eyes to the good, then what virtue do you have over the vile dog and the base monkey? If you boasted of your noble fathers who built glory and highness over the days, we said: You spoke truth. But they built and you demolished, they were generous and you were not, they were righteous and you were not. Rather, you shat on glory. You are a shame among blazes, and a pebble among pearls. What does the noble origin benefit the silly branch, and the Hashimite lineage and the Bahilite soul? What good is the most generous of people boasting, and the meanest of them when tested? If his fathers, who are the most glorious ancestors and best nobles, are mentioned, men lower their eyes to them out of magnification, greatness, reverence, and respect. If he is mentioned, he lowers his eyes out of shame from his bad news, and looks down out of embarrassment from his malicious trace. May Allah protect us from the positions of ugliness and gatherings of cursing, and cover us with His beautiful cover, and shade us with His shading shadow.

"Section on Untying the Saying of the Other"
"Your father is a free father and your mother is a free woman... And two free ones may birth a non-noble.
So let not people wonder at you and at them... For dross from silver is not wonderful."
Your father is free and your mother is free. There is nothing in them but a blaze (nobility). But you are between them a shame. Two noble ones may birth a non-noble. Dross from silver is not wonderful, nor are thorns in the palm tree strange, nor smoke from fire odd.

"Section on Untying the Saying of the Professor Abu Bakr al-Khawarizmi regarding Raja' and Al-Abbas, sons of Al-Walid al-Isbahani"
"And when I saw the two sons of Walid... And between them a difference in deeds.
I gifted the ugliness of this one to the beauty of that one... And advanced the consequences and nights.
It is the hand; the right of it did good... So we permitted for it the sin of the left."
When I saw the two brothers, So-and-so and So-and-so, and between them a far distance in qualities and severe difference in deeds. So-and-so has in every noble deed the blaze of white horses and the primary feather of the wing. And So-and-so protects his penny and degrades his soul. I gifted the ugliness of this one famous for disgraces to the beauty of that one mentioned for high qualities. I ran on my habit in advancing consequences and nights. They are in representation nothing but the two hands; the right of them did good, all good. So we permitted the sin of the left by the permission of Allah the Manan.

"Another on Untying the Saying of Abu al-Fath al-Busti"
"I said when you became a chest (leader) and the groups... Of people became delegates to you.
May Allah not tend to the one who tended to you and raised... Above the hands of the sons of highness your hands.
For indeed, he is humiliated who granted you glory... And indeed, he slipped who slipped towards you."
I saw you as a chest issuing your opinion, and people crowding at your courtyard. I did not possess except the supplication issuing from a constricted chest and a snowy heart. I said: May Allah not tend to the one who tended to you, until your hands rose above those of highness. For indeed, he is humiliated who extended the tent of glory over you, and slipped, by Allah, who slipped towards you.

"Another on Untying the Saying of Mansur ibn Badhan"
"Abu Dulaf, poverty to me is not in its essence... Except a man hoping for your dew and expecting it.
As if you are a drum, wonderful of voice, hollow... Empty of goods, desolate are its entrances.
And more amazing than what is in you is the handing over of command... To you in mockery, and that you are accepting it."
Abu Dulaf, the poor is none but the one hoping for your dew. And the disappointed in his right and truth is none but the one seeking shade in your shelter. You are nothing but the drum; its voice frightens while it is empty of returns, and its fame pleases while it is zero of benefits. Of wonder is people handing over command to you in mockery, and your accepting it metaphorically and as a nickname.

"Another on Untying the Saying of Ibn 'Arus al-Shirazi"
"Perish Time, for it has come with a wonder... And erased the traces of wit and literature.
And came with scribes, if my hand extended... In them, I would have returned them to the Kuttab (School).
And I see Ibn Jumhur has become boasting... Imitating the great scribes.
But he tears a thousand scrolls when... He is asked for an answer to a letter."
And the saying of Abu al-Fath Kushajim:
"Did you claim that in writing you are overtaking... My striving, and said: Our weapons are pens?
Far from it! That is a mixed craft... In it is clear light and darkness.
This iron is the weapon of the heroes of war... And with it the cupper spills our blood."
Perish and relapse for Time, for it has come to us with wonder, erased the traces of literature, and came with scribes who rightly should be returned to the Kuttab. Among them is So-and-so, fraudulently inserting himself among the great scribes and their likes, imitating their leaders and virtuous ones. He is the stupid one who tears scrolls and exhausts bundles when ordered to answer a letter, then does not come up with correctness in it. The matter is that he claims to rival me, and alleges that he is overtaking my striving in matching me. He says: Our craft is one, which is speech, and our weapon is one, which is pens. He does not know that the craft of writing varies in degrees, differs in classes. In it is sunny morning and pitch-black darkness. And this iron is the weapon of heroes whom refrainment does not afflict, and with it the cupper extracts our blood. Farewell.

"Another on Untying the Saying of Ibn Zurayq al-Kufi regarding Al-Suli's Poetry"
"My house is without Khaysh (coarse linen for cooling), but I... If I wished, the Khaysh would be two layers.
A house, if its heat pains me... I recited two verses of Al-Suli."
The authority of heat has strengthened, and the carpet of embers has been spread for it. The mid-day heats borrowed their fire from the heart of the abandoned, until they exceeded the heated oven. When I became weary with it of life, and the trick in ice and Khaysh failed me, I intended Al-Suli's poetry and recited two verses from it, and repeated it twice. So I find the mask of heat has been uncovered, and its harm has been restricted. I see the scorpions of cold creeping to me, and its storms blowing on me. So wonder at poetry that returns summer as autumn, nay dense winter. Oh what a beneficial medicine for severe heat, if only it didn't bring us the prepared severe cold (Zamharir).

"Another on Untying the Saying of Abu al-Fath Kushajim, and it is the most eloquent said in satirizing the singer and wittiest"
"And a singer, cold of tone... Impaired of hands.
His nearness cuts pleasures more... Than the shout of separation.
No one saw him in... The house of a people twice."
We have been afflicted with one who sings, so he distresses. And plays, so he does not delight. Rather, he necessitates hitting him after cursing him. His nearness imitates the shout of separation between lovers. He is not free of defect and stumbling, and is not seen twice in a house.

"Another on Untying the Saying of the Other"
"The heavens weep when he calls... And the earth seeks help from his prostration.
If he desires one day the meat of sandgrouse... He strikes them down in the air with his breath."
And the saying of the other:
"He spent the evening talking to me, so I said to my companion... Is he talking or breaking wind from his mouth?
Oh woe to basil, his weeping is by him... And woe to the cup that gives him drink."
We seek refuge in Allah from the breaths of So-and-so, for they take away breaths and fly the souls of sitters. If he calls, the sky weeps from his greasy, dirty call. If he prostrates, the earth seeks help from his prostration breathing of excrement. If he desires the meat of birds while they are in the air, almost hitting the clouds of the sky, it is only that he sends up to them that deadly breath, and sets upon them those malicious breaths, until he strikes them down around him in twos and ones, and hunts them - may Allah make him ugly - a hunter. Among his characteristics is that it is not known if he broke wind or breathed, and passed gas or spoke. So oh woe to the drink that becomes from his drinking, and oh woe to the basil that greets him. Oh what a man, the entrance of his eating is more malicious than the exit of his waste.

"Another on Untying the Saying of the Other regarding the Length of the Beard"
"And a beard four by four... Long, wide, square.
He weaves from it every day a shirt... And stuffs from its edges a pack-saddle."
And the saying of Al-Najim:
"And a beard carried by a fool... Like two sails when they are raised.
If he dove in the sea a dive... He would catch its whales all together."

If the beard grows long, the mind becomes sparse (Kawsaj). If it increases, virtue decreases. I see for So-and-so a beard among the wonders of the earth, extreme in length and width. Every corner of it is a cubit by a cubit, and every wing is a sail with a sail. If it were of goods, it would be of sacks. Or of sins, it would be of major sins. If shaved, shirts would be woven from it. If plucked, pack-saddles would be stuffed with it. If he dove with it in the sea, he would catch its whales. If he traversed the desert with it, its ghouls would be frightened.

"Another on Untying the Saying of the Other regarding the Size of the Nose"
"I was in a banquet of a people who sent... A messenger towards Musa the Crusher (Al-Hutamah).
So his nose came to us before forenoon... And Musa came long after darkness."
A wonder, not hidden from you. Which is that I was in a banquet attended by noble guests and witty youths. They suggested So-and-so to marvel at his huge nose and massive heaviness. When the messenger was sent to him - and the story is long - his nose came to us uprooting, while the day had matured and risen. He came while the night had cast its cloak upon us and dressed us in its fur. So seeing exceeded hearing, and we witnessed one of the lessons. We spent the night drinking and being merry and delighted, and marveling at that obscene nose.

"Another on Untying the Saying of Abu Bakr al-Badisha'i regarding a Parasite (Tufayli)"
"O ant of ghee in parasitism, no... Trick blocks its approaches.
He smells the scent of roasting from a march of two months... So in an hour he arrives at it.
If we protect ourselves from you with the wall... And with doors and the lock, you do not care about them.
And if we swat you like a fly from the... Dish so you do not taste what is in it.
You fall into it risking, so it is either... Eating or death in its sides.
We plant the vineyard for wine, so you see... Counting its days and numbering them.
Year by year, so when it is clarified or... The clay is removed from its jars.
You came gently so you are its drinker... Before its clarifyer and its cupbearer."
O more parasitic than an ant on ghee, and than the fly on dates. I see you smelling the scents of cooking and roasting from a march of two months, so you arrive at them in less than two hours. Walls and doors do not repel you from them, nor do locks and veils benefit us with you. If we chased you like dogs and swatted you like flies, you fell into the dishes and were not deterred from them by sticks. You risked yourself, so either frantic eating or malicious death. The vineyard is planted in its time and supported by its sticks. You cease not to count its days and number its years, until it ripens and is trellised so it holds fast, and bears the mothers of nectar in stores of crystal and carnelian. When it is picked and stacked, and presses are taken for it and it is pressed, and deposited in the bellies of jars, and given respite for a time, you calculated its period and fulfilled its count. So when the clay is taken from its jars, you work the trick in it, and drink its purity before he who clarifies it and serves it. So may the pure wine not be wholesome for you, which you repel (others) from with the palm. You crowd the most generous class, and drink it like sand in summer.

"Another on Untying the Saying of Abu Bakr al-Khawarizmi regarding Veiling (Hijab)"
"Abu Nasr, gently with veiling... For you are not that great man.
And do not be stingy with that face from us... For it is not that beautiful face."
And the saying of another:
"I will leave this door as long as its permission is... As I see, until it softens a little.
If I do not find a trick for permission with you... I found a way to leave coming."
Gently, Abu Nasr, with this long veiling. For you are not that great man, nor is your face that beautiful, nor your gift that abundant, nor your shade that shading. I have abandoned your door, and left you and your veil, until what was difficult of your permission becomes easy, and what was hard of it becomes simple. If I do not find a way to enter upon you, I found it to leave coming to you. Peace be upon other than you.

"Another on Untying the Saying of the Other"
"By my life, if you veiled the slaves... With your door, the rhyme is not veiled.
I will throw it from behind the wall... Hideous, bringing you calamity.
It deafens the hearer and blinds the seer... And safety is asked for without it."
If you veiled the slaves from you, and the severe rejection from you faced me, they did not veil from you the circulating rhymes and the dazzling rare meanings. I throw them from behind your wall, and attack your house with them. I send them as burning thunderbolts, disturbing calamities, scorpions and snakes. They deafen ears, blind eyes, strike skins, and tear veils. Without them, Allah is asked for safety and lasting protection. No trade profited for one who made his honor a target for my speech and set himself as a goal for my arrows.

"A Letter on Untying the Saying of Ibn Tabataba al-Alawi"

"If I intended what is in your hands begging... Or came complaining to you the tightness of my hand.
You knotted for me with thousands four... Decreased by seven from the number."
And the saying of Al-Mushattib al-Bayhaqi:
"I said to a water-carrier at his door... Tottering with the waterskin, naturally gifted.
Why do you carry water to his house... While bread in it is strictly forbidden?
He said: To spray on whom he fears for... And to wash if he dies of hunger."
And the saying of another:
"They set up the sentry on a hill... And said: Do not sleep, to the sentry.
If you see a person from afar... Then clap with fingers on fingers.
You see them, out of fear of guests, mute... Establishing prayer without Adhan."
You asked me - may Allah keep you - about So-and-so. You have fallen upon the expert and encompassed the clarity of his state. Know that he is the image of miserliness, the person of stinginess, the statue of meanness, and the mold of blameworthy character. Whenever I entered upon him, complaining of the tightness of my hand to him, and seeking what is in his hands, he knotted for me four thousands, and decreased seven from them without dispute (referring to a hand gesture indicating nothing/zero). I have an anecdote with a water-carrier, one of the wittiest of his likes and most naturally gifted of his forms. I saw him running with the waterskin to his house. I said: Why do you carry water to one who is stingy with bread to his family let alone his visitors? He said: To sprinkle on the face of whom he fears for from emptiness (hunger), and to wash with it whoever dies of hunger. No wonder, he is of a people known for miserliness and described with meanness. They take their caution against guests, and see in them the edge of swords. They set up the sentry on the hill overlooking the regions and districts, and advise him to be awake and sharpen the eye, until if he sees a person, he claps with hands. Another anecdote is that you hear nothing from them but whispering, and you see them, out of fear of guests, mute. They, in most times and moments, establish prayer without Adhan. It is fitting for those whose qualities are these that their union not be sought. Farewell.

"Another on Untying the Saying of Ibn Bassam"
"Abu Ja'far built a house and erected it... And the like of him is a builder of good houses.
Beautiful is its exterior and hunger is its interior... And in its sides are misery and harm.
What does the decoration of his house benefit a man... While there is no good nor water in its hollow?"
And the saying of another:
"If you desire his drinking companionship... Then lift your right hand from his food.
For death is lighter to him... Than a guest chewing and swallowing.
Equal are the breaking of his loaf... Or the breaking of a bone of his bones."
And the saying of Ibn al-Rumi:
"Isa skimps on himself... And he is neither remaining nor immortal.
If he could, for his skimping... He would breathe from one nostril."
Of the quaint news, O my master - may I be your ransom - is that So-and-so built a house that buildings lower their heads in shame from, and palaces admit falling short of. Its exterior is beauty complete, and its interior is hunger existing. What benefits the noble house and the beautiful buildings in it, while there is nothing in it to feed, nor found in its regions what to nibble? Mentioning the man, if you desire his friendship, lift your right hand from his table. Because red death is lighter to him than the guest moving his jaws before him. Equal to him are the breaking of his neck and the breaking of his loaf. If he could, for his cold estimation and increasing skimping, he would breathe from one nostril. This is a little of his many uglinesses, and some of the flood of his scandals. Farewell.

"Another on Untying the Saying of the Other"
"Lo, O hated of Allah and son of his hated one... I see hatred of old in your father and in you.
Your father is the Imam of people in hatred, all of them... And you are the Crown Prince after your father."
And the saying of another:
"O you from whom Allah turned away... The world out of his hatred.
And O you whose part testifies... With the part to his hatred.
And O heaviest of Allah's creation... Of those walking on His earth.
And whom the Angel of Death loathed... And disdained his seizing."
And the saying of another:
"And a heavy one, more severe than the nearness of death... And than the intensity of painful punishment.
If Hell disobeyed its Lord, there would be... Nothing but him as punishment for Hell."

O you who inherited hatred from his father... So he contained it and fulfilled it. If your father was an Imam in hatred not to be surpassed... Nor competed with, nor repelled, nor denied, nor defended, nor disputed. And indeed his crown prince during his life... And his successor after his death. And you are the most hated walker on the face of the earth... And one whose parts testify against the other with hatred. Your death is not decreed... And your days do not end because the Angel of Death flees from you due to your hatred... And does not proceed to seize you. You are heavier than the slap of humiliation in the land of estrangement... And than the distress of death upon sin... And than the punishment in the kindled Fire of Allah. If Hell disobeyed its Lord... Its punishment would be nothing but you... And it would not be tortured except by your dwelling and meeting. May Allah relieve us from your hatred and heaviness... And grant us a good look by your transfer. Chapter on Proverbs "A Poem by Abu al-Fath al-Busti and the Untying of Every Verse according to the Proverb Written Under It" A man's increase in his world is a decrease... And his profit other than pure good is a loss. Increase in the world is decrease. And every finding of a luck that has no stability... For its meaning in verification is a loss. Whoever found what has no stability has lost it. O builder of the ruined house diligently... By Allah, is there for the ruin of life a construction? O builder of his house and property, are you able to build what was ruined of your life? O greedy for wealth collecting it... Have you forgotten that the joy of wealth is sorrows? The path of wealth is sorrow and its joy is sorrow. Do good to people, you will enslave their hearts... For long has kindness enslaved the human. Kindness enslaves the human. And be upon Time a helper to a hopeful one... Who hopes for your dew, for the free man is a helper. Help the brothers, for the free man is a helper against Time. And strengthen your hands with the rope of religion, holding fast... For it is the pillar if pillars betray you. Hold fast to the rope of religion, for it is the firm rope. Whoever fears Allah is praised in his consequences... And He suffices him the evil of those who were mighty and those who were lowly. Whoever fears Allah wears wellness and praises the consequence. Whoever seeks help from other than Allah in a request... Then his helper is inability and disappointment. Whoever seeks help from other than Allah, his helper disappoints him. Whoever is generous with money, people incline entirely... To him, and money is a temptation for humans. Whoever is generous with money, people incline to him. Whoever makes peace with people is safe from their calamities... And lives cool of eye, joyful. Whoever makes peace with people is safe. Whoever has the authority of reason over him tomorrow... Greed has no authority over his soul. Whoever the authority of reason possesses, the authority of greed does not rule over him. Whoever associates with people encounters fatigue from them... Because their nature is transgression and aggression. Whoever associates with people is not safe from their calamities. And whoever searches for brothers hates them... For most brothers of this age are traitors. The brothers of this time are traitors. Whoever sows evil reaps in its consequences... Regret, and for reaping the crop is a time. Whoever sows evil reaps regret. Whoever relies on the wicked sleeps while in... His shirt from them is a viper and a snake. Whoever relies on the wicked wears his shirt over vipers. Be moist of cheerfulness, for the free man, his ambition is... A page upon which cheerfulness is a title. Cheerfulness is the title of the free man's kindness. And accompany gentleness in all matters, then... No companion regrets nor does a human blame him. Whoever accompanies gentleness, his companions praise him. And let not a luck dragged by clumsiness deceive you... For clumsiness is destruction and a man's gentleness is construction. Gentleness builds and clumsiness destroys. Do good if there is possibility and ability... For possibility will not last upon doing good. Seize doing good as long as there is possibility. Protect the freedom of your face and do not tear its veils... For every free man is a protector of the free face. The free man is the one who protects the freedom of his face. If you meet an enemy, meet him always... With the face by cheerfulness and radiance covered. Extinguish the fire of enmity with the water of cheerfulness. Leave laziness in good deeds seeking them... For no lazy person becomes happy with good deeds. Most often, laziness and happiness do not gather. The shade of a man is stripped of piety and intellect... Even if leaves and branches shaded him. If a man is stripped of the shade of piety and intellect, he is exposed to the sun even if shaded. And people are helpers of the one whose state befriended him... And they are against him if it became hostile to him, helpers. People are helpers of the owner of the state, and they are against him if it turns. And do not entrust the secret to a slanderer, humiliating it... For no wolf tended sheep in the desert. Do not entrust the secret to a slanderer, just as you do not entrust the wolf with sheep.

Not every water is like Sada' for its drinker... Yes, nor is every plant a Sa'dan. Not every roof is a sky. Nor every water Sada'. Nor every branch Khayzuran. Nor every plant Sa'dan. And for managements are knights; if they gallop... In them, they excel just as war has knights. For the management of affairs are knights, just as for fighting are knights of wars. Do not scratch with procrastination the face of a favor... For kindness is scratched by procrastination and delay. Do not scratch with the nail of procrastination the face of the favor. Suffice from living what has blocked a need... And in it for the free man is contentment and sufficiency. Suffice from living a sufficiency that blocked a need. The content person is pleased with his living... And the owner of heat (greed), even if rich, is angry. The content is pleased even if poor. And the greedy is angry even if rich. Suffice the youth his mind as a friend he associates with... If brothers and friends avoid him. Suffice the youth his mind as a friend if friends avoid him. They are two suckling brothers: wisdom and piety... And inhabitants of a homeland: money and tyranny. Wisdom and piety are suckling brothers. And money and tyranny are racehorses. If a homeland rejects a noble man, he has... Behind it in the vast earth homelands. If his homeland rejects a noble man, then the earth is his homelands and people are his brothers. O oppressor, rejoicing in glory, helped... If you are in a slumber, then Time is awake. If you are in a slumber from your glory, Time is awake. Whoever finds injustice palatable, if its eater were fair... While he finds the taste delicious, is suffering (Khatban). The eater does not find injustice palatable, just as the taster does not find Colocynth sweet. O scholar of pleasing biography... Rejoice, for you are quenched without water. O scholar, you are quenched without water. And O brother of ignorance, you have become in depths... So you are amidst them undoubtedly thirsty. O ignorant one, you are thirsty in the depth. Do not think joy lasts forever... Whoever a time pleases, times displease him. Do not think joy lasts, for whoever a time pleases, times displease him. O strutting in the lush youth, intoxicated... From its cup, did a drunkard attain guidance? The drunkenness of youth is like the drunkenness of wine. Do not be deceived by a lush, moist youth... For how many youths advanced before greyness. Do not be deceived by youth, for the old Sheikh may carry the funeral of the small child. Suppose greyness shows the excuse of its owner... What is the excuse of a grey-haired one whom a devil seduces? What is the excuse of the Sheikh if he does not triumph with his authority over his devil? All sins, Allah forgives them... If sincerity and faith accompany the man. Sins are forgiven with true sincerity. And every break, religion mends it... And what breaks the channel of religion has no mending. Every break is mended by religion, and there is no mending for the break of religion. "Likewise a Poem by Abu Abdullah the Blind Al-Abiwardi" My fasting, if I break fast with illicit gain, is error... And my knowledge, if it does not benefit, is a type of ignorance. I do not count fasting if I break fast with Haram. And if knowledge does not benefit, it is a type of ignorance. And my purifying (Zakat) money I collected from usury... Is calculation, and some generosity is taken from miserliness. Like the thief of pomegranates from her neighbor's vine... Visiting the sick with them and coveting virtue. And a prostitute giving the poor her earnings... She has nothing but toil upon the kiss (or acceptance?). Whoever purifies money collected from usury is like the thief of pomegranates doing good to the sick with them. And the prostitute giving the poor the wage of adultery. And whoever traveled carried by the fangs of a wolf... It is better for him than his traveling barefoot. Riding the fangs of the wolf is better than walking. The crow comforts the wolf in all his hunting... And what the crows hunted in the palm fronds. The wolf shares with the crow in his little catch, and what the crow hunts in the tops of palms. To a disobedient mother who does not see the cradle of her child... Is dearer than the wet-nurse kind to the child. The harsh mother is kinder to the boy than the kind wet-nurse. If the sheep turn returning from the emptiness... Their crooked goat becomes leading the herd. If the sheep turn back, the lame goat advances. If the owls neighbor the falcons, their... Buttocks (or bowels) are cut from the intensity of fear. If the owls neighbor the falcons, their buttocks are cut. And the hawk is not frightened if it dives from above... By the shouting of the crane screaming from below. The hawk is not frightened by the shouting of the crane. If there is enmity between the two she-camels... Then woe to the bug from the urgent killing. Woe to the bug from the enmity of the two she-camels.

Two camels, this one does not stand out of stupidity... And this is difficult, not kneeling for the saddle. One of the two camels does not stand from its stupidity, and the other does not kneel for its difficulty. Lo, indeed the sheep is only hung by its leg... So what is the matter with people I do not bear their burdens? Every sheep is hung by its leg. Leave me and my caution of matters I tested... For the stung one may fear the sparkle of the rope. Whoever the speckled snake bit fears the piebald rope. Whoever walks in the trace of the lion, his kebab increases... And the harm of drought is not upon the neighbor of the Prince. Whoever follows the lion to the den eats his Tabahajah (meat dish) the fat wild ass. And an old woman whose little broth spilled said... Lo, welcome to dry bread without work. The old woman's broth spilled, so she was content with dry bread. And how many a washer of his palms attained his lunch... From people, who did not wet his palms with washing. Indeed, he eats his lunch who provides him, not who washes his hand. And how many a donkey went seeking a horn... And returned without an ear, and that was of stupidity. The donkey went out seeking two horns, and returned without two ears. And from a magpie that desired the walk of a partridge... So it forgot its walk and did not walk like the partridge. The magpie wanted to imitate the walk of the partridge, so it forgot its walk and did not take the walk of another. And many a wolf passed by the people hungry... So they said: Shortness of breath overcame him from excessive eating. Many a hungry wolf is accused of fullness. And a wolf whom preachers called to repentance... Said: The sheep escape, stop the blame. The wolf was asked to repent, so he said: Leave me, let not the sheep escape me. And every dust that rose from the walking of a flock... That is better for the wolf's eye than kohl. The dust of sheep is better for the wolf's eye than kohl. If the dog could desire a resting place... Other than the basket full of bread and snacks. If the dog could, he would not rest except in the full basket. And you are but a mouse whose hole narrowed... So it tied to itself the bundles from a thick broom. The mouse's hole did not fit it, so it accompanied a broom. You see vinegar as sharp when water is scarce... And in the opposite is the weakness of the thing and strength in the shape. Vinegar where there is no water is sour. Do you see the mote in the eye of another... And neglect the stump obstructing your eyes?
