Do you see the mote in your brother's eye and not see the pebble in your eye? Leave searching and digging for every hidden thing... If you attained herbs, be distracted from the place of growth of herbs. Eat the herbs and do not ask about the vegetable garden. And hasten to catch the thief before his hastening... To catch you, and be sure of the dirty thief. Catch the thief before he catches you. And couple the donkey with your palfrey if it weakens... From the enemy, it takes from its manners nobility. Tie the donkey with the palfrey, if it does not take from its running, it takes from its character.

Chapter on Descriptions and Similes
"Section on Untying the Saying of Ibn al-Mu'tazz describing the Crescent"
Welcome to a Fitr (breaking fast) whose crescent has shone... Now, so go early to the wine and come early. And look at it like a boat of silver... Burdened by a load of ambergris. "And the saying of the other describing it" O Reem (gazelle), rise now, woe to you, and look... At the face of the crescent when it appeared in the East. Like a female friend (Khalilah) who looked at a male friend (Khalil) of hers... So she veiled herself in shame with a blue sleeve. "And the saying of Kushajim describing it also" Welcome and hello to the crescent... It appeared to the eye of the seer. Like a grain of barley of silver... Mounted on a dagger. "And the saying of Ibn al-Mu'tazz" And the crescent of Shawwal, its light shines... And the Daughters of Na'sh (Ursa Major) stood opposite it. Like the fingertip of a sincere one when he saw... The face of the Vizier, he prayed for the length of his survival. Welcome to a Fitr whose East has raised its crescent, and the East was adorned with it. As if it is the face of a beautiful, morning-like female friend, who was ashamed of her friend so she veiled herself, and with the blue sleeve she covered her face. Or as if it is a boat of silver full of ambergris. Or a grain of barley of silver mounted on a dagger. Or the finger of a sincere one in loyalty to our Master the Prince, the Master, the Just King, the Patron of Blessings, Khwarazm Shah - may Allah strengthen his victory - when he saw in his face the two moons, and in his person the two weights (Jinn and Mankind). He prayed to Allah for the length of his survival, the continuity of his blessings, and the suppression of his enemies. So greetings now to the wine, and the morning faces, from morning to morning. And drink to the Ma'muni state which is the state of auspiciousness. And thanks to the Khwarazm Shahi days which are the days of beauties. May Allah perpetuate them as long as the crescent shines and the appearance of the new moon repeats. "Another on the Saying of Ibn al-Mu'tazz regarding the Morning and the Pleiades" O my two friends, give me drink... Coffee possessing intoxication.

The night has turned away from us... And the morning folded it a folding. And as if the morning when... It loomed from under the Pleiades. Is a King who approached in the... Crown, ransomed and greeted. The morning drink, O my two friends, the morning drink! May blessings never cease to come to you and go. Do you not see the night turned back and retreated, and the curtain of darkness was torn? The morning folded the darkness just as the King Khwarazm Shah - may Allah perpetuate his kingdom - folds his enemies. And spread the robe of light just as our Master - may Allah strengthen his victory - spreads his brilliance and light. What does the morning resemble, with the Pleiades above it, except our Master the King - may Allah perpetuate his state and highness - with the crown of highness upon him. He is ransomed and greeted. So give me drink to the mention of his high qualities, and delight me with poetry in which Al-Tha'alibi came. Suffice me with that as superior singing and pleasing, yearning hearing. Farewell.

"A Note on Untying the Saying of the Other describing the Oud and the Songstress"
And making an Oud speak with a lightened stick (plectrum)... It would have been, were it not for that, non-speaking. Moved by a palm whose fingertips seem... Tubes of pearls collared with carnelian. "And the saying of the other" And as if it is in her lap a child of hers... She embraced it between upper chest and breast. At times she tickles his belly, and if he erred... She rubbed for him an ear of the ears. I have, my master - may I be your ransom - a songstress who brings down fortunes. When she makes the Oud speak with a light Oud, good of dancing. Moved by a palm whose fingertips are in proportion to verification. Tubes of pearls capped with carnelian. The Oud in her lap resembles nothing but a child she beds her breast. She tickles his belly, and if he errs, she rubs his ear. Her hearing refused to be pleasant except with your presence. Just as our joy swore not to be complete except with your joy. If you see to allocate for us a share in your nearness which is the nourishment of the soul and the substance of intimacy, you will have done so, God willing.

"Another on Untying the Saying of the Other describing the Narcissus"
As if she applied kohl to an eye with his eye... And as if his leaves are papers. "And the saying of the other describing the Citron" A body of silver whose shirt is gold... Compounded in a wondrous composition. In it for the one who smells it and sees it... Is the color of a lover and the scent of a beloved. "And the saying of the other regarding the Bitter Orange" It glances at us among the branches as if it is... Breasts of virgins touched by perfume (Khaluq). "And the saying of Ibn al-Rumi regarding the Violet" And lazurite ones fulfilling with their blueness... Amidst the gardens upon red rubies. As if they are above layers slapped with them... The beginnings of fire in the tips of sulfur. I am, my master and lord - may Allah prolong your survival - in a gathering like a sample of Paradise. Around me is narcissus whose leaf is like paper and whose eye is like the eye. And citron wearing the shirt of gold over the body of silver, combining the color of the yearning lover with the scent of the beloved adored. And bitter orange as if it is balls of gilded leather, or breasts of veiled, saffron-perfumed virgins. And violet exceeding red rubies and imitating the beginnings of fire in sulfur. The sun of jars has risen, and the stars of drinking companions have appeared, and the tongues of lutes have spoken. If you favor by attending, you will share with us in joy, God Almighty willing.

"Another on Untying the Saying of Ibn al-Rumi describing a Chicken and Qata'if (Pancakes)"
And a scalded one, yellow, dinar-like in price... And color, Hazu (luck?) brought it to you. We remained peeling its skin from its meat... As if gold is peeled from silver. And Qata'if came after that, subtleties... The uvula is pleased with them and the throat is pleased. Faces laughed from the sugar (Tabarazad) over them... Tears of eyes are squeezed from the fats. What is your say, my master - may Allah make me your ransom - regarding a chicken dripping with ghee, dinar-like in color and price? If you extend the hand to its fresh sides, you peel gold from silver. Followed by subtle Qata'if, freshly made, thin of crust, thick of stuffing. Laughing from the crushed sugar, weeping from the pounded almond oil. Paying the taste of wellness and concluding with the good outcome. Will you be active for it and please me by helping with it? God Almighty willing.

"Another on the Saying of Al-Buhturi describing the Cloud"
Possessing rumbling with the yearning of thunder... Dragging the tail, truthful of promise. Shedding tears without passion... Having a breeze like the breeze of the rose. And a ring like the roar of the lion... And a flash of lightning like the swords of India. The wind of the East brought it from Najd... So it scattered like the scattering of a necklace. And the earth went with a luxurious life... As if its streams in the low land. Were playing with Backgammon from its bubbles.

My master and lord - may Allah prolong your survival - do you not see this cloud, how its tails dragged, and its approach announced fertility? Its thunderers rumbled and its promises came true. Its tears overflowed without passion. Its breeze is like the breeze of the organized rose, its ring like the roar of lions, and its lightning like the flashing of swords between rows. When the wind of the East brought it, and it imitated in its goodness the ornament of youth, its necklace was untied and its contract scattered. It imitated the palm of our Master the King, the Patron of Blessings, Khwarazm Shah - may Allah perpetuate his kingdom - in its overflowing with gifts and its generosity with connections and presents. So the earth went with the most auspicious ascendant and happiest, and the most pleasant life and most comfortable. As if the streams play Backgammon with its bubbles, and the cloud weeps longing for its loved ones. Since we have been watered from the pouring downpour, give us drink from the water of grapes, and gather for us the reunion of amusement and mirth.

"Another on Untying the Saying of Ahmad ibn Sulayman ibn Wahb regarding the Cypress"
Surrounded by Cypress like songstresses dressed... In green silk on a moderate stature. As if they, while the wind struts among them... Intend embracing, then shyness prevents them. "And the saying of Ibn al-Mu'tazz regarding the Narcissus" As if the eyes of the fresh narcissus around us... Are vessels of pearls whose stuffing is carnelian. If the drops wet them, I thought their tears... The weeping of eyes whose kohl is perfume (Khaluq). We, our master - may Allah prolong your survival - are in a garden surrounded by cypress lined up like the statures of loved ones in green clothes. As if they, while the wind struts in them, swaying and bending them, intend embracing and holding, and want joining and healing. Shyness prevents them, and fear repels them. Around us are eyes of narcissus imitating vessels of pearls whose stuffing is carnelian. If the drops wet them, their tears imitate the weeping of eyes whose kohl is perfume. The beauty of the place and the goodness of the time have called for seeking support against sorrows with the daughters of jars. They are not pure except with meeting you. So do not muddy by your delay, and burden your foot to us, and bestow your generosity upon us. God willing.

"Another on Untying the Saying of Abu Bakr al-Khawarizmi regarding Perfume"
And perfume that does not betray every perfume... Greets us with the breaths of the beloved. The tail remains covering it but... The buttons of pockets tell on it. Whenever a nose smells it, a heart yearns... As if the nose is the spy of hearts. My master - may Allah prolong his survival - narrates in the Sunnah which is all good and blessing, that gifts are shared. Gifted to me is perfume, superior, wondrous, which imitates the breaths of the beloved. Rather, as if it is kneaded from the morals of our Master the Supported King Khwarazm Shah - may Allah strengthen his victory - or as if it is the good praise on his days, shining with his beneficence and favoring. So I shared with my master - may Allah perpetuate his support - in his good trace and good news. I sent of it what, if it prays to the fire of the incense burner, breathes the scent of Paradise. And if the tails cover it, the pockets tell on it, spirits find rest in it, and hearts yearn. He - may Allah perpetuate his glory - pleases me by accepting it, and signs to me its receipt. God Almighty willing.

"Another on Untying the Saying of Al-Sanawbari"
Gild your cups, O boy... For it is a silvered day. And the atmosphere reveals in whiteness... And in the ornaments of pearls it displays. Do you think this snow and this... Roses on the branches being shaken? The rose of spring is colored... And the rose in Kanun (winter) is white. This, my master - may Allah perpetuate your glory - is a silvered day, and gilding cups in it is obligatory. Do you not see the atmosphere revealing and displaying in whiteness, and pearls in ornaments? So do not think it snow, for it is shaken on the branches. The rose is white in Kanun as it is colored in Nisan. Since the necklace of the sky has untied, let the necklace of drinking companions be organized. You, my master, are the central jewel of the necklace, and the first of the knot. So favor and hasten, and do not delay. God Almighty willing.

"Another on Untying the Saying of Al-Sahib"
The atmosphere approached in robes of light... And gifted scattered pearls. As if the sky became an in-law to the earth... And the scattering became of camphor. This, my master - may Allah prolong your survival - is a day whose air approached in robes of light and came to us with scattered pearls. Until as if the sky became an in-law to the earth, and scattered for it pure camphor. So scatter upon us joy with your countenance, and assist us with your help, on what we resolved of mounting the vehicles of joy, and striking the fire of mirth with the cup. God willing.

Chapter
Nayrouz and Mehregan

"A Letter on Untying the Saying of the Professor Abu Bakr al-Khawarizmi from a Poem"
O King who fulfilled with his ambition... Over the worries of the kings of the earth and ambitions. Be happy with the rising of this Nayrouz and note it... For it will not stay for a creature and has not stayed. A day of Time, an old man in his youth... And renewed, and what comes of the ancient. Kisra used to, if it came to him, make it judge... Over his mind, and he is the worst of who judged in it. An old man visited by an old man, so he shook hands with him... With the cup and the bowl and the strings and the tunes. A new day and a kingdom fresh... And sobriety between them is a type of madness.

May Allah make our Master the Supported King, the Patron of Blessings, Khwarazm Shah, whose ambition fulfilled the high ambitions of all nations, happy with this new season and praiseworthy Nayrouz. Which is, despite its youth, an old Sheikh of ancient attribution, and despite his old age, a youth of recent birth. Kisra used to revere it if it came to him, and honor it if it arrived. He placed it in the place of the dearest comer, and made it judge over his mind while it is the worst judge. Oh what an old Sheikh, who used to visit a generous Sheikh. So he shook hands with him with wine, took off for him the clothes of dignity, and treated him kindly with tunes and strings. Our Master - may Allah perpetuate his kingdom - is the inheritor of Kings; Allah inherited him their ages, lands, and homes. So what is upon him if he preserved the Kisraic customs as he preserves the Hanifite Sharia? To seek help with jest for seriousness, and with falsehood for truth, and rest sometimes from the bitterness of policies to the sweetness of intimacies. May Allah combine for him the benefits of religion and the world, as He combined for him the characteristics of glory and highness. "Section on Untying the Saying of Al-Buqri the Scribe"
You burned with blackness the silver of his cheek... Indeed you burned the core (blackness) of hearts.
"And the saying of the other"
I was hoping that when he grows a beard... It would lighten my sorrows and bring me patience.

"And the saying of the other"

You asked me - may Allah support you - about the human who possessed my rein when the heart was empty, and acquired my affection while youth was dyeing. Take the news and know that when I burned with hair the silver of his cheek, the core of my heart burned from his love. "Another on Untying the Saying of the Other, Al-Bassami"
O you whose beard announced his death to the brothers... You turned back while people are between approach and retreat.

Days when your face was polished of cheek-hairs... And for spring on your cheeks were lights.

O you who died while alive, and lived while being nothing. Hair has announced your death to your brothers, and copied (abrogated) the verse of your beauty with your friends. So you turned back while people are between approach and retreat, and were clothed in two robes of disgrace and ruin. You were of those for whom the observer smiles and to whom thoughts attach. Eyes choked before you since hair transformed your beauty, and hearts turned away from you when Time changed your state. I do not forget but the intimacy of your days, while Paradise is picked from your nearness, the water of beauty ripples in your face, and the lights of spring are dependent on your cheek. So now when your death approached, your wish failed, the shade of life vanished from you, and you became a pledge of passing, and your cheek-hair blackened just as the houses of the dead blacken. Farewell.

"In the name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful"

"Then this" book is light in size, heavy in weight, small in body, large in gain. Regarding Metonymies (Kinayat) for what is reprehensible to mention, ugly to publish, or shy to name, or taken as bad omen, or elevated and protected from. With acceptable words that convey the meaning, articulate the intent, beautify the ugly, soften the dense, and clothe it in elegant exhibition. In addressing Kings, corresponding with the modest, discussing with people of virtue, and conversing with those of chivalry and wit. So the desire is obtained and success looms, with turning away from what the hearing recoils from and nature is not intimate with, to what stands in its place and substitutes for it, of speech the ear permits and the heart does not block. That is only from eloquence in souls, characteristics of rhetoric, results of skill, and subtleties of craft. I see myself not preceded in authoring its like, arranging its resemblance, and setting its jewels. From the Book of Allah, the news of the Prophet, peace be upon him, the speech of the predecessors, the necklaces of poets, the texts of the eloquent, and the anecdotes of the witty. In types of prose and verse, and arts of seriousness and jest. I had authored it in Nishapur in the year four hundred. The High Tongue - may Allah perpetuate his highness - mentioned it, and the Obeyed Command - may Allah perpetuate his elevation - issued to send a copy of it to the Populated Treasury - may Allah perpetuate its honor. I created it another creation, cast it a second time after the first, verified its categorization and arrangement, and excelled in its refinement and gilding. I titled it "The Book of Metonymy and Allusion" (Kitab al-Kinaya wa al-Ta'rid), and honored it with the High Name - may Allah establish it as long as days and nights last. I brought it out in seven chapters, each chapter containing several sections titled with their subjects.
"The First Chapter" on Metonymy regarding Women and Harem, and what occurs with them and connects to their mention of all their affairs and conditions. Its sections are five.
"The Second Chapter" on mentioning Boys and those who speak of them, and Metonymy regarding their descriptions and conditions. Its sections are five.
"The Third Chapter" on Metonymy regarding some waste of food and the place prepared for it. Its sections are four.
"The Fourth Chapter" on Metonymy regarding uglinesses and disabilities. Its sections are twelve.
"The Fifth Chapter" on Metonymies regarding illness, greyness, old age, and death. Its sections are eight.
"The Sixth Chapter" regarding what time and condition necessitate of Metonymy regarding food and drink and what connects to them, in two sections.
"The Seventh Chapter" on various arts of Metonymy and Allusion, different in arrangement. Its sections are seven.
Here I am opening its context and fulfilling its rights and conditions with the help of Allah Almighty and the state of our Master the King, the Master, the Patron of Blessings, Khwarazm Shah - may Allah establish it and perpetuate it.

"In the name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful"
"Chapter One.. On Metonymy regarding Women and Harem, and what occurs with them and connects to their mention of all their affairs and conditions"
"Section on Metonymy regarding the Woman"

The Arabs use metonymy for a woman with Ewe (Na'jah), Sheep (Shah), Young She-Camel (Qalus), Sarha Tree, Tillage (Harth), Bed (Firash), Threshold ('Atabah), Flask (Qarura), Basket (Qawsara), Sandal (Na'l), Shackle (Ghull), Fetter (Qayd), Shade (Zullah), and Neighbor (Jarah). Reports have come and poems have spoken with all of them.
"As for" metonymy with Ewe, the Quran clarified it in the story of David, peace be upon him: "Indeed this, my brother, has ninety-nine ewes, and I have one ewe," meaning a woman.
"As for" metonymy with Sheep, it is as Antara al-Absi said: "O sheep, not hunted for one to whom she is lawful... Forbidden to her guardian, she was not forbidden." He used metonymy for a woman and said: What a prey you are for one for whom it is lawful to hunt you. As for me, the sanctity of neighborhood has forbidden you to me.
"As for" metonymy with Young She-Camel, it is as a man from a raid he was in wrote to Umar bin Al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him, advising him regarding his women: "Lo, convey to Abu Hafs a message... May my trusted brother ransom you, my wrapper. Our young she-camels, may Allah guide you, we have been... Occupied from you (them) in the time of siege."
"As for" metonymy with Sarha, which is a tree, it is as Humayd bin Thawr said: "Allah refused except that the Sarha of Malik... Over all the branches of the 'Idah (thorny trees) pleases." He used metonymy for Malik's wife with Malik's Sarha, the best metonymy, and expressed her perfection in beauty over all women with the best expression. One who said (the following) followed his path in this metonymy: "I have no sin against them that I knew... Except that I said: O Sarha, peace. Yes, then peace, then peace, then peace... Three greetings, even if you do not speak." Such metonymy occurs regarding one whom they do not dare to name or blame themselves for declaring her name, as the poet said: "And I use metonymy for Qadhur with other than her... And I express clearly sometimes with her, so I declare."
"As for Tillage", from it is the saying of the poet, casting it in the way of riddles: "If locusts ate the tillages of a people... Then the eating of locusts saddened me with worry." He means by his tillage a woman. In the Quran: "Your women are a tillage for you."
"As for Bed", Allah Almighty said in describing Paradise: "And beds (surur/women) raised." Meaning women. Do you not see Him saying after it: "Indeed, We have produced them into a creation. And made them virgins."? It is narrated about some of them that he said to a man who wanted to marry: "Thicken your bed," meaning choose the plump of women.
"As for" the Threshold, it is in the story of Abraham, peace be upon him. He visited his son Ishmael, peace be upon him, so his presence coincided with his absence from the house. His wife came to him and informed him of his state, and did not offer him hospitality. He said to her: "Say to my son that your father sends you peace and orders you to change your threshold." When Ishmael, peace be upon him, returned and the woman told him the story and delivered the message, he divorced her immediately in compliance with his father's command, because his saying "Change your threshold" is a metonymy for divorcing her and replacing her.
"As for" metonymy with Flask, it is from the saying of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, to the driver of the camels on which were his wives: "Gently with the flasks."
"As for metonymy" with Basket (Qawsara), from it is the saying of the Rajiz poet: "Successful is he who has a basket... He eats from it every day once."
"As for the Sandal", from it is the saying of Umar, may Allah Almighty be pleased with him: "The woman is a sandal the man wears if he wishes, not if she wishes."
"As for the Shackle", from it is the saying of some wise men of the Arabs mentioning women: "Among them is the loving, the fertile, the sitting. And among them is a shackle Allah places on the neck of whom He wills and unties from whom He wills."
"As for the Fetter", from it is the saying of Abu al-Hasan al-Jawhari al-Jurjani from a poem regarding Al-Sahib, mentioning his preparation to march to his presence and using metonymy for divorcing his wife: "My steed is before me and my tail tucked up... And my heart from longing comes and goes. I was hobbled by my family, fettered... And here I am from that hobble released." Mentioning divorce, I approve and find very witty what Ibn al-Amid wrote in metonymy for the oath of some kings by divorce, which is his saying in a section of a letter: "He swore an oath in which he named his free women (wives)."
"As for the Shade (Zullah)", it is with some Kufans a wife, and with some metonymic. Likewise Al-Halilah (Wife). He recites: "And I am in need of the death of my shade... But the chattel of evil remains, long-lived."
"As for the Neighbor", Al-A'sha says in it: "O our neighbor, leave, for you are divorced."
"Of the beneficence" of Al-Mutanabbi, the famous, is his saying to Sayf al-Dawla when he attacked Banu Kilab and captured their women then returned them to them: "If the Prince captured dogs (Kilab - pun on tribe name)... The fog prevented him from their suns."

He used metonymy for women with Suns, and for protection before them with Fog. The Arabs also use metonymy for women with Fawns (Ju'dhur), Gazelles (Ziba'), Oryx (Maha), and Cows (Baqar).
"Al-Nu'man" bin al-Mundhir used this metonymy and his blood was in it. That is because he had wronged Zaid bin Adi when he killed his father Adi bin Zaid. Zaid was the translator of King Parviz. He used to wait for calamities for Al-Nu'man and seek disasters for him. When he knew the King's inclination to women, he described Al-Nu'man's daughters to him and advised him to propose to them, knowing his refusal to marry non-Arabs due to the pride in his soul. He sent a messenger to him for the proposal. Al-Nu'man said: "Does not the King have sufficiency with the cows of Iraq from these black Bedouin women?" Zaid translated this phrase into Persian, uglified the meaning, and worsened the presence. He said: "He insults the King with the nickname Cows." Parviz ordered Al-Nu'man brought and thrown to the elephants, so they trampled him with their feet and finished him off.
Among what has no end to its beauty is the metonymy of the Prophet, peace be upon him, for the beautiful woman in the bad origin: "Beware of the greenness of the dung (Khadra' al-Diman)."

"Section on Metonymies for the Harem"
"When" Abu al-Hasan Khumarawayh bin Tulun, Governor of Egypt, transferred his daughter named Qatr al-Nada to Al-Mu'tadid, he wrote to him reminding him of the sanctity of her predecessor with his predecessor, describing what befalls her of the pomp of the Caliphate, the awe of the Sultan, and the loneliness of estrangement, asking him to comfort her, make her happy, and draw her near. The Vizier Ubayd Allah bin Sulayman wanted to answer the letter in his handwriting. He asked Ja'far bin Muhammad bin Thawabah to rely on him in the answer. He did so. Ja'far bin Muhammad wrote a letter in which he said in a section: "As for the Trust (Wadi'ah) - may Allah strengthen you - she is in the status of what transferred from your left hand to your right hand, out of our stinginess with her, guarding of her, and observance of your affection in her." When he showed it to the Vizier Ubayd Allah, he was very pleased with it and said to him: "Your metonymy for her with 'The Trust' is half of eloquence." He signed for him an increase in his stipends and fiefs.
"When it was" the days of Izz al-Dawla bin Mu'izz al-Dawla, and he transferred his daughter to Umdat al-Dawla Abu Tha'lab al-Hamdani, Abu Ishaq al-Sabi wrote on his behalf to Abu Tha'lab a letter which the people of the craft approved and memorized this section from, for its inclusion of several subtle metonymies. Its copy: "And Abu al-Najm Badr al-Harami has headed - and he is the trustee over what he observes, the loyal in what he guards - towards you, O my master and lord - may Allah perpetuate your glory - with the Trust. She has only transferred from a homeland to a dwelling, from a planting place to a wedding place, and from a shelter of nurture and kindness to a dwelling of dignity and favors. She is a piece of me obtained by you, and a fruit from the harvest of my heart separated to you. He has not separated from me who connected his rope to your rope, chose for him your brilliant virtue, settled him in the spacious home of your beautiful characteristics, and dwelled him in the vast protection of your noble nature and oddities. There is no loss upon what your trust contains and your maintenance encompasses."
The author of the book said: Ibn al-Amid, Al-Sahib, Al-Sabi, and Abd al-Aziz bin Yusuf - who are the eloquent of the age and unique ones of the time - often use metonymy for the daughter with 'The Noble One' (Karima), for the young girl with 'The Basil' (Rayhana), for the mother with 'The Free' (Hurra) and 'The Pious' (Barra), for the sister with 'The Full Sister' (Shaqiqa), for the wife with 'The Great of the House' (Kabirat al-Bayt), for the harem with 'Who is behind the curtain', and for the wedding with 'Uniting the gathering' and 'Connecting the rope'. If I wrote the sections containing these metonymies, the breath of the chapter would extend. In what I presented of these points is sufficiency.
"And told me" Abu al-Nasr Muhammad bin Abd al-Jabbar al-Utbi. He said: When the mother of Emir Al-Radi Abu al-Qasim Nuh ibn Mansur died, my uncle Abu al-Nasr al-Utbi needed to correspond with the Presence for condolence for her. He did not approve of the word 'Mother' and 'Parent' in mentioning her. So he wrote a letter in a section of which he said: "The effectiveness of Allah's decree regarding the one whose survival made the Inhabited House the ascent of accepted supplications and the descent of hoped-for blessings has knocked on ears." The scribes of the Presence approved it and memorized it.

"Section on Metonymy for the Private Part of the Woman"
Abu al-Qasim al-Rasuri recited to me for some Arabs:
"And if the noble wastes the request of his nose... Or his wife for a hateful thing, he does not get angry."
"The Arabs" say that the fetus, when its days are complete in the womb and wants to exit from it, seeks with its nose the place from which it exits. Professor Abu Bakr al-Tabari said to me: Look how this poet was subtle in his deletion for the metonymy for the mother's vagina with his saying "request of his nose".
"The meaning" of the verse is that a man, when he does not protect the vagina of his mother or his wife, does not get angry at anything done to him after that.
Al-Sahib said in his treatise titled 'Alerting to the faults of Al-Mutanabbi's poetry': Poets used to describe wrappers (Ma'azir) and use them as metonymy for what is behind them, purifying their words from what is hideous to mention, until this naturally gifted poet stepped to declaration which no one else was guided to. He said: "I, despite my fondness for what is in her veil... Am chaste from what is in her trousers."

Much fornication is better than this chastity.
"Among what" is approved for Al-Hajjaj is his saying to the mother of Abd al-Rahman ibn Muhammad ibn al-Ash'ath: "You intended the money of Allah and placed it under your tail," because he hated to say "under your butt" as the commoners say, fearing he might have risked, as Abdullah ibn al-Zubayr was faulted when he said to the wife of Abdullah bin Hazim: "Bring out the money that is under your butt." She said: "I did not think anyone took charge of anything of Muslims' affairs and would speak with this." Some of those present said: "Do you not see the hidden divorce (Khul') she alluded to?"
"Abu Mansur al-Azhari said" regarding the Prophet's prohibition, peace be upon him, of approaching women in their "Mahash" (places of collection/backsides), that it is a metonymy for their anuses, and its origin is from "Hash" (garden/privy).
"Al-Jahiz said" regarding the saying of Allah, Great and Glorious is His Name: "And those who guard their private parts (Furuj)." And His saying: "And Maryam, the daughter of Imran, who guarded her private part (Farj)," that it is a metonymy for the Awrah (private part). When it became frequent in speech, some commentators said it needs a metonymy. So he said regarding His saying Almighty: "And they said to their skins: Why did you testify against us?" that it is a metonymy for private parts. As if he did not know that the skin speaking is the most wondrous wonder. Had it been so, He would have said when mentioning private parts: "And those who guard their skins," and would have said: "And Maryam, the daughter of Imran, who guarded her skin."
"The Jurists narrated" that Rifa'a divorced his wife, and she married a man called Abd al-Rahman ibn al-Zubayr - with Fatha on Zay and Kasra on Ba - then she complained of him to the Prophet, peace be upon him, and said: "What is with him is like the fringe of a garment." The Prophet, peace be upon him, said: "Do you want to return to Rifa'a? No, until you taste his little honey ('Usaylah) and he tastes your little honey." Look at the subtlety of this speech, its abundant luster, and its beautiful metonymy for the private part and intercourse with 'Usaylah, which is the diminutive of 'Asal (Honey). It is masculine and feminine. Those who denied its femininity went to say it is the diminutive of 'Asalah (a portion of honey). It is said 'Asalah and 'Asal, just as Tamrah (a date) and Tamr (dates) are said.
"Of the rare" metonymy and its good ones is the saying of Abu Hakima Rashid bin Ishaq the Scribe in his art for which he was famous, from a poem: "Then, there is no good with you to be hoped... O penis of little benefit. Long did you knock down the knights of war... And conquered the impregnable fortress. And stormed the Matamir (dungeons/silos) of passion... And this is the wine, and the dark-eyed fawn has startled us... With his appearance. So hasten with him and with us a drunkenness... The causes of what I ask become easy. For I saw he has a forelock... Indicating that 'He Does' (Yaf'al - passive/active sexual role implication)."

I was recited for Al-Hasan al-Marwazi the Blind regarding a Christian boy: "I do not forget, I do not forget the fawn of the church... Wanting the church from his house. O beauty of what is above his buttons... And O goodness of what is under his belt (Zunnar)."
Al-Sari al-Mawsili wrote to a friend of his, Surayyah, on the Day of Doubt, describing what he had of amusements: "On the morning of Doubt we invite you... To the wine, take it early. And I have a songstress who gives you... The pearls of speech from her mouth. If she tickles the Oud... You think it is conversing with her. And wine crowned with perfume... From the breaths of its cupbearer. And roses like the cheeks of soft girls... Imitating it and it imitating them. And an 'Alaq' (boy) carrying the banner... We do not cheat nor camouflage."
"For Al-Sahib": "Indeed Ibn Masrur is a scribing youth... Taking a pen from every friend. Beautiful of appearance, possessor of a sign... Among the most skillful people in carrying the flag."
For some contemporaries from the people of Nishapur: "I sent in describing a friend of ours... A truth written with gold. In beauty a peacock, but he is... More prostrating in seclusion than a hoopoe."
I have not heard better or more innovative than the saying of Abu al-Hasan al-Jawhari al-Jurjani to some notables, seeking means to him by his service in his boyhood, and using metonymy for the meaning with the subtlest metonymy: "Lo, O elevated King... Grant me of your abundant gifts. Your slave has a sanctity, and mentioning (it) is obscene... So do not necessitate mentioning the means."
Of what is deemed salty for Al-Matrani al-Bashi is what he wrote to a friend of his whom he saw having a boy: "I saw a fawn circling in your sanctuary... Singing, familiar with your generosity. It made me covet regarding him that he is a fawn... Bribing to cover, and is not of your servants. So occupy him for an hour when... His inkwell is empty, if you see, from your pen."
Of the pleasant metonymy for the handsome, not bulky boy is the saying of Al-Jammaz: "This fawn of yours, his face is beautiful... And what is other than that is all faulted. So understand my speech, O my brother, a sentence... The address does not resemble what is in the book."
And for another in his meaning, granted to me: "O Sahl, a witty one... His enchanting glances tempt me. Whatever you wish of world (Dunya), but he is... A hypocrite, you do not have his Hereafter (Akhirah - pun on rear)."
In similar to that, wits said in prose: "There is nothing behind Abadan but wood." Abu Nasr bin al-Marzuban put it into verse and said: "O gazelle whose face... Like the full moon reveals darknesses. I tasted from his mouth and from... His kiss the water of life. I have nothing after Abadan... Except the wood."
I heard some commoners say in Persian describing a boy taking from his rear and spending on his front: "So-and-so melts the tail-fat on the fat." Then I heard some commoners say in that: "So-and-so spends from his basin on his pitcher."
"It reached me" that the postmasters in Nishapur wrote to the Presence in Bukhara reporting what occurred between some Sheikhs there and one of the Turkish commanders. He said in recounting that: "And he said to him: O Mu'ajir (rented one/prostitute)." When the Vizier of the time looked at this word, he disapproved of it and considered it great, and dismissed the postmaster from his job. When he arrived in Bukhara and got into his council, he scolded him for that slip and rebuked him, saying: "Why did you not protect the Sultan's presence from such a dirty word?" He said: "May Allah support the majestic Sheikh, what should I write then, when I was ordered to report news as they are?" He said: "Were you unable, woe to you, to use metonymy for it and say: He cursed him with what youths are cursed with, or words conveying its meaning?"

"Section on Metonymy for what is taken from them"
Al-Mubarrad recounted saying: Sulayman bin Wahb used to write for Musa bin Bugha and loved a slave of Musa, seeing the world in him. Musa went out one day hunting, and with him was Abu al-Khattab the Scribe. A matter came upon him in which he needed Sulayman, so he ordered him summoned. Abu al-Khattab said to that boy: "Hasten to Sulayman and bring him." So he galloped to him. When he got before him, Sulayman was gentle with him until he attained what he loved from him, and rose with him to Musa's hunting place and obeyed his command. The next day, Abu al-Khattab wrote to him: "There is no good with me in the friend... Who sleeps while the friend (Khalil) is awake. A saying of non-ingratitude from one who saw... For every majestic favor. Will you thank me in the morning... For my gentleness for you regarding the messenger? When we were in the hunting of mountains... And you were in the hunting of plains."
The like of this metonymy is better than the metonymy of Ibn al-Rumi in his saying: "Is a handsome one preventing me my need... Whose character is hatred and obstinacy? For my need for him is only... The need of a rooster for a hen."

Verses by Ibn al-Mu'tazz passed in the utmost pleasantness, the last verse of which includes a very witty metonymy, which is: "And a fawn who corrupted my heart... After the goodness of its repentance. He was generous with the army of beauty in... His numbers and equipment. So repentance died when... He appeared with his awe. And Iblis came congratulating... My looking at his countenance. And he ceased not reminding me... Of my Lord and the pardon of His power. And said to me: What is a kiss... And other than it in His mercy?"
Mentioning the kiss, verses by Yunus al-Arudi were recited to me containing a subtle metonymy for what follows the kiss, which are: "I am, from your love O my master... In a terrifying, difficult plan. And you have permitted a kiss today... Observing in it the sanctity of companionship. As if I, when I attained it as a gap... Kissed the corner of the House (Kaaba) of the veil. And since I won kissing the Corner... How can I enter the Kaaba?"
Of the witty metonymy for the kiss is what Abu al-Fadl Abdullah bin Ahmad al-Mikali recited to me for Abdullah bin al-Najm: "Complaining to you of what... The skin found of treachery in you. Bewildered, if you wished, guided... Thirsty, if you wished, arrived (at water)."
Of the good metonymy for turning away from contact with women to thigthing with boys is the saying of some: "I do not ride the sea, but I... Seek Allah's provision on the coast."
The most innovative I heard in the meaning of Tightness and Width with the best metonymy and gentlest expression is what Abu Nasr Ahmad bin Akrid al-Zanjani recited to me for himself regarding his boy Yusuf: "Yusuf went from us with ninety dirhams... And returned with a third of the money in Yusuf's palm. So how is his reform hoped for after this... When two-thirds of his money was lost in disposal (Tasarruf - pun on spending/change)?"
The parallel of this story in the obscenity of meaning and purity of wording is what Abu Ja'far Muhammad bin Musa al-Musawi recited to me. He said: Muhammad bin Isa al-Damghani recited, not naming its sayer: "Remember when I sent him as a Pawn (Baydaq) (soldier)... Into you, so he met me as a Queen (Farzan)." From the borrowing of chess players, if a pawn of theirs becomes a queen on the board, they mark it with something to distinguish it from other pawns. This poet used metonymy for that thing that it entered clean and exited marked dirty.
"Of" the rare metonymy for coming to the boy is what Judge Abu Bakr al-Satti recited to me for Al-Sari al-Mawsili from verses: "I made my camel kneel in a tavern of Utrujjah... And how good is drunkenness in it as a resting place. Wine shakes hands with itself in it... And we sow offspring in it in the salt marshes (Sabakh)." Look how he used metonymy for sodomy with sowing in salt marshes that do not grow.
"Of" the famous that fits this section is the saying of some: "My soul fulfilled its wishes of everything... Except stabbing with the cucumber into the fig. I do not plant forever except in a balcony... And it is not permissible except under manure."
Abu al-Fath al-Busti recited to me for himself: "I ransom the gazelle who spoke to me in grammar... Debating, so I avoided the honey of his lip. And cited the accepted argument as witness... Verifying, to show me the virtue of his knowledge. Then we separated on an opinion I was pleased with... So the Nominative (Raf' - raising) is of my attribute and the Accusative (Nasb - setting up/erection) is of his attribute." Meaning he was the Subject (Fa'il) and the Subject is Nominative, and the Gazelle was the Object (Maf'ul bihi) Accusative.
For Abu Tammam in what is close to it: "I used to call you Abdullah before, for... I have become calling you Zaid without shame. You permitted generously what you used to prevent... Not every generosity of a youth invites to honor." "And for him": "What was in the bedroom of your affair... It is in the Congregational Mosque. O length of my thought about you from a carrier... Of a sheet with a broken seal."
As for the saying of Ibn al-Mu'tazz: "And he came to me in the shirt of night, hiding... Hurrying the step out of fear and caution. So I spent the night spreading my cheek on the road for him... In humiliation, and dragging my tails on the trace. And there was what was of what I do not mention... So think good and do not ask about the news." It is a metonymy for declaration.
Similar to it is for Abd al-Samad bin al-Mu'adhdhal: "And if souls blew yearningly... And the friend desired the nearness of the friend. There was what was between us, I do not name... It, but it is the cure of thirst."
For some people of the age, and the intent is the last verse:

"I pardoned my time for all its trifles... And counted the day of the rebellious as the highest of its gifts. And met trees there with a stature from which... The branch of the Ban tree was suspended from its movements. The rose of the garden is ashamed at his rising... And he dismisses it with the rose in his cheeks. The blossom of the chamomile prostrates to his mouth... And the scent of the rose falls short of his breaths. When the night darkened, he reclaimed the light of the forenoon... With a face gathering beauty, some of its attributes. Oh what a night, thin of darkness... Due to the union of the gathering of intimacy after its dispersion."
Of the bad of this section is the saying of some virtuous ones: "Indeed I, when my drunkenness came... And it was time for my siesta. I entered the finger of my belly... Into the eye of the back of my friend."
Of the good metonymy for thigthing is the saying of Abu Nuwas: "And a gazelle whose buttons the soul craves... To undo. The Surah of Al-Nas (Mankind) spread him... For us after his turning away. So we circled around him... And did not approach his house."

"Section on Metonymy for Sodomy and its People"
If a man speaks of (prefers) boys over women, it is said: So-and-so prefers land hunting over sea hunting. "So-and-so" speaks of gazelles and does not speak of fish. "And So-and-so" loves lambs and hates ewes. Abu Nuwas said: "I am a man who hates ewes, and... The lamb from their offspring amazes me."
So-and-so inclines to one who does not menstruate or lay eggs. The poet said: "May I be your ransom, we chose you only... Because you do not menstruate or lay eggs. If we inclined to the connection of songstresses... The wide land would narrow with our offspring."
So-and-so writes on backs. And So-and-so loves Mim (Male) and hates Sad (Female/Box?). "Ibn al-Rumi did evil" in his saying: "My hatred for Sad is famous, indeed I am a man... Whose affection is purer for the Hawamim (Mims). My hatred is not for a Quran, nor my loathing... Of it for Allah, but for Sad and Mim." "Another said": "For dotting the Sad, Allah satisfied Qudama... And Abdullah dots every Mim."
It is said So-and-so is of the Attarin (Perfumers), and Attar is a metonymy for the Kunnas (Sweeper/Scavenger) in many lands. Abu Ishaq al-Sabi said in dispraising sodomites: "For the need of a man in backs (Adbār) is turning back (Idbār)... And those returning to vaginas (Ahrah) are free (Ahrār). How many a clean, witty one spent the night riding... The back of a boy, so he became a perfumer (Attar)."
If he speaks of (prefers) hairless beardless boys, it is said his condition is the people of Paradise, because the Prophet, peace be upon him, said in describing them: "Hairless, beardless, kohl-eyed."
If he speaks of the small over the big, it is said So-and-so prefers kids (Sikhal) over rams. "It is narrated" that when Hammad Ajrad sat to educate the son of Al-Abbas bin Muhammad, Bashar bin Burd said: "Say to the Prince, may Allah reward him with good... Let not Time gather the kid and the wolf. The kid is deceived and the wolf's concern is his negligence... And the wolf knows what goodness is in the kid." "He also said": "O Abu al-Fadl, do not sleep... The wolf has fallen among the sheep. Indeed Hammad Ajrad... Is an evil Sheikh who has become aroused. Between his thighs is a spear... In a sheath of leather. And he, if he gets a chance... Wipes the Mim with the pen." When the verses spread, Al-Abbas ordered Hammad's expulsion. "Similar" to this slander is the saying of Abu Ishaq al-Sabi in a letter: "O Abu al-Fadl, listen... To the saying of a man who purifies love for you. The grazing of your boys has... Become for the wolf (Sirhan) a plunder."
Ibn Sakra al-Hashimi had a boy he used to take as a condition (lover). When he grew up, he expelled him from his house. He was asked about that. He said: "We left him, and in him was... For a lover, a cooing from a cook (Tabbakh). The cooing of the bird, and of... Our habits is eating chicks."
If a man speaks of small and big, it is said So-and-so hunts what is between the crane and the nightingale. "If he" speaks of adultery and sodomy both, it is said So-and-so hunts the two birds and grasps the two registers, and So-and-so is a pen with two heads. He recites: "Which inkwell his pen has not met... And which roof his ladder has not reached?"
If he comes and is come to (active/passive), it is said So-and-so is a quilt and a mattress, and So-and-so submits to Qisas (retaliation/equality), so at times a roof and at times a floor. "If he" speaks of the beauty of face without bulkiness, it is said he speaks of the World (Dunya) without the Hereafter (Akhirah). "If he speaks of both together, it is said he speaks of the Hereafter and does not forget his share of the World." "If the boy combines" these two qualities, it is said he is World and Hereafter. "If he is" handsome, not bulky, it is said he is a hypocrite, and his mention has preceded.

"Section on Metonymy for the Appearance of the Beard, in Praise and Dispraise"
Abu Nuwas used to say: "Provision yourselves with a pleasure not found in Paradise," using metonymy for coming to those with cheek-hair, because the people of Paradise are all hairless and beardless. "In the book" Lubab al-Adab: So-and-so, the hand of beauty has enveloped him, and burned the silver of his cheek and embroidered the brocade of his face. "Of" the best I lecture with in metonymy for the line of the beard is the saying of some Muwallads (post-classical poets): "A book from Beauty, its signature... From Allah, on his cheek has descended." How witty is what Al-Sahib used as metonymy for it with "fuzz of beauty" in his saying: "Does the fuzz of beauty harm him... While the full moon by him is moon-struck?" Badi' al-Zaman recited to me for himself from verses: "Be as you wish, for I... Have forged a heart of iron. And I sat waiting for the eclipse... And that is not far." He used eclipse as metonymy for the appearance of the beard, as the other said: "Alas for a full moon that has been eclipsed... Sorrowfully, and does sorrow avail?" Of the innovative and hidden metonymy in this section is the saying of Judge Abu al-Hasan Ali bin Abd al-Aziz: "Love has tormented your yearner... So give him the best of your morals. Do not shun him and observe his right... For he is the last of your lovers." He uses metonymy for the nearing of the beard's appearance or its appearance, and that he has no lover after it.

"The Third Chapter on Metonymy for some Waste of Food and the Place Prepared for it"
"Section in its Introduction"
I read in "Al-Mustanir" that Yahya bin Ziyad, Muti' bin Iyas, and Hammad Ajrad gathered in a session enjoying themselves, and with them was a man who was their boon companion. A wind with sound exited from him, so he was ashamed and did not return to them. One of them wrote to him: "Is it from a young she-camel that left, no one harmed her... Except she reminded her of homelands in the sand? Her shackle betrayed her, so she erupted when she grunted... And the sin in it is only upon the one who betrayed. You granted us from you abandonment and hate... And were absent from us three (days), you do not cover us (visit). Ease upon yourself, for there is no one among people... But his she-camels escape sometimes."
Similar happened to a slave girl singing in a gathering where Al-Jammaz was. She wanted to see what he had (of wit). She said: "What do you desire me to sing for you?" He said: "Sing: O wind, you are not fair to the ruins... How much obliteration of a beautiful view you have!" She laughed and knew that he had sensed that.
"Similar" happened to a man in Al-Sahib's gathering. He was ashamed and cut off from him. Al-Sahib wrote to him: "O Ibn al-Husayri, do not go in shame... For an accident that was like the flute (Nay) and the lute (Oud). For it is the wind, you cannot imprison it... Since you are not Solomon son of David."
"Similar" happened to a youth in his gathering at night. Al-Sahib said to him: "O boy, do not sleep." He was embarrassed and said: "This is the creaking of the bench (Takht)." Al-Sahib said: "I reckon it to be the creaking of the 'Taht' (Under/Bottom)."
"Of" the pleasant I heard in this metonymy is the story of Abu Abdullah bin al-Hajjaj. He invited a songstress he used to flirt with. When she arrived at his place at night and the cups circulated, he dozed off, so his back cracked while she was sitting. She got angry and left. He wrote to her the next day: "My lady got angry and denied... A crack that presented in my back. And I have no sin, but I... Creak at night and do not know. I wish I knew, while she is angry... Did the fart come from her hole or my hole?"

"Section on the Consequence of Eating"

Allah Almighty used metonymy for it with His saying: "Or one of you came from the Gha'it (low land/privy)." Al-Gha'it is the depressed place of the earth. They used to come to it for cover and withdrawal, then that became frequent in their speech until they named the event (defecation) by its name, and derived from it the verb 'Taghawwata'. "Of" the commoners' metonymies for the need to enter the toilet is their saying: "He has a need no one else can fulfill." "Of" the subtleties of doctors is their metonymy for filling the intestines with 'Tabi'ah' (Nature) and 'Baraz' (Stool/Appearance), and for the flow of nature 'Khilfah' (Diarrhea), and for rising for it 'Ikhtilaf' (Going back and forth). "From it" is the saying of Abu al-Ayna', having been asked: "To whom do you go back and forth (Takhtalif)?" He said: "To one who goes back and forth (Yakhtalif) against him (has diarrhea)." Doctors may use metonymy for urine with 'Ma'' (Water) and 'Dalil' (Indicator), and for vomit with 'Ta'aluj' (Treatment).
"Some" commentators said regarding the saying of Allah Almighty: "They both used to eat food," and His saying: "What is this Messenger that eats food and walks in the markets?" that it is only a metonymy for the event (defecation), because whoever eats must have a consequence of eating and shaking off the waste. "Al-Jahiz" faulted them for this interpretation and said: As if they did not know that the touch of hunger and what afflicts its people of humiliation and inability is the greatest proof that they are created, so they claim upon the speech something Allah has dispensed them of. "Mentioning" interpretation, Abu al-Nasr Muhammad bin Abd al-Jabbar al-Qubbi said to me: Some people of Jurjan asked me about the interpretation of His saying Almighty: "And they said: What is this Messenger that eats food and walks in the markets?" I said: It means he is not a King nor an Angel. That is because Angels do not eat or drink, and Kings do not shop or degrade themselves. So they wondered that one like them in state is distinguished from among them in highness of place and majesty. And Allah knows best where He places His message.
"I read" in the book "Al-Mustanir" that Abu Tammam and Al-Khath'ami met in a gathering of intimacy. Abu Tammam stood to go to the toilet. Al-Khath'ami said to him: "We enter you (input)?" He said: "Yes, and I bring you out (output/excrete)." Those present wondered at this novel beginning and strange quick answer.
"Similar" to this story is what Abu al-Nasr Sahl bin al-Marzuban told me. He said: Ibn Mukarram entered upon Abu al-Ayna' and asked him to stay with him. Ibn Mukarram said: "I will go and perform wudu (ablution)." Abu al-Ayna' said: "Then nothing of you returns to us," meaning because he is all 'Hadath' (impurity/excrement/event).
The people of meanings recite for Abu Sa'tara: "They continued to give him drink all night... Foul-smelling of wine and water." Meaning they beat him while he was drunk until he defecated.
Bishr al-Marisi used to say, if told 'So-and-so has placed (Wada'a - authored/defecated) a book': "Placement is of two types: one has pride, and the other has steam." He means the saying of the poet: "I passed by her house and placed in it... Like the body of the sandgrouse, having steam."
Some wits wrote to one drinking medicine: "Explain to me how you became... On a state of the states. And how much the she-camel traveled with you... Towards the empty dwelling."
The author of the book wrote to the High Assembly - may Allah comfort it - on a day he took medicine: "O owner whose origin possessed honor... And left not a tip of it for mankind. When you took the medicine and the lucky... Ascendant stood upon the resolve from you. You polished the sword of highness and purified the gold of... Glory, and life from you cleared. May you never cease sipping joy in leisure... And shaking off onto them from you sickness."
The Arabs say: "No opinion for a 'Haqin' nor for a 'Haqib'." Al-Haqin is a metonymy for one holding urine. Al-Haqib is a metonymy for one who needed the toilet but did not defecate, likened to the camel 'Haqib' whose heel rope approached his front preventing him from urinating.
Mansur al-Faqih was witty in metonymy for the event (defecation) by his saying: "Wake up, for your body is from a sperm drop... And you are a vessel for what you know."

"Section on Metonymy for the Place where that Need is Fulfilled"
It is metonymized by 'Al-Hush' which is the garden, 'Al-Mustarah' (Restroom), 'Al-Mabaraz' (Place of going out), 'Al-Madhhab' (Place of going), 'Al-Mutawadda'' (Place of Wudu), and 'Al-Mida'ah'. The best I heard in that and truest is the saying of Abu al-Fath al-Baktamari: "The most worthy house of the houses of mankind... To protect it of old and its curtains. A house, if a visitor visits it... He has fulfilled the greatest of his wishes. The master enters it in silk just as... The slave enters it in his rags. And it is, when it is cleaned... The chivalry of a man in his house."

Mentioning metonymies for that place, a story intercepted which Abu Sa'd Duwayst wrote to me with a chain to Al-Zubayr bin Bakkar. He said: Muhammad bin al-Walid al-Zubayri told me: A man from Banu Hashim arrived in Medina with two singing slave girls. He was told there was a jester there, so he sent for him and brought him. He gave him Nabidh into which he had put 'Sukkar al-Ushr' (a purgative), which loosens the belly. The Hashimi feigned sleep and winked at the two girls. When the jester drank three (cups), his belly moved. He said: "I do not think them but Meccans." He said: "May I be your ransom, where is the House of the Doctrine (Bayt al-Madhhab)?" One said to her companion: "What does he say?" She said: "He says: Sing to me: 'I went (Dhahabtu) from abandonment into other than a doctrine (Madhhab)... And the length of this avoidance was not right.'" So he was patient over a great hateful thing. Then he said: "I do not think them but Basrans." He said: "May I be your ransom, where is the House of Emptiness (Bayt al-Khala)?" One said to the other: "What does he say?" She said: "He says: Sing: 'It became empty (Khalat) and its people departed... He destroyed it who destroyed Lubad.'" He said: So he was patient over a great matter, and it darkened between his eyes. He said: "I do not think them but Kufans." He said: "May I be your ransom, do you not hear? Where is the House of the Garden (Bayt al-Hush)?" One said to the other: "What does he say?" She said: "He says: Sing: 'Al-Hanbadhan became wild (Awhasha), then the monastery from it... Then its villages, then the besieged dwelling.'" The jester said: "They did not understand me." He was patient over the severest thing, and his belly opened and his trick narrowed. He said: "They are definitely Medinans." He said: "May I be your ransom, where is the House of the Privy (Bayt al-Kanif)?" One said to the other: "What does he say?" She said: "He says: Sing to me: 'Passion surrounded me (Takannafani) as a child... So it grayed me while I was not middle-aged.'" He said: "O two adulteresses, I will inform you what it is." He stood up lifting his robe and defecated on them and filled the gathering. The Hashimi woke up and said: "Woe to you! What have you done?" He said: "You sat me with these two adulteresses who do not think the Kanif is anything but the Straight Path. They envy me being guided to it." He said: "Do you spoil my clothes on me?" He said: "By Allah, what I spoiled on myself of my belly is more severe than what I spoiled of your gathering."
"I" conclude this section with a report from the Prophet, peace be upon him, in metonymy for defecating in streets and paths of passersby, which is his saying, peace upon him: "Beware of the two cursers, and prepare the paths."

Chapter Four
Metonymy regarding Uglinesses, Disabilities, and Defects

"Section One: On Ugliness and Blackness"
If a man is ugly in creation, deformed in image, it is said in metonymy for him: "He has relatives in Yemen," because monkeys abound there.
"Of the pleasant" metonymy for ugliness is the saying of Abu Nuwas: "A female sayer to her in the passion of advice... Why did you abandon this wandering lover? Her answer was in touching beauty... Do I combine this and the Haram (sin)?" This is like their saying: "Bad dates and bad measure."
If he is intensely dark-skinned with ugliness, it is said: "As if his face is the moon of the thirtieth (no moon)."
The saying of Nusayb is deemed good in metonymy for the blackness of his daughters in a speech he addressed Umar bin Abdul Aziz with: "O Commander of the Faithful, I have been afflicted with daughters of mine on whom I spent my color, so they became stagnant (unmarried)." He pitied him and gave him a gift. Regarding Nusayb it was said: "A brother of mine from the sons of Ham bin Noah... His forehead was the Stone of the Maqam (Black Stone)."
"It is told" in a long story regarding Sukayna bint al-Husayn bin Ali, may Allah be pleased with them, that she ordered the expulsion of Al-Farazdaq from her house and said: "By Allah, he shall not enter upon me until the crow turns grey." Al-Farazdaq was gentle and tricked, and said to Nusayb: "Will you bring me in to her and take her gift?" He said: "Yes." So he asked permission for Nusayb from the doorman. He permitted him, and Al-Farazdaq entered on his track. When Sukayna saw him, she said: "O malicious one, you have betrayed me." He said: "O my mistress, you said 'until the crow turns grey', and here, by Allah, is the crow turned grey," meaning the blackness of his (Nusayb's) face and the whiteness of his hair. Nusayb said: "I knew he did not intend good for me." Then she expiated for her oath and gave them abundant gifts.
No one used metonymy for the black praised one better and more innovatively than Al-Mutanabbi's metonymy for the blackness of Kafur al-Ikhshidi by his saying: "So she came with us to the pupil of the eye of his time... And left whiteness behind her and tear ducts." He combined good metonymy with good alerting and quality of preference, and excelled as he wished.

"Section on Heaviness and Coldness"
Abu Ja'far Muhammad bin Musa al-Musawi told me: I entered one day upon Sheikh Abu Nasr bin Arbad in Bukhara. With him was a boring Alawite; he was hurt by the length of his sitting and abundance of his speech. When he rose, Abu Nasr said to me: "This cousin of yours is light on the heart." I said to him: "Yes," agreeing with him on his opinion. He smiled laughing at my saying and said to me: "I see you did not notice the purpose." I ceased not to think until it occurred to me that he meant 'light' inverted, which is 'heavy'. This meaning Sa'd Duwayst intended by his saying: "And a heavy one who visited me, and as if he... Turned in the eyelids of my eye and in my heart.

I said to him when I was bored by his nearness... I see you on my heart light on the heart (pun on Qalb/Heart/Inversion)."
Al-Nasir the Alawite, the Deaf (Al-Utrush), used to say if a person spoke to him and he did not hear him: "O you, raise your voice, for some of what is in your spirit has become apparent to me," using metonymy for heaviness.
Badi' al-Zaman looked at a cold, tall human and said: "The winter night has approached, for it is long, cold."
Ibn Abi Ayyub entered upon Ibn Haddar visiting him while he was shivering. He said to him: "What do you find (feel), may I be your ransom?" He said: "I find you," using metonymy for coldness.

"Section" on Metonymy for the Disease that has no Cure except by Disobedience to Allah
It is said: So-and-so hides the Staff (Al-Asa). And So-and-so is the Staff of Moses, because it swallows what they fabricate. And So-and-so hides the staff in the far vestibule.
"Abu Nasr Sahl bin al-Marzuban told me" said: Some of Banu Hashim said to Abu al-Ayna': "It reached me that you hide the staff." He said to him: "And you (plural) invite it to appear."
Al-Tabari recited to me for himself regarding the Bridle (Lijam): "I saw for the bridle in its creation... A conformity to poetry and a pun. It fraternized with Pharaoh, but it... Punned in carrying the Staff with Moses. And covered (Ghshsha - tricked/covered) Iblis, but it... Differed in prostration from Iblis."
It is said: So-and-so is of those who fall down on their chins. "And he is" more prostrating than a hoopoe. Regarding that, some contemporaries say: "I sent in describing a friend of ours... A truth metonymized by the mosque (Masjid). In beauty a peacock, but he is... More prostrating in seclusion than a hoopoe."
And So-and-so is a crow, because he hides the shame of his brother. Mansur al-Faqih said: "Indeed in the affair of Ahmad bin al-Tahawi... And in the affair of his wife is a wonder. She divorced herself the evening she was wed... And permitted him her wine and clothes. It was said: What is the matter with him? She said: A crow... Did you stipulate on a husband a crow?"
Of Al-Sahib's witticisms in this metonymy is his saying, and it is narrated for another: "He has a field in his trousers... In which he plants sugar cane." "And his saying": "He attended the mosque with a softness... Which the world innovated in his religion. By Allah, he does not attend it rushing... Except out of relief for its columns." "And his saying": "I saw him yesterday carrying the staff... So I asked him about it to clarify an excuse. He answered me: I am acting like an old Sheikh with it... This, and I have in it other uses." "And his saying": "By Allah, I did not take writing as a craft... Except for the love of scrolls (Daraj - pun on Insertions/Stairs) and pens (Aflam - pun on Boys/Pens)."
Professor Al-Tabari recited to me for himself from a poem: "He said: I am the King (Al-Malik). So I said: Truly... By turning the Lam into Nun in spelling (Manik - F****d). And I did not see of the tool of the King anything... With you except your bearing of the banner (Liwa - pun on twisting/banner)." He also recited to me from another: "You do not sacrifice a sword for Islam... And you, as you knew, are of the column (Amud). And you are ascetic regarding prayer and its people... But you are not ascetic regarding prostration."
It is narrated that Ibn al-Ahwas looked at Al-Farazdaq while he was on a mule. He said to him: "O Abu Firas, your mule is on five (legs)." He said: "The fifth is dearer to you." Al-Ahwas was accused of Ubnah (passive sodomy).
"Of" the good allusion to it is the saying of Amr bin Babah: "I say when Amr passed by us... And greeted a hidden greeting. If Amr boasted of the virtue of wealth... Indeed Allah favored with wellness (Afiyah)."

"Section on Metonymy for Leprosy (Baras)"
Jadhima was a leper, so he was metonymized as Al-Waddah (The Bright) and Al-Abrash (The Speckled). When Bal'a bin Qays became leprous, it was said to him: "What is this?" He said: "The sword of Allah polished it," and it is narrated "adorned it (hallahu)" with Ha and Shadda on Lam. "Among those" who used metonymy for leprosy with "Wadah" (Brightness) is a man from Banu Nahshal where he said: "Sawdah fled from me when she saw... Baldness of the head in my skin and brightness (Wadah). It is an adornment for me in the face just as... The blazes of the colt adorn the horses." Ibn Hassa said in metonymy for it with whiteness: "Do not think whiteness in him is a defect... Indeed the excellent horses among their peers are piebald." "For some of them": "The brother of Lakhm lent you a garment from him... Congratulations on the shirt to you, O speckled one." The brother of Lakhm is Jadhima the Speckled. A man leprous of hand used to dye it to be more hidden for what is in it. His boy was asked what he does. He said: "He treats ivory with teak (blackwood)."

"Section on Metonymy" regarding several disabilities.
The blind is metonymized by "Al-Mahjub" (The Veiled). Regarding that, Uthman bin al-Walid bin Utbah says: "By my life, if I entered evening upon blindness... Indeed, the noble ones before me were afflicted in sights. Umayyah and his son lived veiled... Our father Abu Amr, and Harb, and Hashim."

When Al-Mutawakkil wanted Abu al-Ayna' for his boon companionship, he said to him: "O Commander of the Faithful, I am veiled (blind). The veiled one errs in his intent, and turns to one who does not turn to him. Everyone in your gathering serves, and I need to be served in it."
The one-eyed is metonymized by "Al-Mumatta'" (The One Allowed Enjoyment). The one with a white spot in his eye by "Al-Kawkabi" (Starry) and "Al-Mukawkab". The one with a scar on his face by "Al-Mushattab". "How" excellent is how Awf bin Muhallim used metonymy for deafness by his saying: "Indeed the eighty, and I reached them... Have made my hearing in need of a translator."

"Section on Miserliness"
The miser is metonymized by "Al-Muqtasid" (The Frugal). It is said: "So-and-so is clean of kitchen" and "So-and-so is pure of pot." The poet said: "White of kitchens, their maids do not complain... Of cooking of pots nor washing of napkins." "Another said: The kitchen of Dawood in its cleanliness... Is the most resembling thing to the throne of Bilqis. The clothes of his cook, if they get dirty... Are purer in whiteness than papyruses." Abu Nuwas: "I saw the pots of people black from burning... And the pot of the Raqashis is white like the full moon." Al-Jammaz said to a man: "May Allah have mercy on your father, for he was clean of the napkin of the table." Professor Al-Tabari said: "A youth, restricted of food... And drink and perfume. Pure of bread and bowl... And napkin and pot. Little of ants and flies... And rats and cats." Mentioning the lack of rats, a Bedouin woman said to one of the Caliphs: "I complain of the lack of rats." He said: "How beautiful is this metonymy! I will surely increase your rats." He ordered much food and money for her. Of the rare metonymy for miserliness with food is the saying of Humayr when asked who attends the table of Muhammad bin Yahya. He said: "The most noble of creation and the meanest of them," meaning angels and flies. Not cold is the saying of Hammad Ajrad: "I visited a man in his house, glorious... Having modesty and having good. He hates to give indigestion to his guests... Indeed the harm of indigestion is cautioned. And desires that they be rewarded with him... By fasting, and the fasting one is rewarded." Of that is the saying of the other: "At his doors, whichever face... You intended for him, is the brother of Murr ibn Udd (Bitter son of Udd - pun on turning back)." Among what is deemed good in this chapter is the saying of Ibn Tabataba al-Alawi: "And a scribe, a calculator, if you intended seeking... What is in his hands when you went begging him. He added ninety followed by its three... To three thousand and nine hundred." And his saying in this exact metonymy: "If I intended what is in your hands begging... Or came complaining to you the tightness of my hand. You knotted for me with the left hand four... Clasped, seven of the number."

"Section on Metonymy" regarding a group of defects and blameworthy morals.
If a man is ignorant, it is said: "So-and-so is of the resting ones," due to their saying: "He rested who has no mind." "If he is" safe of side, simple-minded, it is said: "So-and-so is of the people of Paradise," because the Prophet, peace be upon him, says: "Most of the people of Paradise are the simple-minded (Bulh)." "If he is" stupid, they said: "His adjective (Na't) is diptote (La Yansarif - does not conjugate/leave)." "Abu al-Hasan al-Shahrazuri recited to me," he said: Abu al-Hasan al-Lajjam recited to me for himself regarding Ibn Matran al-Shashi when he was dismissed from the post of Tirmidhiyyah: "We were dismissed (Surifna), and everyone who... Was before us is dismissed (Munsarif). And we were dismissed by a poet... Whose adjective is diptote (Laysa Yansarif)."
If he is meddlesome, entering into what does not concern him, taking upon himself what is not binding on him, they said: "He is the executor (Wasi) of Adam." This description may be placed in the place of praise, as the poet said: "And Adam was, when his death was decreed... Commanded you while he was breathing his last with the soul. That you tend them, so you tended them... And sufficed Adam the cost of the sons."
If he is impudent, they said: "There is a shield (Daraqah) and a pupil and a hammered (Mutraqa) cheek." "This" word is by Al-Sahib from a letter of his to Abu al-Abbas al-Dabbi mentioning Abu al-Hasan al-Jawhari the poet.
If he is little of brain, they said: "So-and-so is empty of the upper room." The poet said: "Our friend, his conditions are high... But his upper room is empty."
If he is very reckless, they said: "Bring a peg (Watad) with him." "If" he is a liar, they said: "The turtle-dove is with him Abu Dharr." This word is sweet from the witticisms of Al-Sahib, and I have not heard in its meaning better or more eloquent than it, because the turtle-dove is cited as a proverb (for lying). The poet said: "More lying than a turtle-dove... Saying amidst the dry leaves and spadix: This is the time of fresh dates... While it has not appeared to her." And Abu Dharr al-Ghifari is the one about whom the Prophet, peace be upon him, says: "The green (sky) has not shaded nor the dusty (earth) carried one more truthful in tone than Abu Dharr." "Of" their metonymies for lying: "So-and-so slaps the eye of Mahran." "Mahran" is a man cited as a proverb in lying. "If" he is boring, it is said: "So-and-so is of the remnant of the people of Moses," as he said:

"I see you a remnant of the people of Moses... For they do not have patience for one food."
If he is of much affectation and arrogance, they said: "So-and-so increases the saffron." They compare him to the pot made with affectation.
If he is beautiful of appearance but has no substance, they said: "So-and-so is Faludhaj of the market." Al-Hajjaj said: "And how many a friend pleasing my eye... In the mold of beauty and elegance. He has no opinion in the beautiful... Nor does he do the beautiful a bit. As if he, walking in the shirt, is... Faludhaj of the market in a thin sheet."
"If" he is bad of handwriting, they said: "So-and-so, his handwriting is the handwriting of angels," because the best handwriting is the clearest, and the worst is the opposite, and the handwriting of angels is not clear to people. "I heard" Abu al-Qasim bin al-Hasan al-Tarani the Jurist say: I heard Abu Muhammad Yahya bin Muhammad al-Alawi say: That was only said because the worst handwriting is 'Raqm' (scribble/numerals), and the writing of angels is 'Raqm', as Allah Almighty said: "A written (Marqum) book. Witnessed by those brought near."
"If he is" a foundling with no known father, they said: "He is of the upbringing of the Judge and of the clients of the Prophet, peace be upon him," because the Judge orders the upbringing of foundlings and spending on them from the picked-up property for acts of charity, and the Prophet, peace be upon him, says: "I am the patron of who has no patron." This meaning Abu Nuwas intended by his saying: "We found Al-Fadl more generous than Riqqash... Because Al-Fadl, his patron is the Messenger."
It is told that a man accused of false claim (of lineage) said to Abu Ubaida when he was accused of the Book of Vices (Mathalib): "Do you insult the Arabs all together?" He said: "And what harms you of that?" Meaning he is not of them. "If" he claimed lineage in Hashim while he is a false claimant, they said: "He is the cousin of the Prophet from Al-Duldul," which is his mule. Meaning the kinship between them is like the kinship between the Prophet and the mule. Regarding that, Abu Sa'd Duwayst says: "I ransom you; you are not of Hashim... Nor are you of Ahmad the Sent. If you said I am the cousin of the Prophet... Then you are a cousin from Al-Duldul." The wittiest I heard in metonymy for false claim and lying of lineage is the saying of Abu al-Fath Kushajim: "A Sheikh of ours from the Sheikhs of Kufa... His lineage in Iraq is prescribed (Mawsufah)." Meaning falsified (Muzawwarah), because 'Muzawwarah' (broth for sick) is prescribed for the sick.
"If he is" a heretic, they said: "So-and-so is free (Hurr) and he is of the free," using metonymy that he is outside the noose of Sharia. "Perhaps" they used metonymy with "Al-Kharrat" (Stripper/Turner), since the dogs of Mecca are called "Al-Kharrata" because they strip their collars and their treachery. So the heretic is without religion just as the dogs of Mecca are without treachery (loyalty?). "Abu" Dulaf al-Khazraji has a poem in imitating Banu Sasan and describing their classes, and in it in mentioning their heretics: "Men who realized regarding transmission... And causation and the command. Khalijis who did not menstruate... Nor spent the night upon purity." The Khaliji is the one who does not wash his anus. "Did not menstruate" meaning did not purify. They saw the wisdom of stripping collars with treachery. The people of Baghdad say to one who committed heresy: "So-and-so has crossed," meaning he has crossed the bridge of Islam. It was said to some of them: "Have you crossed?" He said: "I was born in that place," using metonymy that he never ceased to be so.
If he is vile, mean, it is said: "He is the eighth of the Companions of the Cave," because Allah Almighty says in their story: "And their eighth is their dog."
"If" they were in the count of beasts and livestock, they said as the poet said: "Are you not of the male whom He mentioned... In Surah Al-Jumu'ah and Al-Nahl?" Meaning the saying of Allah Almighty in Surah Al-Jumu'ah: "Like the donkey carrying books." "And in" Surah Al-Nahl: "And horses and mules and donkeys for you to ride."
"If he eats" their food, they said: "So-and-so is inflamed of stomach, and in his vitals is Mu'awiyah." "If he is" bad mannered in eating together, they said: "His hand travels on the table and grazes the land of neighbors."
"If he is" light-handed in pickpocketing and theft, they said: "He is taker of the hand of the shirt." The hand of the shirt is the sleeve. The thief cuts his sleeve and lightens it to be more capable of his work. Al-Farazdaq said regarding Amr bin Hubayrah: "You gave charge of Iraq and its dwellers... To a Fazari who took the hand of the shirt." He also said, and it is of the verses of meanings: "I think you are bereaved of a quarter, a hypocrite... Wearing the robes of betrayal and treachery." He used metonymy for his right hand being cut off, so a quarter of his limbs goes.
"If he is" not clean of body, neglecting its care, they said: "So-and-so is nails of a fever (Huma) and wrapper of a pasture." Good is Abu Nuwas's saying: "Whoever his hunting place is far from him... Then the hunting place of the hornet is his clothes." "And for Al-Sahib": "His wild animals graze in his robe... And his nail rides for hunting." "Of" the commoners' metonymies in this meaning is their saying: "He reviews the soldiers." "Sa'id" bin Humayd excelled in metonymy for body odor by his saying to Abu Hiffan: "The Abdi (slave?) has become frightening me with his assault... And how can I be safe from the might of the crushing lion?
