Who does not protect me from his sword, a shield... And my caution does not prevent me from his plot. He has arrows without feathers or nock... And his bow is forever stripped of the string. So how can I be safe from one to whom I expose a side... While his arrow hits hidden from sight?" I heard some old women use metonymy for body odor with "smell of youth."
"If he is" a pimp, they said: "So-and-so gathers the reunion of loved ones" and "So-and-so brings the beloved." "It may be used as metonymy" for the watcher also. "If he is" skilled, they said: "So-and-so is skilled in pimping; he drags one by a hair and unites between the lizard and the whale."
"If he is" either handsome of neck or handsome of form but has nothing behind him and no benefit with him, they said: "There is no village behind Abadan." Professor Al-Tabari recited to me for himself regarding Abu Sa'd Duwayst bin Millah al-Harawi: "Abu Sa'd has a pretty robe... But the stuffing of that robe is his shit. If you pass his clothing to him... There is no village behind Abadan."
If he is illegitimate, they said: "His father is short of wall." Al-Sahib said from verses: "So pave for his erectness (Nasb - pun on lineage/erection) his excuse... For the walls of his father's house are short."
If he has madness, they said: "So-and-so is written on the shirt," because the madman may have written on his shirt "Not to be sold or gifted." In metonymy for the enmity-holder, Abu Sa'd bin Duwayst says: "And opposing the truth, not allied... To truthfulness, a slave of debate and argumentation. He left the pilgrims (Hujjaj) for disputation (Lajjaj), so I said: O... Abomination of chickens and station of pilgrims (Hajjaj)." I heard Abu al-Fadl Abdullah bin Ahmad al-Mikali say: Abu Ubaida said: "Al-Aridah" is a metonymy for giving. It is said: "So-and-so is strong of Aridah." And "Al-Iqtisad" (Economy) is a metonymy for miserliness. If they said "Your boy is rebellious (Musta'sin)," that is a metonymy for hunger. Shurayh said: "Al-Hadd" (Limit/Edge) is a metonymy for effort and hardship.

"Section on Metonymy" for Dispraising Poets and Poetry
If a man is a pseudo-poet not a poet, they said: "So-and-so is the Prophet of Poetry," because Allah Almighty says regarding His Prophet, peace be upon him: "And We have not taught him poetry, nor is it befitting for him." Mukhallad al-Mawsili said: "O Prophet of Allah in poetry... And O Jesus son of Mary. You are of the most poetic creation... Of Allah as long as you do not speak." They sing the saying of the poet: "Poets, as we know, are four... A poet who runs and is not run with. And a poet who recites in the middle of the crowd. And a poet whom it is your right to hear. And a poet whom it is your right to slap. And him I meant by saying: O fourth of poets, why did you satirize me?... Did you think I am silenced, not speaking?" For some people of the age: "Say to our heavy poet... Raised by his appearance over the watchers. O second of sudden death and third... Of Husayn, indeed you are the fourth of poets."
If he is cold of poetry, they said: "So-and-so is from the family of Summer." Al-Jammaz said regarding Abu al-Samt: "Indeed Abu al-Samt... And his poetry are of the family of heat. Blessed is he for whom in summer is recited... Five verses of poetry." Ibn Wariq al-Kufi said regarding Al-Suli's poetry: "My house is without Khaysh (cooling linen), but I... Knot from my Khaysh two layers of a house. Whenever my heat intensifies in it... I recited two verses of Al-Suli." Ahmad bin Tahir said regarding Al-Fath bin Khaqan when he fell ill from heat: "What is the medicine of Prince Fath bin Khaqan... ?? this time. The medicine of the Prince is that they recite to him... Some of what ?? Abu Hiffan." It was said to Al-Attabi: "Abu Muslim has paralyzed creation." He said: "Perhaps he ate from his poetry." "A group" of poets gathered over a hot Faludhaj. One of them said to the other among them: "As if it is your place in the Fire." He said: "A verse of your poetry fixes it." "It was said" to Professor Tabari: "So-and-so's poetry ?? but like well water in summer." He took it from the saying of Ibn al-Rumi: "You are to me like the water of your well in summer... Heavy ?? severe cold." "Abu al-Hasan al-Himyari recited to me" for himself in metonymy for bad, uncirculated poetry: "We have a friend whose poetry is domestic... It does not get used to travels and estrangement. But I hear it observing... His right in the precedence of companionship."

"Section on Asking and Begging (Kudyah)"

The first to use metonymy for asking (begging) was Khalid bin Barmak. Abdullah bin Sharik al-Numayri came to him in a group of the people of Sawtat seeking his generosity. Beggars (Su'al) were called Su'al. Khalid said: "I, by Allah, find this name ugly for them, and among them are nobles and generous ones. But we call them Visitors (Zuwar)." Abdullah said to him: "By Allah, I do not know if our visiting you is greater, or our gift, or our naming." Yazid bin Khalid al-Kufi, known as Ibn Hubaybat, said regarding that: "Khalid followed in his generosity the cut of Barmak... So glory for him is new and rooted. The sons of lack used to be attributed before him... To a name in which there is evidence of lack. They are called Su'al (Beggars) in every place... Even if among them is a famous and great one. So he named them Zuwar (Visitors) as a covering for them... And that is of the action of the noble, noble." Al-Suli mentioned this report for other than Khalid with a chain of his, that Al-Musawir bin al-Nu'man, when he governed the districts of Fars, people came to him. It was said to him: "Your Su'al (beggars) have gathered." He said: "How ugly is this name! These are Visitors." So they were named by it from that day. Ziyad al-A'jam says regarding it: "Indeed Al-Musawir gave in his gift... To his askers the best of names for humans. They used to be called Su'al, so he made them... Without creation, Zuwar, and he did not deviate."
It is said: "So-and-so is of the companions of the Bag and the Niche (Mihrab)," and "So-and-so is of the reciters of Surah Yusuf," because the reciters of beggars increase in reading it in markets, gatherings, and mosques because it is the best of stories. Muhammad bin Wahb said: "If you were memorizing of poems and grammar... Indeed you were of the reciters of Surah Yusuf."
It is said: "So-and-so is the successor of Khidr" if he is roaming in travels, traversing lands in begging. "He may" be described with this metonymy who increases his risings and connects his movements even if for other than begging. Some of them were seen begging in a village. He was asked: "What are you doing?" He said: "What Moses and Khidr did," meaning they asked the people of a village for food.
"Nasr bin Sahl bin al-Marzuban told me" said: A son was born to Abu al-Ayna'. Abu Ali al-Basir came to him congratulating him. He said: "What time did he leave his mother?" He said: "The time of morning at the beating of the drums." Abu Ali said: "I hope Allah makes you know his blessing, for he did not miss his time," meaning that beggars spread at that time for begging.
"It is said" a man asked some of the pretending-to-be-rich. The asked one said to him: "Our interior is like your exterior, and the garden is all celery," meaning he is like him in poverty and need for asking.
"Some" eloquent ones wrote in demanding provisions for a man: "So-and-so is residing waiting for his answer and the fruit of his acceptance (Ijab)," using metonymy for the gift with 'fruit of acceptance', and he did very well. "I said" in the book "Al-Mubhij": "Whoever brought the pearls of speech milked the udder of the noble."

"Section on Metonymy for Poverty and Bad State"
"It is said": "So-and-so has worn the slogan of the righteous," meaning he became poor. "And it is said": "So-and-so, the hem of his state thinned, and his house resembles the heart of Moses' mother (empty), and he reads Surah Al-Tariq," meaning nothing is seen in it but the sky and stars. "And it is said": "So-and-so came to us in a shirt upon which Time ate and drank, and a Jubbah reciting 'When the sky splits open'." "And So-and-so", his bed is the dusty (earth) and his cover is the green (sky), if he does not cover himself from Allah with anything.
"Abu al-Hasan Muhammad bin Abdullah known as Ibn Sakra entered" the Bathhouse of Musa in Baghdad, and his sandal was stolen. He said: "Thieves shoulder to shoulder upon it until... He goes barefoot who greets by it and goes naked. I did not intend a robe by it, but... I entered as Muhammad and exited as Bishr," meaning Bishr the Barefoot.

"Section on Metonymy for Slapping (Saf')"
Abu Hiffan used to say: "I do not joke except with the two hands and the two parents," using metonymy for slapping and cursing.
Of the most eloquent I heard in metonymy for slapping is the saying of Ismail al-Sabhi regarding Abu Nuwas: "And when he addressed our honors... And there was no avenger for his honor. We wrote satire on his neck veins... With a transcript from the palms of servants."
Of what is deemed witty is the saying of Ibn Lank in Abu Riyash: "His fingers from the sweets are yellow... But the neck veins from him are red." "And his saying": "I did not kiss his mouth, but... The palm of my hand kissed the back of his neck."
The saying of Mansur al-Faqih is approved: "O you who sees me while creation... All of it in knowledge is below him, protect. Do not button upon it your... Collar if it appears to you to protect it."
What Abu Bakr al-Khawarizmi recited to me for some regarding an impudent slapped person is deemed good: "His weapon is in his face... And his money is in his crown. So all that he owns... He gathers in his turban."
How subtle is the saying of Al-Sari al-Mawsili in metonymy for slapping: "A people, if delegations attend the kings... Their turbans are shaken off at the doors."

Nothing wittier was seen in this meaning than what Abu al-Hasan Ali bin Ahmad bin Abdan recited to me for Ibn Sakra regarding Ibn Qari'a: "I saw a tall cap seeking help... From above a head calling out: Take me. It has become anxious, so it sometimes leans... From the left and from the right. I said to it: What is it that afflicted you? She said the speech of a sad, depressed one: It afflicted me that I am not of my mold... And I fear that people will deny me. And if they take to joking with me... And if they do that to me, they will cut me."

"Section on Metonymy for Lowly Crafts"
Al-Sha'bi was asked about a man who proposed to a woman. He said: "He is soft of sitting, penetrating of stab." So he was married, and behold he was a tailor. Al-Jahiz narrated about Al-Nazzam that he used metonymy for the weaver with "the most waisted of belly," meaning that subsidence has waisted his belly. "A cupper was asked" about his craft. He said: "I write with iron and seal with glass."
"Of the best" I heard in this metonymy is what is told that Al-Farazdaq entered upon Bilal bin Abi Burda while he was dispraising Mudar and praising Yemen. Al-Farazdaq said: "Indeed the virtue of Yemen is not repelled, especially the one by which Abu Musa was distinguished." Bilal said: "Indeed the virtues of Abu Musa are many, so which one do you mean?" He said: "By his breath from the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, when his blood overcame him," meaning that he cupped him in some of his travels. Bilal said: "Yes, he did that to the Messenger of Allah, and he did not do it to anyone before him nor after him." Al-Farazdaq said: "The Sheikh was more God-fearing and knowledgeable of Him than to proceed upon His Prophet without skill." Bilal was silent and held a grudge for it against Al-Farazdaq. It was counted among Al-Farazdaq's silencing answers.
"Of the rare" metonymy for the cupper and its famous ones is the saying of Utbah al-A'war to Ibrahim bin Sayyar: "O son of him who lived not persecuted... May Allah have mercy on you, what a man! The necks of kings are submissive to him... Among barefoot and shod. Your father, the baldric wore out his shoulder... How many a brave warrior he bled, and a hero. He takes from his money and from his blood... He does not spend the evening fearful of an avenger. In his palm is a sharp edge that overcomes him... Cutting the necks of noble masters."
The night patrol in Kufa caught a man. He said to him: "Who are you?" He recited: "I am the son of him whose rank Time does not lower... And if it descends one day, it will return. You see people in crowds at the door of his house... If he passes, and delegations come to him." So he let him go and thought him the son of some nobles. Behold, he was the son of a bean seller (Baqilani).
"Abu al-Fadl al-Mikali recited to me" for Abu Bakr al-Allaf regarding Al-Zajjaji the Grammarian: "You have an affection we have mended... But its cracks exhausted us. So behold, your affection is of what... You were selling yesterday (Glass/Zujaj)."

"The Fifth Chapter"
"On Metonymy for Illness, Greyness, Old Age, and Death"
"Section on Illness"
This section is limited to the words of the eloquent of the people of the age in metonymy for illness occurring in the sections of this chapter. "Of them" is their saying: "Time scratched him," which is from the saying of Abu al-Tayyib al-Mutanabbi to Sayf al-Dawla: "Time scratched you out of passion and love... And the beloved may hurt out of affection." "Of them" is their saying: "A period of lethargy appeared to him," "Hit his wood," "Generosity complained for his complaint," "There appeared to him what Allah makes purification not punishment, reminder not denial, discipline not anger," "There appeared to him what erases his sins and expiates his bad deeds."
"Al-Sahib used metonymy" for scabies by his saying to Abu al-Ala al-Asadi from verses: "Abu al-Ala, King of Jest and Seriousness... How are the stars that rise in the skin?"
I heard Professor Al-Tabari say in mentioning a sick person nearing destruction: "The messengers of Abu Yahya have frequented him."
"Abu Mansur al-Shirazi wrote" mentioning the intensification of the illness of some chiefs: "The ascendant of Generosity oscillates, his star swings between shining and setting, and his sun inclines between rising and setting."

"Section on their Metonymies for Greyness"
His night approached. The branch of his youth blossomed. The hand of Time sprinkled camphor on his musk. His tube lobed (?). Chamomile appeared in his violet. "The best" of all this is the saying of Allah, Exalted is His Name: "And the warner came to you."
The people of meanings recite the saying of some Arabs: "When I saw the vulture defeated the son of Da'yah... And nested in his two nests, my chest boiled for it." The Vulture is a metonymy for greyness, and Ibn Da'yah is the crow, used as metonymy for youth.

"Section on their Metonymies for Middle Age (Iktihal)"
He exchanged the piebald for the black. And the magpie for the crow. He was disciplined by the bridle of Time. The dust of boyhood was shaken off. He responded to the caller of intellect. He was clothed in the clothes of the people of minds. He reached the time of wisdom.

"Section on their Metonymies for Old Age"

And Great Age and Decrepitude and Nearing Death. He has been given ample respite. The decades of his life have doubled. Age has ended with him. The sweet days have passed. So-and-so is the afternoon sun on the wall. He has reached the coast of life. He stood at the Farewell Pass. He overlooked the Abode of Stay. He almost joined the Subtle, the Aware.
"When" Mu'awiyah's incisor fell in the basin, his anxiety intensified. Abu al-A'war al-Sulami said to him: "Ease upon yourself, O Commander of the Faithful. By Allah, no one reached your age except parts of him destroyed parts."

"Section on Metonymy for Death"
Allah claimed him for Himself. Allah made him happy with His neighborhood. Allah transferred him to the abode of His pleasure and place of His forgiveness. The happiness of the dying one was written for him. It led him to the awaited matter. Allah chose for him the transfer from the abode of ruin to the place of the righteous. I appreciate the saying of Al-Muraqqish Al-Akbar: "There is no regret over the length of life... And behind a man is what he knows."
Abu Nasr Sahl bin al-Marzuban told me, he said: Ibn Mukarram entered upon Abu al-Ayna' visiting. He said to him: "Rise, may I be your ransom." He said: "May Allah raise you to Him," meaning cause him to die. "A man teased" some wits. He said to him: "I saw you under me." He said: "With three like me," meaning in carrying his funeral.
"I heard" some wise men say in metonymy for the death of a friend of his: "So-and-so has completed the definition of Man," because the definition of Man is that he is a rational living being. They often use metonymy for the grave with "Al-Turbah" (Soil), "Al-Madja'" (Bed), "Al-Marqad" (Sleeping place), and "Al-Mashhad" (Scene/Shrine).

"Section on Metonymy for Killing"
He prayed to the heat of blades before the heat of Fire. A hero and a heavy rain watered the earth with his blood. He lacked the coolness of life and tasted the heat of sharp swords. He quenched from him the thirst of the sword. Better than all this is the saying of Allah Almighty: "So Moses struck him with his fist and ended him," meaning killed him.
"Abu al-Nasr Muhammad bin Abd al-Jabbar told me" said: The Vizier of the time handed over some virtuous workers to Ibn Abi al-Baghl when he rose to the head of his work in Ahvaz, and ordered him to employ him in his works in what he deemed suitable for him to mend the defect of his state. So he employed him over some funds of the Treasury. Then he killed him under demand for what the judgment of fulfillment gathered against him. He feared the consequence of retaliation for his crime against a deposit of one whose favor he was obliged to thank. Thought led to devising what would get him out of the responsibility of his haste and untie him from the noose of his crime. He did not find for that a shifting meaning nor a word indicative of the intent. He sought someone to search for him with an excuse and necessitate for him a cause of separation from the consequence of that dealing on the condition of a state whose danger is great and whose effect appears in blocking the poverty of the state. Until he was guided to a Sheikh from the masters of the craft whom ordeal had crippled and unemployment stagnated. He called him and asked him to compose a letter to the Vizier regarding important matters of the faces of dealings and regarding the story of the killing in the folding of speech. He said to him: "Write an excuse with this meaning." He wrote: "As for So-and-so, the Vizier ordered using him. When I used him (Ista'maltuhu), I found him claiming rights (Istahwaytuhu - from Hawa/containing?), so I performed him (Addaytuhu - paid him/performed upon him?), so he agreed with the appointed term (Al-Ajal - death)." Ibn Abi al-Baghl wondered at his ability, quick acumen, and strength of mind in extracting what belongs to the concise wording and the shifting meaning from the responsibility of his crimes. He gave him abundant money and occupied him with a great work.
The author of the book said: I think the Sheikh alluded in the meaning of what he wrote to a signature by Abdullah bin Tahir, but increased in improving it and the subtlety of its refinement. Abdullah had beaten some of his commanders a severe beating from which he died. His news was raised to him. He signed: "We beat him for his sin, so he died for his term (Ajal)."

The Sixth Chapter
Regarding what Time and Condition necessitate of Metonymy regarding Food and Drink
And what connects to them
"Section on Foods and what relates to them"

Al-Sha'bi entered upon a friend of his, who offered him food and said: "Which of the two masterpieces is dearer to you: The Masterpiece of Maryam or the Masterpiece of Ibrahim?" He said: "As for the Masterpiece of Ibrahim, my pledge with it is (just) now." So he brought out to him a basket of fresh dates. He used metonymy for meat because in his story, peace be upon him: "So he did not tarry to bring a roasted calf." And he used metonymy with the Masterpiece of Maryam for fresh dates, because in her story: "And shake toward you the trunk of the palm tree; it will drop upon you fresh, ripe dates."
"I heard" Abu Sa'd Ahmad bin Muhammad bin Millah al-Harawi say: Al-Mubarrad passed by Sadab the paper-seller while he was at the door of his house. He rose to him and asked him to please him by entering his home and helping him with what was present. Al-Mubarrad said to him: "What do you have?" He said: "My master, I have You and upon it I." Meaning cold meat (Mubarrad) and upon it Rue (Sadab). He laughed at it and answered him.
"I heard" Abu al-Fadl Ubayd Allah bin Ahmad al-Mikali say: A Bedouin said to his wife: "Where has your pot reached?" She said: "Its preacher has stood up," using metonymy for boiling.
"It was said" to Al-Jammaz: "Which legumes are dearer to you?" He said: "The wolf's legume," meaning meat. Some witty jurists entered upon me one day. The conversation prolonged, then he said to me: "What is before His saying Almighty: 'We have certainly encountered from this journey of ours fatigue'?" I said: "Bring us our lunch." He said: "Then act upon it." I found this anecdote witty and ordered bringing what he could eat.
"Al-Tabari used to" say: If you see the boon companion suggesting that this verse be sung: "O my two friends, you treated an apparent... So who treats an internal ardency?" Know that he is hungry, wanting to be fed. "He said": And for this is a story, which is that a man entered a banquet and had severe hunger. The singer asked him about the suggestion from singing. He suggested this verse. The slave girl of the house owner realized his intent and said to her master: "Feed the man, for he is hungry."
"It was said" to some of them: "Which digestive (Jawarish) is dearer to you?" He said: "Wheat digestive," meaning bread.
"The Sufis have" metonymies for foods that are deemed witty, among them their saying: "He carries the Martyr son of the Martyr" (Wine/Bread?). And for Qata'if (pancakes) "Graves of the Martyrs." And for Faludhaj "Seal of Goodness." And for rice with sugar "Sheikh Al-Tabari with the Military Shawl." And for Lawzinaj "Fingers of the Houris."
Al-Jahiz was eating one day with Muhammad bin Abd al-Malik al-Zayyat. A Faludhaj was brought. Muhammad teased Al-Jahiz and ordered that what slips from the bowl be placed from his side. He hastened in eating until he cleaned what was before him. Muhammad said: "O Abu Uthman, your sky has cleared before the sky of people." He said: "May Allah reform you, because its cloud was thin."

"Section on Metonymy for Drink and Amusements and what is added to them"
The origin in this section is the saying of the poet: "Lo, give me the reddish wine from the milk of the vine... And do not give me 'Khamr' (Wine) with your knowledge or my knowledge. Does it not have many various names?... So bring it, give it to me, and use metonymy for that name."
"It is said": So-and-so asked rain from the cloud of intimacy, milked the milker of joy, struck the fire stick of amusement, and rode the withers of mirth. And So-and-so seeks the blood of clusters, bleeds the veins of jars, and organizes the necklaces of brothers.
Al-Suli narrated saying: Khallad used to report the news of Abu Hafs bin Ayyub to Ibn Tulun. Hafs said to him: "O my master Abu al-Fadl, the gathering of wine is but the gathering of intimacy, the theatre of wish, the quieter of worry, the pasture of amusement, and the institute of joy. Or by what is by its mediation, because you are to me among those whose unseen is not accused."
Al-Sahib wrote: "Our master becomes active to take what extends joy, attracts intimacy, and expands the chest."
"Another wrote": "If expansion is denied in the faces of demands, what gathers the reunion of brothers and disperses types of sorrows is lawful."
"Some used metonymy" for it with "Elixir of Joy," "Alchemy of Happiness," "Antidote of Worries," "Soap of Griefs," and "Solder of the Wombs of the Noble."
"Another wrote": "We returned to the arrows of amusement so we circulated them, and to the vehicles of joy so we rode them."
"Al-Tabari mentioned" in the book "Al-Amthal al-Muwallada" that it is said of the drunkard if he reaches the peak of drunkenness: "Moses has crossed the sea."
Ubayd, the narrator of Al-A'sha, "was asked" about the meaning of Al-A'sha's saying: "And a captive from what Babylon aged... Like the blood of the slaughtered, I robbed it of its color (Jiryal)." He said: I asked Al-A'sha about that. He said: "I drank it red and pissed it red." Jiryal is the color of wine.
"It is narrated" from Al-Sha'bi that he said: I have not heard in metonymies and allusions better than what passed between Ubayd Allah and Al-Harith bin Badr. He said to him one day: "What is this scratch on your face?" He said: "I fell from a sorrel horse of mine," meaning wine. He said: "Where are you from the compliant grey one?" meaning water.
"It is said" in metonymy for the little drinker: "So-and-so is a snuff-taker (Mus'iti)." It is the saying of Ibn Lank: "I ransom you; if you knew some of what is in me... You would not have made me swallow except with a snuff-pot. Suffice you that a vineyard in my neighborhood... I pass by its door so I almost fall."
Abu Ja'far Muhammad bin Musa al-Musawi recited to me for some: "He claims drinking in a pound (Ratl) and a large jar... While the mother of Antara al-Absi suffices him."

Meaning Zabibah (Raisin), and the name of Antara's mother was Zabibah.
"Like this" metonymy, even if from other than this chapter, is the saying of Ibn Tabataba: "Soft of body, imitating water in its thinness... And his heart is a hardness imitating Abu Aws." Meaning a stone (Hajar), so he put Abu Aws in place of the stone, and Abu Aws is (from the root) stone.
"Then" Abu Muslim Muhammad bin Bahr "mourned it" (criticized it) to him. He wrote to him: "Abu Hasan, you tried to bring a rhyme... Solidified in meaning, but it came to you weak. You said Abu Aws, intending metonymy for... The hard stone, so you brought a calamity. If this is permissible, then break without being small... The mouth of the Master, the Gallant, Mu'awiyah." Meaning Rock (Sakhr), which is the name of Abu Sufyan. "Otherwise, we will set up between us for you a battle... So you become banned in Siffin a second time."
The talk returned to the condition of the section. Al-Tabari wrote describing a singer: "So-and-so is the doctor of hearts and ears, and the reviver of the dead of thoughts and natures."
"Others said": "So-and-so feeds ears joy and ignites light in hearts."
Al-Sahib wrote: "Flags of intimacy are fluttering, and tongues of amusements are speaking."
"Abu al-Faraj al-Babbgha wrote": "Amusement has broken its seal, and Intimacy has spread its flags."
"Others said": "We have heard what lifts the veil of the ear, takes the gathering places of the heart, and mixes with the parts of the soul."

The Seventh Chapter
On Various Arts of Metonymy and Allusion
Different in Arrangement

"Section on Metonymy for Removal (Dismissal), Defeat, and some Sultanic Terms"
Al-Rashid said to Yahya bin Khalid: "I wanted to transfer the ring which is with my brother Al-Fadl to my brother Ja'far, but I felt shy to write to him. So write to him yourself and suffice me." Yahya wrote to him: "The Commander of the Faithful has seen fit to transfer the ring from your left to your right." He answered: "Hearing and obedience. No blessing transferred from me that went to my brother."
"A worker wrote" to the one replacing him, so he was gentle and witty: "You have been entrusted with the work in your region, so may Allah congratulate you on the renewal of your mandate. I have sent my successor to your succession, so do not leave him without your guidance until Allah grants your visit." He answered him with these letters: "No blessing transferred from me that went to you, nor was I empty of a honor that encompassed you. I find my dismissal by you a second mandate, and a sufficient connection from the Vizier for what I hope by your place of good ending and praiseworthy consequence."
"Of" the terms of metonymy for dismissal: "The sword of his competence has been sheathed," "The Diwan has been vacated of his leadership," "The weight of work has been lifted from him."
"Metonymy may be used" for dismissal with 'Sarf' (Diversion/Spending), for confiscation with 'Muwaqa'ah' (falling upon/encounter), and for defeat with 'Taraju'' (Retreat) and 'Tahayyuz' (Taking side/Withdrawal). As Abu Ishaq al-Sabi wrote on behalf of Bakhtiyar to a leader of a side facing an enemy: "If a matter befalls you that necessitates caution, you should resolve to withdraw (Tahayyuz) to the Presence, for it is paved for you, not distant from you."
"Metonymy is used" for the riot of the army with 'Lawthah' (Confusion/Taint). As Abu al-Hasan al-Tawmi wrote on behalf of Abu Ali al-Saghawi: "A confusion (Lawthah) has appeared from the retinue; may Allah help in rectifying and treating it."
"Metonymy is used" for shackling (Taqyid), so it is said: "He was secured with iron."
"It is narrated" that Al-Hajjaj said to Al-Ghadban bin al-Qaba'thari: "I will surely carry you on the black (Adham)," using metonymy for shackles. He feigned stupidity and said: "The like of the Prince carries on the black and the grey (Ashhab) (horses)." He said: "It is iron." He said: "To be iron (sharp) is dearer to me than to be stupid (blunt)."
"Metonymy is used" for bribery with "Pouring oil in the lamp." "Perhaps" it is called "Qandalah" (Lamp-ing). Yahya bin Khalid appointed over the Diwan of Tax a man from the people of Khurasan called Abu Salih. He took bribes, so he dismissed him and appointed in his place Sa'dan bin Yahya. It was said regarding him: "Poured into the lamp of Sa'dan... With the greeting, oil. And the lamps of his sons... Before the bay horse disappears." So Yahya dismissed him and returned Abu Salih. It was said regarding him: "The lamp of Sa'dan, by its light... Is a chick to the lamp of Abu Salih. You see him in his council more cross-eyed... From his glancing at the shining dirham."
Regarding this metonymy, I was recited for Ibn Lank: "I say to a group who attacked with Fiqh... And said: What is other than the possessor of knowledge is false. Yes, no knowledge is equal to your reaching... To the money of orphans and widows. I see you turning the judgment upside down... Whenever oil is poured in the lamps."

I heard Abu Zakariya Yahya bin Ismail al-Harbi say: Umar bin Al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him, used metonymy for extracting the Kharaj (land tax), Ushr (tithe), and all rights of the Treasury by his saying: "And make the milch camel of the Muslims flow." He made the flow of Fay' and Kharaj, from which are their stipends, flow by their milch camel.
"Of that" is that our Master Uthman bin Affan, when he assumed the Caliphate, dismissed Amr ibn al-Aas from Egypt. He had been its governor from the day of its conquest in the Caliphate of Al-Faruq until Uthman took over. He appointed in his place Abdullah bin Sa'd bin Abi Sarh. He sent the Kharaj for a year: fourteen thousand thousand (14 million) dinars. Amr ibn al-Aas was present then with Uthman. Amr used to send it as thirteen thousand thousand dinars. Uthman said: "The milch camel has flowed, O Amr." He said: "Yes, O Commander of the Faithful, but you have harmed its weaning camels (young)."

"Section on Metonymy for what is taken as Bad Omen from its Word"
The stung is metonymized by "Al-Salim" (Safe). The blind by "Al-Basir" (Seer). The desert (perishing place) by "Al-Mafazah" (Place of winning/safety). The Angel of Death by "Abu Yahya" (Father of John/Lives). Al-Sahib was witty in describing two brothers, handsome and ugly, where he said: "Yahya resembled the confused (moon?), but he has... A brother who resembled the face of Abu Yahya."
The Abyssinian is metonymized by "Abu al-Bayda'" (Father of the White), as the poet said: "Abu Salih is the opposite of his name and nickname... Just as you see the Negro called Ambergris. And he is nicknamed Abu al-Bayda' while the color is pitch-black... But they came with it for (avoiding) bad omen."
When the news reached Al-Mansur of the revolt of Muhammad bin Ibrahim bin Abdullah bin al-Hasan in Basra, while he was in a garden of his in Baghdad, he looked at a tree and said to Al-Rabi': "What is the name of this tree?" He said: "Obedience (Ta'ah), O Commander of the Faithful." It was a willow (Khilaf - pun on dissent). Al-Mansur took good omen from that and wondered at his intelligence.
"Parallel" to this metonymy, even if not in its meaning, is what is told that a man passed in the courtyard of Al-Rashid's palace with a bundle of bamboo (Khayzuran). Al-Rashid said to Al-Fadl bin al-Rabi': "What is that?" He said: "Roots of spears, O Commander of the Faithful." He hated to say "Khayzuran" because it matched the name of Al-Rashid's mother.
"As for" metonymy for what should not be metonymized, there is a story here mentioned by Ibn Abdus in the Book of Viziers and Scribes. He said that the names of a group of scribes were presented to Al-Mutawakkil to be invested with works. Among those presented to him was the name of Tamas bin Akhi Ibrahim bin al-Abbas. He struck it out and said: "He is not appointed nor honored, for he uses metonymy for Cupping (Hijama)." He calls the sun "Al-Adwah" (The Enemy). He uses metonymy for the snake with "Al-Tawilah" (The Long One), and for the Jinn with "Ammar al-Dar" (Inhabitants of the House).

"Section on Metonymy for Grooming the Body"
I heard Al-Tabari say: I was one day before Sayf al-Dawla in Aleppo. A cousin of his entered upon him. The Prince deemed him slow and said to him: "Where were you today and with what were you busy?" He said: "May Allah support our Master, I shaved my head, fixed my hair, and clipped my nails." He said to him: "(If) you said: 'I took from my ends', it would have been more concise and eloquent." Better than this is the saying of Allah Almighty: "Then let them end their untidiness (Tafath)." Abu Mansur al-Azhari said in the book "Tahdhib al-Lugha": None of the linguists interpreted Tafath as Al-Nadr bin Shumayl interpreted it, as he made Tafath (to be) dishevelment (Sha'ath), and made its ending its removal by entering the bathhouse, shaving, taking from the hair, plucking the armpit, and shaving the pubic hair.
"Of the subtleties" of doctors is their metonymies for diarrhea with "Istifragh" (Evacuation) and for vomiting with "Ta'aluj" (Treatment).
"I found" in the handwriting of Abu al-Hasan al-Salami in a notebook of his selected poetry he gifted to Abu al-Hasan Muhammad bin Abdullah al-Karkhi, innovative verses of his in metonymy for depilatory paste (Nura): "When he grew a beard, his black turban became... Imitating the circle of the jaw. So he began plotting or softening... To shave the hair from his buttocks or attack. Every day you see him wrapped... In the garden between the pools and ponds. We did not know that he is a moon... Until he was clothed in a piece of the firmament (Falak - pun on sky/basin)."

"Section on what deviated from this Chapter of Metonymies in the reports of the Prophet, peace be upon him"

"It is narrated" from Abu Umamah from Aisha, may Allah Almighty be pleased with her, that the Prophet, peace be upon him, said: "None of you should say: My soul has become bad (Khabuthat). Let him say: My soul has become nauseous (Laqisat)."
"It is narrated" that Banu Qurayzah and Ka'b bin Asad, when they contracted with the Prophet, peace be upon him, for a truce, he accepted it from them. When it was the Year of the Trench, Huyayy bin Akhtab came to them and incited them to break the covenants, so they broke them. The news came to the Prophet, peace be upon him, so he sent men to find out the news. He said to them: "If it is true, then hint it to me with a hint I know, and do not break the arms of the people. And if they are upon loyalty, then declare it and announce it." They came to them, and they burned their book upon which they contracted with the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him. The people returned and said: "Adal and Al-Qarah," using metonymy that they betrayed as Adal and Al-Qarah betrayed. They are Banu al-Hawn bin Khuzaimah. They came to the Prophet, peace be upon him, and said: "There is Islam in us by the Messenger of Allah, so send to us a group of your companions to teach us." He sent with them seven men, their leader Marthad. When they were at Batn al-Raji', a water for Banu Hudhayl, the Adalis said to Marthad: "Stay until we find a place for you." They went until they came to Banu Lihyan and said: "These are a group of the companions of Muhammad. We guide you to them on condition that what you obtain from this is between us and you." They said: "Yes." Some of them preferred themselves (surrendered) and some refused, so they killed those who did not surrender. This is the story of Adal and Al-Qarah.
The companions of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, when they sat with him, it was as if birds were on their heads. Hassan sprang one day and recited to him the saying of Al-A'sha: "Both your parents - the branch was a support... But they increased and I became decreasing. You spend the night in winter full of your bellies... While your female neighbors are hungry, spending the night empty-bellied." The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said to him: "Do not recite the satire of Alqama, for Abu Sufyan riled me up (Shaghaba minni) before Heraclius, so Alqama went west (Gharroba) upon him." Hassan said: "O Messenger of Allah, whoever your hand reached, his thanks is obligatory upon us." Nothing has been heard in metonymy for slander better than his saying "Shaghaba minni", nor in metonymy for denial and protest like his saying "Gharroba alayhi", nor in apology like Hassan's saying "Whoever your hand reached, his thanks is obligatory upon us."

"Section on the Opposite of Metonymy"
Its meaning is uglifying the beautiful, just as the meaning of metonymy is beautifying the ugly. Some wits "entered" a vineyard and looked at the unripe grapes (Hisrim). He said: "O Allah, blacken his face, cut his neck, and give me his blood to drink." It is said that Sulayman ibn Kathir said it, and the mention of Abu Muslim al-Khurasani had run before him. The talk was reported to Abu Muslim, so he admonished him for it. He denied having said it about him. Abu Muslim said: "The trustworthy informed me about you regarding this." He said: "Yes, I said it, but in vineyard such-and-such when I looked at the unripe grapes. Ask the narrator about that. If he mentions to you the story of the vineyard, believe me. If he mentions to you that I said it in a place other than the vineyard, then the matter is as you thought." Someone who did not give it its due versified this prose when he said: "I passed by a cluster of vineyard hanging... Dripping wetness one day, and it was unripe. So I said: May Allah show me your face blackened... And may I be given to drink, O cluster, from your hollow, the blood."
"Ibn Mukarram passed" by Abu al-Ayna' who was on a prayer rug of his. He wanted to sit on it with him. He said: "You cannot fit on my prayer rug." He said: "Rather, it is a rolling place for a cat (Sinnawr - pun on Fasq/sin?)."
"When" Sa'id bin Humayd was appointed over the Diwan of Post at the Presence, Abu Ali al-Basir said about him: "By my father! The soul of Sa'id... Indeed, it is a noble soul. He ceased not to trick until... He became the Winker (Ghammaz) of the Caliph."

"Section on what deviated from the Book of Metonymies of the people of Baghdad"
"They use metonymy" for the beard with "Beauties" (Mahasin). They say to one who has a mote in his beard: "Your hand on your beauties."
"They use metonymy" for decoration with "Shatmah" (Insult) with Zay (Zatmah/Zaymah?). Some people of the age said: "A friend of ours whom Time clothed... With clothes of wealth raising his status. We see him thick of speech temperament... If pride broke his eyelids. He addresses his brothers with Kaf... And insults his boys with Zay."
"They say" regarding one who is mocked while not knowing: "He danced in his boat."
"They pray" against one whom they visit repeatedly saying: "May Allah empower over him what ruminates," meaning the lion.
They use metonymy for the pimp with "Al-Naqib" (The Captain/Leader). Al-Sahib said: "O Ibn Ya'qub, O Captain of Moons... Be my intercessor to a happy youth. Say to him that beauty has a Zakat... So give it in charity to the abandoned."

"Section on Arts of Allusions"

The Arabs use allusion (Ta'rid) in their speech, so they reach their will in a way that is subtler and better than revealing and declaring. They fault a man if he reveals in every way. They say: "So-and-so does not improve allusion except as slander." Allah made it permissible in proposing to women, saying: "There is no blame upon you for that to which you [indirectly] allude concerning a proposal to women or for what you conceal within yourselves." He did not permit declaration. Allusion in proposal is to say to the woman: "By Allah, indeed you are beautiful, and indeed you are young, and perhaps Allah will provide you a righteous husband, and indeed women are of my needs," and similar speech.
"Some philologists narrated" that a group of Bedouins went out to gather provisions. When they returned, a man sneaked at night to the sack of his companion, took it, and put it in his sack. When he wanted to depart and they stood to help each other load (Ta'akama), he saw his sack rising light and his companion's sack tipping and heavy. He recited saying: "A sack ate the dinner of some of the people's sacks... I have not seen a thieving sack before today."
"From" Sa'id bin Jubayr from Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, regarding His saying, Great and Glorious, narrating about Moses, peace be upon him: "Do not blame me for what I forgot." He said: He did not forget, but it was from the allusions of speech. Ibn Abbas meant that he did not say "Indeed I forgot" so he would be a liar, but he said "Do not blame me for what I forgot" making him imagine forgetfulness as an allusion.
"Sharik al-Numayri rode with" Umar bin Hubayrah al-Fazari on a mule. It passed Umar's palfrey. Umar said to him: "Lower its rein (control/gaze)." Sharik said: "It is Maktuba (Written/Destined - pun)." Umar intended the saying of the poet: "So lower the gaze, indeed you are from Numayr... You reached neither Ka'b nor Kilab." Sharik intended the saying of the other: "Do not trust a Fazari you are alone with... On your young she-camel, and write it with straps."
"A Tamimi and a Numayri met" in a gathering and waded with the waders. The Tamimi said: "I like the falcon among birds of prey." The Numayri said: "Especially if it hunts the sandgrouse (Qata)." The Tamimi only intended the saying of the poet: "I am the falcon overlooking Numayr... Allowed from the sky for it is the pouring." The Numayri intended the saying of Al-Tirimmah: "Tamim knocks on meanness, more guided than the sandgrouse... And if it walked the paths of noble deeds, it would get lost."
"A man from Muharib entered" upon Abdullah bin Yazid al-Hilali while he was in Armiliyah. Abdullah said: "What did we encounter last night from the Sheikhs of Muharib! They did not let us sleep," meaning frogs. He intends the saying of Al-Akhtal: "Croak with nothing, Sheikhs of Muharib... I did not think them to be feathered nor sharpened. Frogs in the darkness of night responded to each other... So the water snake was guided to them by their voice." He said: "May Allah reform you, they lost a veil (Burqu') last night, so they were searching for it." He intends the saying of the poet: "For every Hilali there is a shield from meanness... And for Ibn Yazid there is a veil and housings."
"Of allusions by deed" is what is narrated that Mu'awiyah sent speech to Amr ibn al-Aas. He said to the messenger: "Look what he returns to you." When he spoke, Amr bit his thumb until the messenger finished, and did not add to that. When he returned to Mu'awiyah, he informed him of his deed. Mu'awiyah said to him: "What did he intend?" He said: "I do not know." He said: "He only said: Do you scold me while I chew the bit of a strong horse?"
"Al-Fadl" bin al-Rabi' was impugned in his lineage because Al-Rabi' was a slave (Mamluk), but he attributed himself to Yunus bin Muhammad bin Abi Farwah, client of Uthman. That is because a slave girl of Yunus gave birth to Al-Rabi', and Yunus denied him. When he grew up, he sold him. Conditions and ownerships turned him until Ziyad bin Abdullah al-Harithi, maternal uncle of Al-Saffah, bought him. When he saw his intelligence and literature, he gifted him to Al-Mansur. When he freed him and favored him, it reached him that he attributes himself to Yunus. He disciplined him and said: "I freed you and chose you, then you claim the clientage of Uthman?" For this story, Ja'far bin Yahya nicknamed Al-Fadl bin al-Rabi' "Abu Ruh" because the foundling is metonymized by it. The people of Medina call the foundling "Farkh" (Chick), and it is with them a chick of adultery. It is told that Al-Rashid was eating one day with Ja'far. Three chicks were placed for him. Al-Rashid said to Ja'far joking: "Divide them for equality in my eating." He said: "A division of justice or injustice?" He said: "A division of justice." Ja'far took two chicks and left one. Al-Rashid said to him: "Is this justice?" He said: "Yes, with you are two chicks, and with me are two chicks." He said: "Then where is the other?" He said: "This," and pointed to Al-Fadl bin al-Rabi' who was standing at his head. Al-Rashid smiled and said: "O Fadl, if you held fast to our clientage, this would fall from you." Al-Fadl did not understand what they said except after a while.
It is narrated that a man from Banu Fazara threw a blue ring to a man from Banu Dabbah. The Dabbi tied a strap on it and returned it to him. He only intended the saying of Al-Fazari the poet: "Your eyes were endowed, O son of Muka'bar... Just as every Dabbi is blue from meanness." "Do not trust a Fazari you are alone with... On your young she-camel, and write it with straps."

"Abu Ali al-Salami mentioned" in the book "Nutaf al-Turaf" that Abdullah bin Tahir appointed some of his cousins over Marw. Its people complained of him. A group of them came as a delegation to Abdullah and complained to him and spoke much about him. He thought they were exaggerating against him, so he did not dismiss him. When they left, some Sheikhs there said: "I will suffice you of him." He arrived at Abdullah, who asked him about the condition of the country. He informed of calm and tranquility. Then he asked him about the news of their governor. He described him with virtue, literature, and what the Prince gathers of lineage, and exaggerated in mentioning the good. Then he said: "Except that he..." and pecked with his finger on his head a peck (Naqrah), meaning he is light-brained. Abdullah said: "What have governors to do with recklessness? Console him." So he dismissed him. The Sheikh returned to Marw and informed them that he dismissed him with a peck (Naqrah).
I heard Abu Nasr Sahl bin al-Marzuban say: A son was born to Ibn Mukarram, so Abu al-Ayna' came to him congratulating. When he left, he left a stone behind him, alluding that the child belongs to the bed (Firash) and for the adulterer is the stone (Hajar).
"Ibn Abdus recounted" in the book of Viziers and Scribes that Sulayman bin Wahb was in charge of Kharaj and Estates in Egypt, and Al-Husayn the Servant, known as 'Arq al-Mawt' (Sweat of Death), was in charge of the Post there. He attended one day with Al-Husayn, and he used to joke with him much. He called for a Sikbajiyya soup (vinegar stew), and it was brought. When he drank it, he said: "O boy, bring me a toothpick (Khilal)." Those present wondered at his request for a toothpick after the soup. He only alluded to Al-Husayn the Servant, indicating that servants (eunuchs), if they age, make toothpicks. Al-Husayn said: "O boy, bring us two toothpicks (Khilalayn)," and placed one of his index fingers on the other like the shape of a cross, alluding to Sulayman that he was a Christian, and he was accused of collusion with Christians.
And Allah Glory be to Him, the Exalted, knows best.
Then the Book of the End in that Metonymy...
And may Allah bless our Master Muhammad and his family and companions and grant peace.
